content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Unfortunately ES isn't a very good 4x strategy game, playing it more only reveals all the major flaws of the game, however one major aspect of any 4x game is decently programmed AI, and that is something Endless Space doesn't have at all, since the AI is poorly programmed and starts with more or less infinite bonuses and the ability to do things the player can't -  the outcome of the game almost always leans in favor of the A.I winning no matter the difficulty setting, unless the player has enough experience to know all the aspects of the game, knows the skill tree and how to get important research done first and of course, the player gets an almost legendary start.    Even on the easiest of difficulty settings, the A.I can still easily beat a skilled human player because of the boosted AI stats.  Not to mention, throwing almost endless high powered fleets of ships if war is declared against the player and to add further insult, knowing almost intimate information about the players empire so it can attack your weakest points at any time, like many 4x games - basically the AI is programmed to cheat since thats the easiest way to program an AI to give a human player a challenge, even on the newbie difficulty A.I difficulty makes me want to face palm.   I'd like to know how its possible for an A.I player with a couple of planets to have nearly double the score I have sometimes when I have nearly triple the star systems, wonders and a large fleet of ships?Some would say its a "Smart A.I" but there is a difference between a proper smart A.I and one that has been programmed with cheap bonuses that more or less gives it a clear winning edge against the player.   Also, I think the galaxy map isn't big enough, the so called "Huge" map feels quite small by comparison to other 4x space strategy games with maybe less than a 100 star systems without mods.  Many of the good mods unfortunately break the game completely as they haven't been updated, these mods we're perhaps the saving grace of the game but now its more or less been abandoned. Like someone commented, this game seems to be better played co-op against A.I players.  Single player just isn't worth your time, especially if your a 4x fan - ES seems to be more like a zerg rush than empire building, which weakens the gameplay considerably -  so the title really should be changed to Endless Zerg or Endless Fleets. I think the premise of the game is fairly good, the graphics, sound - all that is fine.   The problem really lies with the execution of the gameplay, thats where it falls down.    I think a sequel that fixes all the major problems the original has would be a good contender for the top 4x space strategy title,  but they need to fix a lot of problems and make sure they don't make the same mistakes. 4x space strategy is about expansion, empire building - in a nutshell turtling out your empire, building fleets - defending choke points - exploring the galaxy.  ES does this, but in such a way it all takes the back burner,  the galaxy without 'working' mods is way too small - The AI cheats too much to make the game fun or interesting, so a sequel needs better programmed AI without infinite bonuses or other stupid stuff.  Overall, 4/10  Endless Space isn't 'terrible' per say, but AI does heavily let the game down.  GalCiv remains the king of 4x space strategy games.  I'm glad I got this from the Humble Bundle sale, I would never pay full price for this.   I would like to see a sequel to see if they can improve the game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												I like this game, it's pretty good. It has pretty great civ customization options, a pretty good galaxy customization scheme, and a neat approach to in-universe tech explanations. The devs are pretty good with long-term upkeep, and have released regular updates so far.However, it is a bit awfully easy to win using economic, science, and wonder victories. As in, extremely easy unless you're playing on the top-tier difficulties. The combat isn't particularly deep and doesn't really get any better, and the hero system is pretty useless sometimes.Disharmony adds a neat dimension to the game by removing a quarter of the economic system as a challenge, but you'll only end up playing as the Harmony once you're comfortable with the game. Since they're packing a lot of new features in updates for Disharmony, I'd say it's probably worth it.All in all, Endless Space + Disharmony is a good purchase at prices below $20. I got the entire package at $12 during a sale, so I'm happy.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												**9.5/10**HANDS DOWN!Is the game perfect? No. Does it have some of the same issues other turn-based 4X games have? Yes. But that is where the similarities to other generic 4X games (like Civilization) end. The game occupies one of the most fascinating sci-fi settings I've seen in a strategy game, second only to Starcraft.  The gameplay is fluid, easy to pick up, but hard to master.  And as for strategy, well, let's just say even the toughest game of Risk couldn't prepare you for the decisions you have to make on the fly in this game when playing at high difficulty, both in terms of expanding to other star systems as well as micro-managing the indivudal planets and systems you already control.Before I bought this game, I had never played an Amplitude Studios game.  "Endless Space" has single-handedly turned me into an Amplitude fanboy!*** Also, if you enjoy "Endless Space" I HIGHLY reccommend that you also pick up their Early-Access games "Dungeon of the Endless" and "Endless Legend".  They are the most highly polished early-access games I've ever seen on Steam.  This studio knows what they're doing!

												„Endless Space“ is a complete and very nice game. It remembers me on older games like „Master of Orion II and III“ and „Galactic Civilizations II“. It seems to me that the game designer knows much science fiction books like for exemple Frank Herbert's „Dune“ and Isaac Asimov's „Foundation“- series. The game is nearly perfect and you are missing nothing of the usual science fiction stuff, when you are playing it. You really make no mistake if you buy it. The game is not difficult to play but it could be that it is finished sometimes to fast. The research tree is consisting on four branches but you need not research all steps. If you concentrate yourself on one of the many victory ways you will surely win.The metascore of the game is 77; i would say that an 80 is justified. The game is pure fun and the known feature „terraforming“ opens you many ways to build a perfect galactic empire.Achim Hamm

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												 	Being a fan of Science Fiction and Strategy games, I was intrigued when I saw Endless Space on Steam. Not only did it combine both of my favorite genres, but it was an indie game as well. So I decided to take it for a spin. Little did I realize that I would be sucked into a vibrant universe and asking my wife to allow me "Just one more turn!"Endless Space plays like a standard 4X game. The player guides his race in gathering resources, researching technologies, building up a military force, and managing star systems in an attempt to conquer the galaxy. What sets this title apart from its peers is how it combines these elements together. First off, the game is easy to learn. This is because the interface is clean and very intuitive. Gone are the days of sifting through various menus to find out what something is and what you are working on. For example, if you want to see what you are researching, just click on the research button. You are then presented with an easy to read research tree with the current project highlighted. Also, if you are unsure what something is or does, just mouse over the item and it will tell you what it is. As with any game of this type, managing your far flung empire later in the game can get tedious. Amplitude Studios combats this problem in a unique way. When an event happens you are notified by a pop-up that will take you to the event when you click on it. If multiple events are present, this pop-up will remain until the player dismisses it or has addressed all the events listed. While this goes a long way to ease empire management, it does not totally resolve the problem. Later turns can still be long and drawn out while you deal with these events.The combat in Endless Space is where the game excels. The player can either have the computer resolve the battle automatically, or the player can take control and fight the battle. It is one of the few titles that I have played where tactics are essential. Do I send my fighters in first or do I bombard the enemy from a distance. Each choice affects not only if you are successful, but how many losses one sustains. The game also rewards players for using a mix of ship types. While yes, one could win a battle with a battle group composed of only battleships, but a "combined arms" battle group will make the battles quicker with less losses. This creates a world where each battle is different, and sometimes the "weaker" side will win.The only problem with Endless Space is that the factions are balanced too well. No matter what faction you play, you have some sort of built in counter that negates the other faction's abilities. At first this made the game really easy to play and but soon it can become monotonous. Most of the balance issues have been addressed with the Disharmony DLC and patches, but some of them still remain.Overall, I have to give Endless Space 9 out of 10 stars. This highly polished and easy to learn game has raised the standard for not only games from the 4X genre, but indie games as well. I highly recommend it to not only fans of the 4X genre, but new players as well. Just make sure to say goodbye to your friends and family before you play!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I've been learning this 4x game by exploration, which is oddly appropriate considering exploration is a good part of the game.  It has been living in a window on my other monitor, which is one of those pleasant advantages of a turn based game, so I haven't really played as many hours as it will say I have -- but it's been a constant companion for days.  I work on things on the "tomato" rule -- do something, take a break -- and this has been my "take a break."  The devs have managed to infused a good feeling of RPG into the factions and context of the game.  It's polished like an apple, the art style is gorgeous, the music is...well, it reminded me of Eve and I turned it off after a bit.  But the skill trees are deep and interesting, the strategy is pleasantly no-one-solution, the achievements are -- many of them -- gigglesome and some might really appeal to the obsessive.Much more elegant than Sid Meier's stuff.  It appeals to the anthropologist (xenologist?), engineer, and storyteller in me as well as the game geek/dev/closet space grognard.I find myself interested in trying to win the game as different factions having played against random different factions as AI in 2 player games.  I find myself doing dishes and modelling how larger games with more factions would work out, after a few days of playing.  What better recommendation for a game than that it amuses me away from the keyboard, as well as at the keyboard?

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Reading the other positive reviews, I don't understand how people are recommending this game. They list out all of the same flaws I found but they're still recommending the game...? I guess 4X just isn't what it used to be, but I found this game to be terrible. The UI wasn't friendly at all - information was in completely different places on different screens, and doing simple tasks was often confusing. I had to do a google search to figure out how to upgrade my existing ships.The combat was boring and gave very little feedback as to what happened or why. The default view of combat jumps around like a speed freak, and although you can turn it off you'll be back to the same view next time. There was a description of how much damage you did but in mixed fleets that wasn't enough to tell you what happened. I finally gave up when a hero-led fleet was repairing faster than I could damage the ships. The hero character was completely unbalancing.Parts of the game had potential which is what made the things that didn't work so much more frustrating. For the first ten turns I thought I finally had something that was an update of the old 4X classics.

												This is a 4X game with tabletop grade gameplay. The cinematics are impressive, but rare. The actual gameplay is turn based and on a strict node system. The screenshots and videos paint a poor picture of the actual game content, and I found Star Ruler to be much more satisfying, with its 3D galaxies, extensive expansion capacities, and customizable ships for realtime combat.If you like freeform strategy, I wouldn't recommend this title.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2012
												Behold, endless space.You will be astounded at the wonderfully complex systems this game offers, everything from custom ships to procedural systems with unique planets that offer an array of negative anomalies to make your expansion and developmet within the game no less than abysmal.Stand in awe as you bleed hours away while sifting through the tech tree searching deep within the depths of a seemingly endless array of technology that also feels procedurally generated and is delivered with skillful random assembly.Watch in amazement as you expand your Empire upon the stars, flying into the unkown, discovering procedurally generated systems and planets containing a baffling number of negative effects that will make your people develop an unending disatisfaction of you and their new homeworlds.As you bask in amazement of your empires rage you will find yourself in endless space, finding new ways to appease your people meanwhile a vast array of alien species that will threaten your empire and push you to new heights of frustration.Upon countering that new plateu you will enter the ship customizer and find you have no tech in weapons, thus leading to your imminent reduction in empire size and your eventual defeat on Newbie difficulty.Endless Frustration.Lots of good ideas, terrible execution lacking proper difficulty scaling. The in game systems are so complex and confusing it is nearly impossible the play "correctly" without dedicating a huge amount of time to understand how it works - which as far as i can tell is very inconsistent. Things that should be common sense are not so and it seems that it was deliberately made to become obscenely harder the longer you play but in doing so went the opposite direction as to what would apply to common sense of an empires' development and that breaks the game since even an economically inclined person will have to throw away his appropriate logic in order to conform to the unjustifiably broken systems in Endless Space.

But I gave up on December 31st, 2012, and haven't played since after I realized that no matter what style of play I adopted, the AI oppenents at just about the same juncture in every game would apruptly declare war on me. It didn't matter whether I was accomodating or threatening, powerful or way behind, I got attacked. For me, these MoO style 4X games are all about creating a grand narrative and being engaged by that unfolding story. For all its plus factors, this program's apparently rigid algorithm just kept getting in the way.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												I wanted to like Endless Space so badly. I love 4x space games, and like a lot of us am still waiting for the successor to Master of Orion 2 to come along. I'd been hoping ES would finally succeed where so many others had failed. In fact, I periodically download and play it again hoping that maybe I was wrong and there's a good game buried in there somewhere.There's not.As many people have written the biggest problem is combat. There's nothing interesting about it. There are three types of weapons and three types of defenses. Each gets linearly more powerful as you tech up, and each defense stops one type of weapon and is useless against the other two. If you have the right defense against an enemy ship you win. If you don't, they win. There's a system where you play three cards to influence the battle, but it moves too slowly and has too little impact to make any difference.There's no diversity of units like in Civilization nor tactical combat like in Master of Orion (or the brilliant Total War series). There's just a big game of rock, paper, scissors. One side wins, the other side loses, you rebuild and repeat. Don't bother with any other type of victory either. There's no room for cleverness in a rocks/paper/scissors system and no stationary defenses, so if you don't put everything into your military the player who did will crush you every time.It's the same with domestic policy. Your systems have to specialize, so you pick whether a system will produce money, tech or industry, plug in all the appropriate buildings and then auto build cash, science or ships. You don't really decide which to do, because each planet is good for one particular thing so the system composition pretty much decides this for you. There's nothing interesting happening in the galaxy or territory uniquely worth fighting over, no external threat or game changing discoveries. Even the little tactical interest that comes from star lanes and wormholes is gone shortly into the game once ships can fly through open space.By the mid-game your empire is pretty much running on autopilot. Cash and science systems tick away and your only interaction is to build fleets and throw them at the enemy. Periodically you upgrade the design of your ships for new science or if the enemy switches to a different weapon.Most of the problem came from the developers' focus on making a multiplayer game. They stripped the mechanics down in order to keep them balanced, and that ultimately made the game *much* less interesting. The wonders, for example, confer system bonuses instead of being big, powerful icons that can change the course of play. System bonuses aren't interesting. I can catch up to that with a few extra factories and don't even need to if they show up on a lousy planet. But the multiplayer would be unbalanced if one person could, by random chance, stumble across a game changer. It's the same with everything else. There are no weird discoveries to make in the galaxy or overpowered planets, like MOO2's gaians, because that would advantage one player too much. Military tech marches up rails up three branches and that's it, no clever or assymetrical weapons or decisions to make for fear of breaking things. Even the races are just a collection of relatively minor statistical differences from each other, nothiing that feels truly different or unique.There are a lot of little things wrong with Endless Space and a couple of big ones, but ultimately the game just isn't that much fun. It feels flat and lifeless. One play through is pretty much exactly like every other and by midway through your second game you'll get bored.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												As a big fan of 4X Space Strategy games, I find Endless Space quite lacking.  While it mimics other 4X games adequately, it has very little unique.  Both diplomacy and research are extremely limited, with no room for variation in either department.  Combat is simplistic and underwhelming.  You play the role of observer more than anything.  Only one thing stands out as different: system invasion.  Instead of just blockading or taking over, you have to wear down a system's resistance, an especially useful system when being attacked on multiple fronts.  All in all, though, 5 out of 10 stars.

												Good for a few games, but really the fact that it's an Indie title clearly shows after you get past that. Multiplayer is buggy as all hell, I can't tell you how many times the game froze halfway when all players completed their turn and it just had to be aborted. Not to mention if you don't set the game speed to fast you'll be playing for 6 or so hours just to complete a single game. Finally, the game is very snowball-ish, once a player pulls ahead, his resources will keep him only amassing more and more, keeping him ahead, with very little to be done to stop him/her. I love the concept, but it's just not refined enough. I recommend passing on this title.

												It's a nice 4X space game, but the AI is more than a bit wonky, the learning curve is steep, the tech tree (which is more accurately described as a four-sectioned web) is flat-out unintuitive, the combat is essentially glorified rock-paper-scissors with almost no strategy whatsoever, and the interfaces could use some polishing. Mac OSX support is excellent for an Apple geek like me, but my opinion on this game is simple: pretty much everything Endless Space does, Galactic Civilizations II does better. Get GalCiv. Enough said.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I consider myself a pretty heavy Space 4X afficionado.  I have played a very wide range of titles in the genre, including MOO2, Sins of a Solar Empire, Space Empires IV and V, Galactic Civilizations II, StarDrive, and Endless Space.  I have even played some of the much older titles, such as Stars! and Spaceward Ho!Unfortunately, I have to agree with TotalBiscuit's assessment of this game: it is well put together, and it is executed adequately, but it lacks soul.THE GOOD:*The user interface in this game is one of the most easy-to-use and informative Space 4X UI's I have ever seen.  I can usually get all of the information I need with a couple of clicks.  Queueing up production, changing tax percentages, or checking which systems needed my immediate attention was very accessible and intuitive.  Gone are the days when I had to make 5+ clicks just to find the information I was looking for, and then 3+ more clicks in order to implement a decision based on that information.*The music in this game is fantastic.  If I could, I would rip the music from this game and use it in the other Space 4X games that I enjoy.  I was also impressed by the fact that the music was somewhat dynamic; when I was in the main space view, the music played with its full instrumentation, but when I went into system view or ship design, the instrumentation scaled back dynamically and played a more sparse version of the same music.  I suspect they have two simultaneous tracks going on at the same time and the game dynaimcally fades from one to the other based on user actions.*The game is challenging early on.  If you don't expand quickly into different systems and establish the borders of your empire, other races will come in and take neighboring systems much earlier than you would expect.  Moreover, if other civilizations don't see you building up a strong enough military early in the game, many of them will simply declare war on you because you look like an easy target.*The tech tree is extensive and varied.  With four main branches to work through, there is plenty of new tech that can be researched through early, mid, and late stages of the game.*Victory conditions are varied and well developed.  The traditional military victory is available, of course, but you can also win the game by expansion (own a certain percentage of the galaxy), science (research enough tech to 'ascend' to a new form of existance), diplomacy (ally yourself with most/all other races, and prevent war for a certain amount of time), economic (earn/control a certain amount of resources/cash), and others.THE BAD:*Combat is by far the most disappointing aspect of this game.  Don't get me wrong--the combat is rendered beautifully, with cinematic camera movements and fabulous explosions.  Sadly, however, combat is NOT user-controllable.  Granted, you can pick rock-paper-scissors style cards that have effects on the stages of combat, but that is as far as user control goes.  I wanted to be able to direct my big battleships and dreadnoughts to strategic positions on the battlefield, while keeping close tabs on the ships that were damaged so that I could steer them away from danger.  No such luck.  As beautiful as the space battles are in this game, I found myself simply picking auto-combat again and again.*Though the races in the game have interesting back stories and differences of starting attributes, in actual gameplay, the races don't really feel much different from each other.  Sure, there are a small number race-specific techs that can be found in the tech tree, but even these don't feel much different than what can be researched by other races.*Planetary colonization and development is boring and forgettable.  There are a few key structures that you can build on each specific planet, but for the most part, the entire star system feels like a single 'colony', for which you build system-wide improvements.  The 'value' of each of these 'colonies' is vastly determined by the number of planets in the system and the amount of population that you can grow system-wide.  Gone are the challenges of a single, resource-rich, but barely colonizable planet that you have to carefully grow to become a viable production center; as long as there are other more hospitable planets in the system, then a low-value planet is virtually pain-free.*Diplomacy in this game is absolutely ridiculous.  While I like the fact that you have to research more advanced diplomacy actions (i.e. trade treaties, tech swapping, alliances, etc.), I felt like the AI was grossly weighted against you in most diplomatic situations.  Even when I was fully allied with a race, with full friendly relationships, they would still ask me for my arms, legs, first-born child, and the soul of my fleet admiral in exchange for a single new technology.  After many attempts, I simply gave up trying to trade technology with my neighbors.  Furthermore, even good races would break treaties with you seemlingly on a whim--I found myself unable to reliably predict how long my good relations with other races would last.*Ship design doesn't allow much as far as meaningful decision-making.  Most of the time, you'll be designing ships with the absolute best weaponry and armor that you have researched; there is very little reason (aside from production cost) to ever use a lesser tech.  Every once in a while, I created a specialized ship (such an invasion ship with high planetary attack capacity but very little ship-to-ship offense, or a carrier that had very little weaponry but loads of fighters and bombers on board).  In many other Space 4X games, I have the ability to design support ships (i.e. refuel, re-supply, repair, or even mobile ship construction yards), transports, miners/resource collectors, star bases, etc.  Not in Endless Space.I wanted to love this game.  I really did.  I put more than 80 hours into it, playing as various different factions (good, neutral, and evil).  But in the end, the lack of controllable combat, the clumsy and unforgiving diplomacy system, and the uninspiring planet/system management process eventually made me decide to go back to other Space 4X games.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Mediocre and not user friendly (mabye even buggy). This game needs to take a lot of tips from other games like civilization 5, like not letting you end your turn without all your solar systems and units having something to do. Or some parts that seem down right BUGGY. Multiple games I had my fleet of military ships stuck on a single star system because the enemy fleet could endlessly retreat from battle and still prevent me from going anywhere. Or my last game I had where I conquered one system and when I moved into the next all my fleets where stuck and unmovable. Literally no action could be made with them, no fighting or invading and I couldn't even move new troops into that system either.Another terrible part of this game is that if a system is invaded even if the ship(s) have no way (or reseached the tech) to invade will still prevent all units from being made or instanly bought there. So the computer can and will incapasitate you from building military or expansion.Like when I first started playing on the easiest of like 7 difficulties newbie, there are pages and pages of tutorials for everything and every menu in this game. But thats fine its a civilization simulator, except that the AI will still beat you on newbie, they expand faster, build military faster, and anything else to win win the game better (Even if that's not their forte). Funny Civilization 5 (and civ 3) has their AI brain dead on the easiest level, so players can sandbox the game while they learn.The fun parts arn't all that fun, but you can expand and compete for the best planets and manages your species and their approval. You and can build fleets of military ships and enjoy what amounts to reletively the same prerendered cutscene but with diferent ships and most of all random camera angles.I really did try to like this game, in fact I've play far too much civ 5 and I wanted to like this game but I don't.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Endless Space DisharmonyLong story short = dont buy this DLCWARNING !!! LONG READ AHEAD !!!I had about 40 hours of gameplay on the clasic Emperor Edition and I loved it. Then I bought the Disharmony DLC.First thing that changed (to the bad imho) was the tech tree. The warfare tree got dumbed down. Yes, it has new features like bombers and the Siege tech to invade systems but the ship weapons pulled the short one.In the description of the game they say how good it is that now you can select if you want Long, medium or melee weapons on your ships which imho is stupid. In Emperor Edition you just put the best weapons you had and if you still had space, you could put on some weaker ones to maximize dmg. In Disharmony you cant do that. If you want put Long, medium and melee weapons on the ship = you cant do that. If you put,lets say, medium range torpedos then thats all you can add in the torpedo section. You cant combine long, medium and melee.You can have only 1 type of torpedos. You also cant put weaker ones in if you want to fill up the space of the ship as I mentioned above.Next, the bugs.I said I had the Emperor edition before. When you launch the game it asks you which key to use. You have 3 options. Honestly I dont even know why are there 3 keys there. Does using the last key of the game give you some extra stuff? I dont know but there you have it.After downloading DISHARMONY all my saved games from Emperor Edition got lost. I sent them a report which didnt help at all. At that time it was a 35 hour gameplay that went Houdini. So i had to let it go.I started to play Disharmony. It was all good. but at the 40 hour timer buggs started to show up. 2 bugs to be specific. I dont know what they are. A window shows up and describes the problem in some programing language. 1 Bug stopped showing after a while. Dont know why. The second bug when it shows then freezes your game and you have to shut it down via Task manager. So I started to save my files more often but you also have autosaves.The next that dosnt work is private multiplayer with a friend. Let me explain.My friend has the Emperor Edition only (I have both). So we wanted to play a private multiplayer.When you start the game the window shows up again with 3 Emperor Editon keys and 1 Disharmony key. So I pushed the clasic Emperor Edition key so the games are compatible. But heck knows why it always starts Disharmony instead of Emperor Edition. And after the game loaded a window pops up and says that I have to launch the clasic verision of the game so I can play with my friend. No♥♥♥♥♥♥Sherlock. We tried so many times but it just would not work.Ok. So we gave upon that too.Now I am at about 65 hours of gameplay (as Steam shows me here)I wanted to continue playing.I go to the LOAD section, pick my saved game and start it. And know it freezes at the loading. After about 20 seconds the loading freezes and I have to close it via Task manager again. I tried the autosaves. All of them. Same♥♥♥♥♥♥ It freezes the whole game.So I played 1 map for 65 hours and now I cant play it.How can a game get buggier after more gameplay time?Other features. It says that you can put the fighters/bombers or your main battle ships in formarions. I didnt even find where to do that. I searched for some options at the Battle window when you start a fight. I searched all the HUD in the manual fight. I found nothing. I dont know if Im just so lame and cant find it even when its somewhere visible or it just isnt in the game. content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												After spending many hours with this title, the best I can say is that is about one third complete. The mechanics are so rigid as to prevent any real play variance. For example, you are compelled into a strict regimen of  play - as any variance either too far ahead or behind results in being attacked. There is no real diplomatic and trade based approach. IN the same way, if you want to pursue a science theme, forget it - as the game is designed to "reward" following a path that essentially linear across the whole possible range of improvements. The time to discover items becomes so distorted if you try to follow a "theme", with turn times blowing out from 2-5 as an average to 30 plus if you try to go a specific route.The planet developments consist of just letting it be automated - trying to decipher half the meanings of some improvements is both frustrating and pointless - there is no visual or other queues to show what you need to stop youe empire constantly going into near revolt, with half of your systems "on strike" - even at the easiest settings. As an example, at the lowest setting, playing the Empire, every system has to be set at "approval enhancements" for it to work at all.This may sound harsh, but this was NOT a $10 game - and having played MOO II 10 tens ago, which absolutely blows this away, I expected far more than I got.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												I played this game since it appeared as early alpha access up until sometime after full release, but before Disharmony.  I can tell you without a shred of doubt that it had great potential in alpha.  I was rather blown away by the amount of polish and content already in the game, as well as the ease of the interface.Endless Space is a fantastic single player game, if it was only that, I would have been clamoring for multiplayer but satisfied to play alone vs AI (although AI was never brilliant).  As far as space 4x goes, the exploration and expansion aspect was very nice. The combat tries mix being quick with some player choices so its not purely predetermined who would win. I found I could win a military victory extremely fast and easily. As a normally aggressive player, I liked this. And here comes why I hate this game...It is because after this game, I hate amplitude studios. Bugs. Extremely buggy alpha. Buggy multiplayer, buggy beta, buggy release, buggy dlc. I remember at one point they announced that they had hired more programmers or some such to fix the various bugs of the game. They did fix some things, semi-quickly.  Going back to why I played aggressively, it was because a multiplayer game reliably crashed around turn 30. I could kill someone by turn 22. So this was the only way I could finish a game. In this I found enjoyment, but it does not by any means make it a good product. After they fixed some bugs, turn 40 became the new life expectancy.  Also, in addition to that, multiplayer games had a host, and the game was reliant on the host. So if you kill the host, or he quits, every one gets booted to the title screen. Someone has to load the autosave, and get everyone to rejoin, which hardly happened. Most of the time the save file was corrupted anyways.Let's insert a small note about amplitudes voting process for their games.  You get forum points of some sort for various reasons, and that is your voting power. They will give you choices of what to vote on to implement next in the game, and you vote. The problem here is the majority of players just play single player or co-op, so they aren't usually looking to balance the game for multiplayer, they just want aesthetic things. Fix the games bugs was never a vote option, mind you. Keep in mind, all these things will be added at some point, you are just voting on the priority project. It's all well and fine, but trivial.So lets fast forward to Disharmony DLC. A guy on my steam friend list still played the game and would periodically invite his entire list, i presumed. I said oh, Disharmony is out and a lot changed, ok, maybe its all better now. So i picked it up. NOPE, still buggy for multiplayer.  Expect to crash sometime after turn 60.  Additionally, they slowed the pace of the game, by nerfing nearly everything.  I was immediately reminded why I hate them, which was amplified by the fact that it had been HOW LONG???? since the game was in alpha and the same game crashing bugs still existed. This was made worse since even though now the game won't crash as early, the pace of the game was slowed so much that it didn't matter.So any "Endless" Title I expect the same garbage to happen. I wanted so bad to give this game around a 8/10 initially, but the studio seemed to not really care much about polishing it, that I really give it a 4/10.  I was recommending it in alpha, I was telling people to never get it ever after release. That is backwards, in case you were wondering.

												This is that rare turn-based strategy space game that gets enough right in terms of design and execution that, even though it is not perfect, you keep coming back for more.  I think that Steam achievements really encourage one to try all the different races - and that is a very good thing as you actually have to change play style to get the most out of each race.  The downside is that some of the achievements are hard to unlock due to requiring luck and/or having opaque requirments.  There are also bugs that may lurk in the endgame in some playthroughs.  However, the positives outweigh the negatives, and the devs have done a decent job of supporting the game (improvements and squashing bugs).  I expect to play this game for years, and I can't say that about many games.  Thus, I recommend Endless Space.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Endless Space is a game of management, strategy & patience.If you find creating & updating templates for your ships, forming fleets, updating planetary build orders,  selecting what to research, upgrading hero abilities etc. boring and tedious... then this game is  not  for you. Otherwise, if you like strategy, you should enjoy it, and (on the higher difficulty levels) find it challenging.As far as space strategy 4X games are concerned, this is one of the better ones. It's graphics and (once you learn it) relatively simple rules, lift it in my opinion above most of it's competition. For this reason I give it my recommendation. There are some things about it that can be difficult for the newcomer: The tech-tree is a perfect example:It's four branches would seem to indicate that you can concentrate research on the branch that interests you the most. This is an illusion. If you want to build a strong empire you'll need to concentrate on  all  branches uniformly. Once your have played for a while (and are more familiar with the research techs), you will discover the ways that certain techs (in different branches) relate with each other.    Pirates are another example:Since victory in the game is all about expanding your empire (as quickly as possible), and colonising systems (before they are colonised by other factions), the appearance of pirates can inhibit this (at the most critical time). Prevention is better than cure. Random events aside, pirate fleets will only spawn in systems not under any factions influence (or surveillance). Station scout ships (if possible) in systems to prevent their spawning and / or station strong fleets at strategic systems to prevent their entry into your space.The use of heroes is another example:Heroes can have a very significant effect on your success in the game, especially in fleet combat. Although all heroes will gain experience over time, speed this up as much as you can. A good way to do this is by assigning them to fleets based at systems on the borders of your space. Use them to fight pirates, enemy faction ships etc. In this respect (if your fleet is strong enough) pirates and cold war can be a good thing.Keep a close eye on what the other factions are doing (if you can). It is easy to lose a game because another faction has reached a victory condition before your faction has.Although, far from perfect, there is much that can be enjoyed from this game.Enjoy!!Algenon

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												I wanted to like Endless Space so badly. I love 4x space games, and like a lot of us am still waiting for the successor to Master of Orion 2 to come along. I'd been hoping ES would finally succeed where so many others had failed. In fact, I periodically download and play it again hoping that maybe I was wrong and there's a good game buried in there somewhere.There's not.As many people have written the biggest problem is combat. There's nothing interesting about it. There are three types of weapons and three types of defenses. Each gets linearly more powerful as you tech up, and each defense stops one type of weapon and is useless against the other two. If you have the right defense against an enemy ship you win. If you don't, they win. There's a system where you play three cards to influence the battle, but it moves too slowly and has too little impact to make any difference.There's no diversity of units like in Civilization nor tactical combat like in Master of Orion (or the brilliant Total War series). There's just a big game of rock, paper, scissors. One side wins, the other side loses, you rebuild and repeat. Don't bother with any other type of victory either. There's no room for cleverness in a rocks/paper/scissors system and no stationary defenses, so if you don't put everything into your military the player who did will crush you every time.It's the same with domestic policy. Your systems have to specialize, so you pick whether a system will produce money, tech or industry, plug in all the appropriate buildings and then auto build cash, science or ships. You don't really decide which to do, because each planet is good for one particular thing so the system composition pretty much decides this for you. There's nothing interesting happening in the galaxy or territory uniquely worth fighting over, no external threat or game changing discoveries. Even the little tactical interest that comes from star lanes and wormholes is gone shortly into the game once ships can fly through open space.By the mid-game your empire is pretty much running on autopilot. Cash and science systems tick away and your only interaction is to build fleets and throw them at the enemy. Periodically you upgrade the design of your ships for new science or if the enemy switches to a different weapon.Most of the problem came from the developers' focus on making a multiplayer game. They stripped the mechanics down in order to keep them balanced, and that ultimately made the game *much* less interesting. The wonders, for example, confer system bonuses instead of being big, powerful icons that can change the course of play. System bonuses aren't interesting. I can catch up to that with a few extra factories and don't even need to if they show up on a lousy planet. But the multiplayer would be unbalanced if one person could, by random chance, stumble across a game changer. It's the same with everything else. There are no weird discoveries to make in the galaxy or overpowered planets, like MOO2's gaians, because that would advantage one player too much. Military tech marches up rails up three branches and that's it, no clever or assymetrical weapons or decisions to make for fear of breaking things. Even the races are just a collection of relatively minor statistical differences from each other, nothiing that feels truly different or unique.There are a lot of little things wrong with Endless Space and a couple of big ones, but ultimately the game just isn't that much fun. It feels flat and lifeless. One play through is pretty much exactly like every other and by midway through your second game you'll get bored.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2012
												Eines der eindruckvollsten rundenbasierten 4X-Strategie-Spiele der letzten Jahre. Es tritt in die Fußstapfen von Spielen wie MOO oder Stars!, welche dem eingefleischten 4X Spieler bekannt sein werden. Die Bedienung ist absolut intuitiv und schon nach wenigen Minuten kommt man sehr gut mit dem Spiel zurecht. Die Übersetzung ist gut und zeigt einen Detailreichtum an Informationen. Die bekannten drei Säulen (Forschung, Planetenentwicklung, Schiffbau) bieten einfache Bedienung, locken aber auch damit sich weiter damit zu beschäftigen. Gerade der Kampf, der in Hinsicht auf Multiplayer-Runden einfach gestaltet wurde, bietet in Form von verschiedenen Schiffskonstruktionen für verschiedene Einsatzzwecke (Lang-, Mittel- oder Kurzstreckenbewaffnung) eine sehr hohe Spieltiefe an. Insgesamt auf dem Sektor Rundenstrategie ein empfehlenswertes Spiel, das durch seine konsequente Ausrichtung auf Multiplayer durchaus den Vergleich mit Titeln wie Civilization nicht zu scheuen braucht. Das indipendent Entwicklerstudio ist zudem sehr darauf bedacht die Ideen und Empfehlungen der Spieler für kostenlose Erweiterungen des Spiels aufzunehmen und auch um zu setzen. Das hat man so mit den großen Studios schon lange nicht mehr gesehen. Einfach Klasse!---One of the most impressive turn-based 4X-strategy-games of the last years. It steps in the footprints of games like MOO or stars! which become known to confirmed 4 X players. The service is absolutely intuitive and already after few minutes one manages very well with the play. The translation is good and shows a detailed wealth of information. The known three columns (research, planet development, shipbuilding) offer an easy service, however, curl also with it further with it to occupy. Just the fight which was simply formed in regard to multi player rounds offers in the form of different ship constructions for different purposes (long, medium or short distance arming) a very high play depth. All together on the sector round strategy a recommendable play which absolutely does not need to avoid the comparison with titles like Civilization by his logical adjustment on multiplayer. Besides, the indipendent developer studio is very much on it the ideas roof and to take up recommendations of the players for free enlargements of the play and also to place. One has not seen this thus with the big studios for a long time any more. Simply class!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2013
												This game has something of a steep learning curve and few resources to help you out, but there is a tremendous payoff if you stick with it.I am a big fan of the Civilization series, and so there is something of a high bar set for all games that even touch on its features. Endless Space does a good job of keeping the core elements that make the genre fun, while bringing its own touch that kept me through the frustrations of initially learning the game.Some of these frustrations are things like difficulty making sense of the technology tree (or sorting through it in a sensible and profitable way), and not quite realizing the importance of updating ship designs and fleet construction. I suspect people will find their own points where they stumble, and while the game always will reward understanding with an entertaining game, it definately took me longer to warm to this game than I normally give.These relatively minor complaints aside, I have found this game a lot of fun to play and fresh enough to reward multiple replays and strategies. A major feature that stands out is combat system for fleets which adds this nice cinematic feel (a bit like Battlestar Galactica scenes) while adding a mechanic that is simple to use, but quite complex to master in terms of determining a best reply (moreso against human players). The game also has a gorgeous soundtrack that will accompany you as you find yourself going deeper and deeper into the night.This recommendation can only apply to fans of turn based strategy games with a 4X feel. There are simpler introductions to the genre, and it's hard to see what's inside that would appeal to people who don't like 'that type' of game. But if you do like this sort of strategy and have not yet tried Endless Space, you'd be hard pressed to find a better alternative.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I've been learning this 4x game by exploration, which is oddly appropriate considering exploration is a good part of the game.  It has been living in a window on my other monitor, which is one of those pleasant advantages of a turn based game, so I haven't really played as many hours as it will say I have -- but it's been a constant companion for days.  I work on things on the "tomato" rule -- do something, take a break -- and this has been my "take a break."  The devs have managed to infused a good feeling of RPG into the factions and context of the game.  It's polished like an apple, the art style is gorgeous, the music is...well, it reminded me of Eve and I turned it off after a bit.  But the skill trees are deep and interesting, the strategy is pleasantly no-one-solution, the achievements are -- many of them -- gigglesome and some might really appeal to the obsessive.Much more elegant than Sid Meier's stuff.  It appeals to the anthropologist (xenologist?), engineer, and storyteller in me as well as the game geek/dev/closet space grognard.I find myself interested in trying to win the game as different factions having played against random different factions as AI in 2 player games.  I find myself doing dishes and modelling how larger games with more factions would work out, after a few days of playing.  What better recommendation for a game than that it amuses me away from the keyboard, as well as at the keyboard?

												WOW!  If you like Civilization II/III/IV/V, then this is a MUST!  Not a re-hashed version of itself, with better graphics.  Endless Space, is what I believe the Civ Community has been SOOO longing for! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												A Sci-Fi Civilization V with an extremely pronounced difficulty curve and an overwhelming technology tree. It would be one of my favourite games, if it was just a bit better balanced. There are so many stats and sub-systems in place, that the AI easily gets out of control, and reacting to that requires hundreds of turns (hours). It's easy to find out that the more efficient, optimal, way to win a match, is to complete one of those endless tech tree branches and get a "tech/political" victory. When  you win this way twice, after endless, frustrated, attempts to follow other strategies, you just lose your interest for the game. Still, it was fun and joyful to play. I felt like I could rule the Galaxy; but sadly not the way I would like to. If properly balanced, it would hold a very high position in my game library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												I like this game, it's pretty good. It has pretty great civ customization options, a pretty good galaxy customization scheme, and a neat approach to in-universe tech explanations. The devs are pretty good with long-term upkeep, and have released regular updates so far.However, it is a bit awfully easy to win using economic, science, and wonder victories. As in, extremely easy unless you're playing on the top-tier difficulties. The combat isn't particularly deep and doesn't really get any better, and the hero system is pretty useless sometimes.Disharmony adds a neat dimension to the game by removing a quarter of the economic system as a challenge, but you'll only end up playing as the Harmony once you're comfortable with the game. Since they're packing a lot of new features in updates for Disharmony, I'd say it's probably worth it.All in all, Endless Space + Disharmony is a good purchase at prices below $20. I got the entire package at $12 during a sale, so I'm happy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												This is that rare turn-based strategy space game that gets enough right in terms of design and execution that, even though it is not perfect, you keep coming back for more.  I think that Steam achievements really encourage one to try all the different races - and that is a very good thing as you actually have to change play style to get the most out of each race.  The downside is that some of the achievements are hard to unlock due to requiring luck and/or having opaque requirments.  There are also bugs that may lurk in the endgame in some playthroughs.  However, the positives outweigh the negatives, and the devs have done a decent job of supporting the game (improvements and squashing bugs).  I expect to play this game for years, and I can't say that about many games.  Thus, I recommend Endless Space.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Endless Space is a game of management, strategy & patience.If you find creating & updating templates for your ships, forming fleets, updating planetary build orders,  selecting what to research, upgrading hero abilities etc. boring and tedious... then this game is  not  for you. Otherwise, if you like strategy, you should enjoy it, and (on the higher difficulty levels) find it challenging.As far as space strategy 4X games are concerned, this is one of the better ones. It's graphics and (once you learn it) relatively simple rules, lift it in my opinion above most of it's competition. For this reason I give it my recommendation. There are some things about it that can be difficult for the newcomer: The tech-tree is a perfect example:It's four branches would seem to indicate that you can concentrate research on the branch that interests you the most. This is an illusion. If you want to build a strong empire you'll need to concentrate on  all  branches uniformly. Once your have played for a while (and are more familiar with the research techs), you will discover the ways that certain techs (in different branches) relate with each other.    Pirates are another example:Since victory in the game is all about expanding your empire (as quickly as possible), and colonising systems (before they are colonised by other factions), the appearance of pirates can inhibit this (at the most critical time). Prevention is better than cure. Random events aside, pirate fleets will only spawn in systems not under any factions influence (or surveillance). Station scout ships (if possible) in systems to prevent their spawning and / or station strong fleets at strategic systems to prevent their entry into your space.The use of heroes is another example:Heroes can have a very significant effect on your success in the game, especially in fleet combat. Although all heroes will gain experience over time, speed this up as much as you can. A good way to do this is by assigning them to fleets based at systems on the borders of your space. Use them to fight pirates, enemy faction ships etc. In this respect (if your fleet is strong enough) pirates and cold war can be a good thing.Keep a close eye on what the other factions are doing (if you can). It is easy to lose a game because another faction has reached a victory condition before your faction has.Although, far from perfect, there is much that can be enjoyed from this game.Enjoy!!Algenon

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Do you like Civilization?  Do you like Space?  How bout Sci Fi?  If you answered yes then this game is for you!  A 4X game, basically its Civ in space.  You choose an alien race/faction (or create your own!) and then setup your game, dictating things like number of opponents, difficulty, and even style of the galaxy (a spiral?  a ring?  a big ellipse?)Once you start play there is an awesome and super detailed tutorial that guides you through each screen and explains how the game functions.  You colonize star systems and then specific planets, and build a combination of planet specific and system specific upgrades.  You also build fleets of ships (from designs you create!) to do battle against space pirates and the other factions.  With multiple ways to win and everything being generated on the fly, this game is just pure awesome for strategy lovers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												This is a well crafted game and is worth getting and playing through. The best way to describe this game is to say that its like Civilization in Space. The AI is good and on the harder difficulties will adapt to what you are doing and hand your♥♥♥♥♥to you. Basically you have to colonise planets in star systems, research new technologies and deal with opponents. combat is worked out on a dice role basis but you design your ships weapons and shields which means on the harder difficulties you have to tailor your fleets to the fleets that you are going to be fighting against.... seriously the AI in this game is like the borg..... they adapt (at least on the harder difficulties). My only gripe with this game is that on the easier difficulties the end game can get boring as you have dominated the galaxy and are just waiting to get to a victory condition. On the harder difficulties it can be frustratingly difficult to get a decent start.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2012
												I was addicted to this game for a good long time.It's not exactly the most balanced or technically stable game I've played, but it's one of the most enjoyable 4X games I've ever experienced.It features a UI that's been polished to a mirror shine, distinct races with genuinely unique and interesting themes and mechanics, and very engaging gameplay on the empire management level.The combat is a little awkward and confusing, but servicable and it doesn't mess with the overall game. Ship building is solid and fun, and the AI is able to provide a genuine challenge.On top of all that the dev team is very loyal to this game, and has been constantly releasing new updates with valuable technical fixes and design iterations that keep making the game better and better.A great time if you like games like Civ. It'll be your 4X fix for a good long time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Excellent 4X game. There are 12 default races and each of the races plays in a very unique way, yet the game keeps an asymmetric balance. Players are able to create custom races. Each phase of the game is different forcing you to change the way you play. Overall, war has a strategic facet that Civilization: Beyond Earth lacks. Downsides: The pirates are annoying and overpowered (You can turn them off). It is nearly impossible to achieve a diplomatic victory, making winning through diplomacy not an option. The combat system is too simplistic. Generally, whoever has stronger ships wins. The strategy aspect is reduced to a rock-paper-scissors style of choosing one of a limited number of tactics. It would be nearly perfect if it included a full RTS aspect like in Star Wars: Empire at War.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												At first the game is really romancing. Getting started and exploring vs risk and reward is something that is motivating. After you reach a certain level of fullness in the galaxy, which comes fairly fast on the largest maps, it becomes a game vs terrible A.I.. A.I. which is bent on its own destruction by sending weak fleets against your strategic positions until it builds up a strong enough one. Trade with tech is worthless, no one ever is willing to do a fair trade even when you are considered very close in relationship, an ally, etc. The trading screen is worthless outside of pounding down another civilization enough to offer peace with reassignment of their closest star systems. Other trade happens without effort. The battle system is unique and I found merit in it, but was disappointed by the repetitive nature of it. I could also exploit engineering cards to lose nothing and keep a steady rotation of heros and fleets repaired. I liked the update system for retrofitting my fleets. The ending... Well anti-climatic. YAY I GOT A REWARD CARD!!!! Felt like Master of Orion, but something is missing. There needs to be more mystery, more random events which involve the player late game. More hero dynamics and or relationship or options or what ever. I got the game on a deep sale.. If you like the idea of risk with your friends and have the ability to play this with several it would be a great game for that. But one player it doesn't have much pull for me to play it again. However I still think its a decent game, just not great. It seems to suffer from the late game boring side like the CIV series which I ADORE does.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Before I review this I believe a bit of my background as a gamer is needed. Among the first games I started playing were the Command & Conquer games (they were SO good, until Zero Hour.. Then it went downhill), so I have experience with fast paced RTS's. I also have sunk many hours into Alpha Centauri, which is more of a 4X/Civ building game. I have played games such as Rise of Nations, Empire Earth, Age of Empires, and many other Strategy games. Now I feel like I know a good Strategy game when I see one, and let me tell you this one of those good ones. Endless Space is a great game for those of you that are 4X/CIv Building fans (not so much for the faster paced RTS fans though you may still enjoy it with the game speed cranked up). If you liked Alpha Centauri, and games like it, you will likely love this game (it is not as in-depth compared to Alpha Centauri too). So far I have sunk 40+ hours into the game (playing on normal speed, so that's only been 1 completed game and 2 that I have yet to complete). I have only played as 3 races thus far. The Sowers have been my favorite of the ones I have played as, they seem the most balanced and have a great late game ship class. The other races I played as, the Siphons and Sherydn (not sure on the spelling of those two), didn't seem as well balanced but are still very playable. Graphically and soundtrack wise the game is great too. I have had a few minor bugs (ship health being displayed incorrectly and one of my fleets derping out) but they were not too bad. As I said, just minor bugs.      Overall, it seems like a well put together game. If you're a fan of Alpha Centauri or games like it, get this for sure. I got the game on a Steam Sale, but I would have payed full price for it. It is well worth 30 dollars. Sorry, about the long review. Again, my main point is if you are a strategy fan and want a good space/sci-fi game then get this!

The Sowers have been my favorite of the ones I have played as, they seem the most balanced and have a great late game ship class. The other races I played as, the Siphons and Sherydn (not sure on the spelling of those two), didn't seem as well balanced but are still very playable. Graphically and soundtrack wise the game is great too. I have had a few minor bugs (ship health being displayed incorrectly and one of my fleets derping out) but they were not too bad. As I said, just minor bugs.      Overall, it seems like a well put together game. If you're a fan of Alpha Centauri or games like it, get this for sure. I got the game on a Steam Sale, but I would have payed full price for it. It is well worth 30 dollars. Sorry, about the long review. Again, my main point is if you are a strategy fan and want a good space/sci-fi game then get this!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Endless Space is endless fun! A game with both windows and osx support, Endless space is your standard galactic empire building "turn based" strategy game. It is pretty in presentation and relatively straightforward to get into, although it falls short in content. It offers a large variety of faction customization options and play styles although the game simply boils down to galactic conquest. The story and single player experience is virtually non-existent, and as such it is a game probably better played online. It is a moderately active community at the time of writing this, however it should be noted that games take several hours to complete and often players leaving or the game crashing can be a frustrating experience. Returning to the gameplay it is about planetary colonization, expansion, resource management and of course combat. The former is all quite self explanatory and is a little difficult to optimize without spending a couple hours of trial and error, the latter being the combat takes place in ship engagements in which your ships fight and you give orders in a series of phases, ultimately it is the orders that matter and the combat is essentially just a cutscene displaying the results of your combat selections. Overall a decent game, it is definitely a very niche game so unless you are familiar to this style of galactic conquest games it or are interested in seeing what they are all about, it is not for you. If that is your thing however Endless Space is a decent entry in the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Although I can understand why many people may have a different opinion to me, I believe this is easily one of my favourite games ever. The universe you are thrown into seems rich and developed yet not linear as every game of Endless Space seems to throw something new at you. The artwork and sound design is some of the best I have ever seen in a game and I personally find the UI beautiful and easy to navigate throughout however some may disagree with me here. The complexity of the game mechanics seems to find the perfect divide between being to simple and overly complicated allowing for an experience which is enjoyable to both new and veteran players. The only two downsides I see to this game are the combat system and part of the AI behaviour. Although the combat system has a few cool features such as the ability to select fleet formations, admirals, ship targeting behaviour and others, these features are built around a card based battle system which feels a bit like an underwhelming complecated version of scissors paper rock. The AI although I personally found to be one of the better AIs of 4X strategy games, seems to play an extremely aggressive expansion strategy in the early game every single time. Although this makes the early game fairly predictable, it also keeps the player on edge and competitive with the AI. Overall, I would highly reccomend this game if you enjoy 4X startegy games similar to Sid Meier's Civilization V and I really hope Endless Space 2 lives up to the great name this iteration of the Endless Space series has created. ( Really sorry for the lack of paragraphing and I hope this helps )

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Endless Space is easily the best space 4x I've ever played.  The diversity between factions is broad enough to allow for interesting replays without being so different as to be unbalanced.  Planet management is on the complex-but-reasonable side.  Ship design and development is fantastic and detailed, yet not micromanagerial.The integration of the components of the rest of The Endless series gives this a compelling universe as a backdrop, and you can easily imagine how an escape pod from one of your fleet became the explorers in Dungeon of the Endless or how one of the uncolonized planets you uncover could be the one you're developing in Endless Legend.Highly recommended as long as you don't mind spending hours playing "one more turn."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is one of the few 4x games I own. When I bought it, I was primarily looking for an entertaining space-themed game with cool battles, which is exactly what I got. It is worth mentioning, that I don't play this game on the higher difficulties which means that this review might not reflect the experience of those who do play on higher difficulties. I do believe that the game can become a bit boring in the mid- to lategame unless the focus lies on military expansion. The boredom will, however, be mitigated by learning technologies that allows for further colonization of different planet types. Furthermore, wars can, in my experience, become tedious since they easily become very focused on production and the mangement of damaged ships. On a final note, I want to mention a couple of positives. Besides from the beautiful combat cinematics, there are two things that I particularly enjoy about the game. Firstly, it is the advisors. These people, of all species, will aid the empire they are working for with their special skills and they can be specialized according to the players prefference. Secondly, I found the different species and the customization to be a fun factor. Mostly because it feels like the species are played differently from each other, and that they often have noticeable boons, and in some cases even drawbacks. I like the ability to create a new species, but the customization options are somewhat limited and it often feels like it is restricted to what already exists.In the end, I'd probably recommend this game, especially if it is on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												This game... lets just say before the review starts, I recommend this game. It is worth the money.Okay, the first time I played I played this game, was around the first time I started using steam. It was one of those free for the weekend deals. I tried it out. Its more than just the gameplay. Basically, one of the themes of this game (I personally feel) would have to be space. The music adds to that theme, the descriptive writing adds to it, the whole game gives off this awe inspiring mood to it. Not just it being epic, or cool, or relaxing. Whenever I play this, no matter how many times, I always feel like there is so much more to try to get at. You are put on a random system in a randomly generated map type of your choosing. The other factions are also placed randomly. I can honestly say I have never gone through a game the same way twice. The ships are fully customizable except for their appearance.When you play this game, it should come across your mind on how big the map is. You're not just in a solar system, you're in a galaxy. Your fleets are traveling to other systems, almost impossibly far away to imagine. The developers somewhat increased the size of the systems just so we can see these points. In reality, we wouldn't see anything from how far away the view is.This game is awe-inspiring, fun, and overall a great game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Pro:+ stable, simply works. It's actually sad that you have to point out something this basic+ a rather intuitive interface+ multiple ways to win the game, customizeable+ a simple, yet powerful race editor which is perk based + every race has small unique "milestones", for example the shipclass specs differ for each race+ community enchanced, people who like the genre have and still can give feedback which is used by the developers to increase the game experience+ good range of diplomacy options+ AI is well developed. Most races might invade if you present them with a too sweet target (no defences) and ignore the diplomacy, every (AI) race has different aproaches to win the game which is not just some random declaration of war.Con- a selected few descriptions still need to be improved to make more sense. For beginners it might not be clear for example that a kinetic weapon is most effective on close range if the description doesn't change between long, medium and close range. Veterans will take a look one on the values provided and will know what to use ( and might not even notice the desription at all). Beginners might also stumble upon the meaning of influence and some other minor things, but nothing mayor, Personal impressions The combat system needs to get used to. Think of it as a 3 phase combat (long, medium, close range) where you can give one general command per phase. Pre battle you can decide formation (which ships will be at the frontline?) and if you prefer to attack all ships, or focus fire on the first three or even on one ship a time. I really would like to see a little more options here, and further more race unique gizmos. At the moment every race can research every tech, save for the very few race specific techs. With a bigger tech tree, maybe even increasing the 4 general directions with a unique per chance tech tree, that would be real nice. Since MoO 2 this is the only game in the 4X turn based genre which is motivating me to continue for months and months to come.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I really want to recommend this because I love like 90% of it; but it's absolutely ruined by the combat system. The combat system is awkward at best, and obtuse at worse. There is also something off with the AI (I'm playing the latest version as of 1/2/2016). The AI is extremely aggressive, even at lower difficultly levels. It is just too aggressive and the worst part about this is I can't learn the obtuse combat system because of it.Endless Legend is much better; just get that and play it. I respect this effort and look forward to Endless Space 2 but this either needs patches or it’s just not worth buying. Should I notice a patch or update, I’ll try the game again and update this review as appropriate. But for now, no, I can’t recommend it and should you be inclined to buy it, get it on sale at least. I think you’ll get a few hours out of it but conclude something similar on the combat & AI. Again, love 90% of the game but those two things just make this not worth the time to play.==============Update: After some effort to learn the combat system (and I still felt it could be better), I've actually played through the game twice. Won once w/ a Science victory. Granted, lower level of difficulty but still. I appreciate this game for what it is. I still feel that EL is a better game over all but this is worth picking up if you like EL/4x. I like it better, for example, than GalCiv3.

Should I notice a patch or update, I’ll try the game again and update this review as appropriate. But for now, no, I can’t recommend it and should you be inclined to buy it, get it on sale at least. I think you’ll get a few hours out of it but conclude something similar on the combat & AI. Again, love 90% of the game but those two things just make this not worth the time to play.==============Update: After some effort to learn the combat system (and I still felt it could be better), I've actually played through the game twice. Won once w/ a Science victory. Granted, lower level of difficulty but still. I appreciate this game for what it is. I still feel that EL is a better game over all but this is worth picking up if you like EL/4x. I like it better, for example, than GalCiv3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												As someone who remembers playing the original Master of Orion back in the early 90s, this game has come the closest to capturing the enjoyment of the original MoO and MoO2 experience of my youth.It is not a perfect game, some people may not enjoy the more "cinematic" battles as opposed to controlling the fleets themselves.  Afterall, that's what made Homeworld such a fantastic game, was the minute RTS control of the entire fleet including the economy.However, I found that the pace of this game, and greater focus on Empire building and Macro development to more than make up for the battle instances.  And while it took me awhile to appreciate how the "cinematic turn based" fighting occurred, I became a big fan of sort of "issuing a strategy" and then watching as missiles, lasers, fighters and bombers did their work on the opposing fleet.While not quite as deep in ship design, as say, Galactic Civilizations, the interface is at least intuitive without needing to try to figure out "where to stuff something."  This ship design has X amount of things it can fit - and you fit what you want.Most importantly - the ability to retrofit your units to more modern designs as technology becomes available is simple, and keeps the game moving smoothly, since you usually have a bunch of other things to take care of each turn.In short, this is perhaps my favorite space-based 4x game I've played in the last decade.  And I really enjoyed the usual (Sword of the Stars and the like) ones, but for me this game has stood out.  It is not as complex as many of the games in the genre, but in my opinion really captured the spirit that I have not happened since I was a 10 year old sneaking onto the computer late at night to play Master of Orion until it was time for school in the morning.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A fun and addicting 4x space game with a relatively steep learning curve. Once you do get the hang of it, its a surprisingly chill game to play, mostly because of the great OST and ambiance. It has everything you would expect in a 4x game, except a stealth/spy system unfortunately. Combat looks spectacular, very pretty. It is semi automated, although you can still make decisions between "rounds" that affect your fleet's(maximize shields, focus fire a ship, counter a weapon type etc.) performance. Lots of options for what to do with systems and planets you own, from terraforming to population control. AI/relations with other factions is pretty straightforward, perhaps a little more competent than Civ5, as least in regards to how alliances work. Ive never had an ally backstab me or drop relations for no reason, which is nice. The UI is simple and polished imo, if you've played any other AMPLITUDE Studio's game, then you'll recognize most controls since its very similar to their other games. Overall a solid 8/10 game that you can easily dump many hours into.
