number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												I was incredibly surprised by this game. I had received it as a gift awhile back and from looking at gameplay videos on YouTube, I decided at the time it wasn't for me. I was dead wrong. This is my first 4X game (explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate) and have passed on other popular games like the Civilization series thinking that they would not be to my liking. Where should I start?Graphically speaking, the game looks and performs very well. Are they top of the line, burn your motherboard-type graphics? No, but for what this game offers, I have been very pleased. As you can see from the pictures provided on this page, you'll spend most of your time looking at either the beautiful galaxy map or the various tabs located at the top left of your galaxy screen. Aside from staring at the galaxy map when zoomed out (which I particularly enjoy), the most eye candy you'll see in-game is of course the "manual" fleet battles that I'm sure you'll encounter during play. I have my graphics set to the maximum settings and the frame rate runs easily above 100 per second. "Manual" fleet battles give you a visual representation of the battles as well as an opportunity to change your strategy as it progresses.The tabs at the top of your screen consist of various actions you may queue up and/or perform on any turn. They range from your overall progression score compared to the other factions in the game to a comprehensive system list to manage your assets, research tree, fleet shipyard, diplomacy and finally your hero cards. These different tabs also range from useful to rather unnecessary. Later in the game (usually after 70 turns) I found myself using this tab the most so I could manage all of my systems happiness, tax rate, system improvements and resources and trade routes. The research tree is absolutely necessary to do anything in the game, but what I found out to be more important was to skip reading guides online and simply just sit down for an hour and read through all of the different tiles. The fleet shipyard isn't required much as you simply just research new ship types in one of the four available tech trees in the research tab along with your various weapons, defenses and support modules in other trees and just make your own designs to build. The hero tab is rather ho-hum as quite simply you look to hire hero cards to place on a system or in a fleet. Managing your ability points as your level them up can be done elsewhere.Diplomacy on the other hand is somewhat frustrating. Split between a sort of good and evil with some rather in between, 10 factions in the base game offer a wide variety of gameplay. There are tiles that you upgrade diplomacy through your research tab to give you various bonuses, however what it won't take into account is that each faction responds differently to diplomacy. Some won't engage in it and are completely hostile, others are hermits and avoid you almost altogether and others hate your guts if you're beating them economically like I have and take forever to form alliances and cooperative trade agreements. I don't quite like how it was designed and wished there was a little bit better way to draw up diplomatic relations more quickly and efficiently. If you're all for blowing them up and conquering systems, then diplomacy won't even be an afterthought for you. Personally, diplomacy has been much to what I described. They tend to either be violent due to the inherited nature or they hold a grudge against you for being better than you for a good two-thirds of the game and then suddenly they become bootlickers and ask for the most ridiculous trades imaginable. Example: I was playing as a peaceful Amoeba faction, exploring and expanding to three arms of an eight arm spiral galaxy with 5 other factions. One hated everyone and was suspicious of anyone (Cravers), one was constantly making threats and talking about glory and me being beneath them even though I was the master race for the whole game in terms of knowledge, diplomatic, expansive and economic power (Hissho); and the others kept to themselves and refused to talk to me until they decided I wasn't going anywhere (Pilgrams, Amoeba and another Hissho). The first Hissho decided an alliance would be good, but thought I was worthless and demanded I pay them a bunch of fuel resources to make the deal. After that I invited the pilgrams since they were 2nd to my capabilities and the Hissho eagerly agreed. Next the Amoeba decided that I'm peaceful enough that they may want to trade with me. At this point, for the rest of the game they kept asking for trade deals that are the worst imaginable. "How about I give you 2 marbles and I'll throw in a jacket with a torn sleeve for 5 units of rocket fuel? Promise not to shoot at you? Our people believe this to be for the glory of the Empire!" Blah Blah Blah.You get the idea.. These "allies" of mine are chumps and couldn't be trusted to fix a crack in the pavement let alone build an empire. Good luck getting good trades in of your own unless they love you to death for not shooting at them all game long. Lastly in regards to diplomacy, take care when you're in an alliance. If you declare war, your allies might not like this and then declare war on you, or in my case, I was in an alliance where one declared war on someone, bringing us into the fight when we didnt want it and I decided to stay whereas my other ally turned on me for staying. Let's just say that didn't end well and I learned my lesson. If you wish to side with other like-minded allies, just be careful when war breaks out.One other thing to keep in mind with the game is to read through each of the factions before you play. Very important as the traits allocated to each one is specific and will help cater to your particular playstyle. In other words, if you have a certain playstyle in mind, you might later on discover that other factions are better at accomplishing those goals. Once you get the handle on the game, take a look at designing your own faction. I haven't come close to mastering the game yet for me to go there, but I'm looking forward to it.Over all, as the 4X title suggests, you get to do a bit of everything and even if it doesn't seem like it will be fun, it is worth another look at the very least. I came from enjoying real-time strategy games like StarCraft, WarCraft, Red Alert and Company of Heroes to loving this game to death. I've only put 24 hours into this game and I've barely scratched the surface and will most definitely put many more hours into it. Even though the diplomacy aspect of the game is somewhat limiting, there is something there for someone who wants to build rather than destroy as well as the capability to just wreck havoc in a pretty decent space game. The faction biographies are fun to read as well as the little bits of information you glean from discoveries around the galaxy as you explore, expand, exploit and exterminate. Take the leap!

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Endless Space: There is ONLY WAR-- except when there isn’t - Hyper Abridged edition(I've played like nine hours of Endless Space despite Steam insisting I've only played five.)Like its terrestrial based cousin, Endless Space is a 4X game by Amplitude; with tons of character, great artwork, and a badass level of scale that really pulls everything together in a nice package.Also like almost every other 4X game I’ve played it’s obtuse and it makes me cry. Jokes aside, I do really like the 4X genre... But for some reason I seem to have poor luck with them. Even when I seemingly do everything right, something goes wrong. But, such is life- right? As a wise Space Captain once said,“It is possible to commit no mistakes and still lose. That is not a weakness; that is life.” I feel like that sums up my time so far with Endless Space. Except the mistakes part, I’m sure I made a lot of those. And while losing isn’t a bad thing, it’s certainly a bitter pill to swallow. Especially when you’re boxed into the eastern arm of a spiral galaxy and one hundred fifty galactic years of bitter and vicious war only let you expand your borders by one system, because the giant Space Amoebas swoop in and steal your hard fought systems out from under you with their super stupid advanced technology…...This review is WAY too long to post on steam, it literally won't let me! so if you like what you've read so far head on over to 100hoursave.com to read the rest! http://wp.me/p4gn9l-il more specifically.But I think it should go without saying, this game is dope as hell and you should buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A great game after the like of Galactic Civilizations, but with a bit narrower focus. It's a turn-based game of exploration, colonization, and occasionally combat that is not unlike Civilization in space. As you scout from your starting system you find additional solar systems connected by jump lanes, and you settle the planets in these systems and build upgrades on them to increase your resources and influence. Like GalCiv, the combat is a largely un-interactive rock-paper-scissors affair that has been expanded since the original release to allow a bit more flexibility. You customize your ships with a few categories of weapons, defenses, and other bonuses; ideally you create fleets that counter the technologies being fielded by your enemies. The progression is much like other turn-based strategy games, and victory can be achieved by expansion, conquest, or research. The pace of this game is generally slow, and it is well matched with an amazing soundtrack with ambient instrumental songs.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Endless Space: There is ONLY WAR-- except when there isn’t - Hyper Abridged edition(I've played like nine hours of Endless Space despite Steam insisting I've only played five.)Like its terrestrial based cousin, Endless Space is a 4X game by Amplitude; with tons of character, great artwork, and a badass level of scale that really pulls everything together in a nice package.Also like almost every other 4X game I’ve played it’s obtuse and it makes me cry. Jokes aside, I do really like the 4X genre... But for some reason I seem to have poor luck with them. Even when I seemingly do everything right, something goes wrong. But, such is life- right? As a wise Space Captain once said,“It is possible to commit no mistakes and still lose. That is not a weakness; that is life.” I feel like that sums up my time so far with Endless Space. Except the mistakes part, I’m sure I made a lot of those. And while losing isn’t a bad thing, it’s certainly a bitter pill to swallow. Especially when you’re boxed into the eastern arm of a spiral galaxy and one hundred fifty galactic years of bitter and vicious war only let you expand your borders by one system, because the giant Space Amoebas swoop in and steal your hard fought systems out from under you with their super stupid advanced technology…...This review is WAY too long to post on steam, it literally won't let me! so if you like what you've read so far head on over to 100hoursave.com to read the rest! http://wp.me/p4gn9l-il more specifically.But I think it should go without saying, this game is dope as hell and you should buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A great game after the like of Galactic Civilizations, but with a bit narrower focus. It's a turn-based game of exploration, colonization, and occasionally combat that is not unlike Civilization in space. As you scout from your starting system you find additional solar systems connected by jump lanes, and you settle the planets in these systems and build upgrades on them to increase your resources and influence. Like GalCiv, the combat is a largely un-interactive rock-paper-scissors affair that has been expanded since the original release to allow a bit more flexibility. You customize your ships with a few categories of weapons, defenses, and other bonuses; ideally you create fleets that counter the technologies being fielded by your enemies. The progression is much like other turn-based strategy games, and victory can be achieved by expansion, conquest, or research. The pace of this game is generally slow, and it is well matched with an amazing soundtrack with ambient instrumental songs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Endless Space is a turn-based 4x game. You are the emperor of a galactic empire. You start off small and slowly through warfare, trade, diplomacy and exploitation you grow into a huge empire spanning hundreds of stars. There are a variety of empires to choose from ranging from a hive of robotic insects who wish to devour the universe to your standard galactic human empire and a gelatinous mass of cells who are peaceful and only wish to socialize. Another excellent point are the resources. There are your basic 4 resources Food, industry, science and dust (FIDS). But there is a wealth of others to choose from. There are 2 main types of these: Strategic resources which can be used in shipbuilding and luxury resources, which confer permanent or temporary bonuses on your empire. The tech tree is a mixed bag. It's HUGE. Now this may be a good or a bad thing. There is loads to research, almost too much. With many of the coolest ones at the very end. Even very important ones are locked away. Want an alliance? Well, you have to research about 3 techs to lead up to that. Found a new resource? You're going to have to research it. Want bigger and better ships? You need to research that too! This brings us up to the next point, ships. Ships are fully customisable. With about 6 ship classes and a wealth of add-ons and modules the possibilities are endless. Unfortunately, using the ships is a different kettle of fish. When engaging in a conflict you must pick 3 "action cards, " these come in a variety of formats, but basically work like rock, paper, scissors. But when the engagement begins you get to watch it play out like a battle from Star Wars. Its cool for a while, but it soon gets old. Taking all these things into account I give this game a solid 7/10.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I'd never heard of this game before trying it out, but it turns out to be an excellent 4X TBS title.This pretty much runs down the checklist of what I want in a game.  Variable alien races? check.  Expansive tech tree? check.  Randomized galaxy to explore, with good variety in system & planet types? check.  Combat is simple, but lets you have enough control?  check.My only complaints are that some of the techs and upgrades seem way more useful than others, and one of the victory types feels a bit too easy to achieve compared to the others.  Also, the combat system can be a bit swingy, and the outcome of an engagement depends on factors that may not be obvious.  Lastly, combat and the other systems aren't explained all that well in-game, so you have to peruse the wiki to get a good idea of what's going on.Still, I've sunk many hours into it, and have no problem suggesting it to others.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												"Looks shiny, but the AI is terrible and there's a severe lack of balance everywhere from combat to the tech tree to the stock races themselves (nevermind custom races). You'll have fun for a few hours, but quickly enough you'll figure out how the game works and realize there's a single best method for winning (not even a handful, a single one) barring random events (which are also unbalanced) and the AI is not a challenge at all, which makes things really bad because multiplayer is half-broken (used to be fully broken)."This and more. Wish I wouldn't have bought it. Combat boils down to a rock/paper/scissors thta can screw you over on one random wrong choice even if your force is vastly superior. The AI cheats, hard, even on normal, and unless you play extremely optimally you will lose. Diplomacy is not an option, the AI turns on you for no apparent reason even if you're in full peace treaty. New ship classes are nested in an exploration tree, fleet sizes are divided between war and diplomacy. Early expansion is the only way to win, and the dev sknow this and slot in extreme happiness penalties to doing this to penalize it, however, unless you do it, you cannot spam enough ships to win vs the ai.If you can maange to play against nothing but other humans, you might have a passable amount of fun. Skip this game.

												Among the best in its genre, Endless Space does a beautiful job delivering a fun strategic turn based game. One of the best games I have ever played, Endless Space is a must have for your game library.  This is one game where the developers listened, and they delivered.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I haven't played since the Disharmony expansion came out, but this is a very nice 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game.  I rate it as the best space-themed 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game (of course, it's also among the newest) and second only to Sid Meier's Civilization games for best 4X[en.wikipedia.org] overall.  It would be tempting to call this Civ2 in Space, but that's not quite accurate.  Certainly, if you've played Civilization or any other 4X[en.wikipedia.org] game you'll recognize that the basic ideas and goals are the same - learning the /massive/ tech tree, manipulating heroes, and mastering the nuances of unit behavior will still take some time, however.  The interface is, unfortunately, clunky and hard to read in the same way that the old Civ games were.  The presentation problems are primarily related to the tiny fonts that don't seem to scale with screen resolution and the amazing complexity of the game.  Here, each hero has multiple disciplines with unique talent trees for each.  Deep options for ship customization almost make for a game within itself, as much time can be spent min/max optimizing weight budget by rotating out varying armaments, engines, colonization pods, hulls, and more.  Planetary systems are similarly complex, and require a fair amount of micromanagement for min/max players - it's a lot like the way it was necessary to position each villager for each town in old Civilization games at harder difficulties.  Unfortunately, it's also rather tedious.  If you're a fan of Civilization and the idea of Civ in space sounds enticing, then this is the game you should be looking at.  It's not perfect and the learning curve is substantial, but there's a lot of promise here.  I'm not sure if there is a follow-up in the works or not, but this is an amazing first effort and I can absolutely see the potential for successive versions to challenge Sid Meier's lordship over the 4X[en.wikipedia.org] genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Review of Endless SpacePros:-Relatively easy to learn compared to other 4X space games (i.e. stream-lined mechanics); tutorial itself is weak though so learning with friends help a lot-Great visuals-Good game length for 4X space game (ranges from 1 to 4 hours, depending on number of players, map size, and aggression of each player)-Diverse number of races and makes good use of the hero system-Gameplay itself is pretty good in terms of economy, expansion, and various aspects of "empire building"Cons:-Mediocre combat system; uses a combat card system, pretty hands-off but it's better than full auto-resolve or micro-managing every battle-Diplomacy system is rather simple-Mediocre AI (if you only play single player, then you'll have much less enjoyment than if you play with your friends)-Increasing difficulty of AI just gives them "cheat" advantages-Some bugs that cause game crashes; however, it is mitigated by auto-saves so this isn't too bad-Other misc bugs can cause the need for loading of your auto-saveOverall 7.5/10. Would give it an 8.5 if it didn't have those annoying bugs and better AI. Recommend playing if you have friends that also enjoy 4X space games.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												It's a lot like Evil Empire 2, ok that's probably too obscure for anyone to know.It's like O-Game where you can design your own ships and it has good graphics.If you're to young to know O-Game, it's a little bit like Civilization in space or more like a turn based Sins of a Solar Empire.You get to colonize planets, grow the population, research technologies (the tree grows in 4 directions with lots of crossover in each branch so that few tech is really "mandatory"), build your fleet and expand your empire.The different races play quite differently.It has it's weaknesses, the combat for example is not the best. My gripes with it is that you can't pick which fleet to attack when you attack enemy fleets around a solar system;Managing fleets is very cumbersome, you have to click a LOT to move ships around, split them, merge them, name the fleets, send them around and wonder why they don't listen to your clicks (e.g.  a combat has started somewhere else and I didn't notice the silent notification), pick them from the tiny window that you have to scroll a lot, find them in the other window after you've sent them to another solar system.You can't directly interact in combat, except for picking 3 strategies for the 3 combat phases and those strategy cards are not intuitive to use at all.I especially hate that the AI built ships with lots of defense but no offense, which I couldn't kill because I didn't focus on military research, but which also couldn't kill me because they had no offense. The AI would "attack" me every turn with them, which was borderline trolling and the kicker is that those ships were "blockading" the solar system which had economic downsides for me but they couldn't actually do any real harm.I'm still recommending it because it's overall a pretty good game. The GUI for economy is well thought out. It works pretty well in coop, you can do the most important actions for the turn, mark your turn as ready to end and continue to do less urgent actions which will still happen in the same turn if you manage to do them before everyone has passed their turn, or else just happen later. Also saving and loading multiplayer games works well.Just maybe wait for a sale :P

												I am a big fan of space strategy games so I had high hopes for Endless Space.  Unfortunately due to the combat system every space battle is a glorified rock-paper-scissors for weapons and shields, giving you a 2/3 chance to do damage and a 2/3 chance to get vaporized, unless you decide to make a balanced ship which will give you a 3/3 chance to do little damage and die.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Among the best in its genre, Endless Space does a beautiful job delivering a fun strategic turn based game.  Most comparable to civilization 5, or other turn based games, Endless Space has you slowly take turns improving your solar systems and taking over the galaxy.  You are given races, which enable the gameplay to change, not to mention the endless customization for creating your own race, and controlling the size of your galaxy.  On top of the 100+ hours you will satisfyingly get, there are also numerous achievements to work for if you want to get all the achievements.  One of the best games I have ever played, Endless Space is a must have for your game library.  This is one game where the developers listened, and they delivered.

												Endless Space is so much fun, If you have never played a 4x strategy I reccomend looking up a good guide. The UI could use dome work, but once you know where everything is it gets better obviously. Just a little over complicated at some points with tons of micro-management. One other thing is the combat is rock-paper-scissors, plain and simple. It has great cinimatics but you have no real control of your ships when fighting which is a big letdown. Otherwise this game is spectacular with a ton of customization and content to explore.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												A turn-based space 4x strategy game set on a grand scale of galactic proportions. Intended to be more of a sandbox start where the stage is set with back-story, races and factions, but it is up to you to define the story after that. While lacking some of the charm and character of a game like Civilization 5, where the characters were very immersive and the feeling of writing history compelled you on. Endless Space, while comparable to Civ 5 and other space strategy games, is not trying to be a copy but a beast of its own. The game also runs fairly well on machines built from crumpets, like mine, 100% 7 year old genuine golden machine right here.The games strength lies in the screen you will be spending a lot of time with, getting to know, making tea for and so on; the galaxy view, also FIDS is a guy you will have to get friendly with, get to know FIDS real well – FIDS stands for Food, Industry, Dust and Science; optimizing these will be important. The interface on the default view and the leaves that stemming from the branches connected to the galaxy interface are simple and relatively easy to navigate; the economy is rather solid, with many resources to monopolize and exploit, – my favourites being Bluecap Mold and Hydromiel - with resources set on low it can create some interesting situations. Managing and growing your empire is can be done easily, but to keep an empire at its optimal level some loving care to keep it in check and sound engineering ideas  are required to achieve a lovely, green and flowering empire. You can also zoom in and out of the galaxy view and into systems which you will find at helpful and the planets vivid colours pleasing to the eye.Hero’s can be important to your strategy too due to their boosting abilities and a variety of roles they can fill either in administration or fleet command, however they are not essential pieces to make keep your empire spinning – just be sure to pick them up and assign them to tasks if you can. Expansion is a very good thing and is a big part of the games early stage. Systems contain planets usually of varying tiers with nice planets being tier one and smelly gas planets + floating rocks being the highest tier, needless to say tier ones are better. You should probably colonise lots of systems as quickly as possible... but not too many at a pace your empire cannot keep up with... that could end very badly and happiness will snowball out of control very quickly; also keep an eye on the happiness of the populous, try to avoid planets with really bad happiness modifiers early on unless you have a good reason to colonise that system – such as a good happiness modifiers outweighing the bad one or a burning desire for that system. Initially colonised systems become outposts and over time will become colonies, colonies are better in many ways, for one they have an influence ring which is good for you but bad for your enemies systems if it swallows it whole; during their outpost state they can still be attacked without war being declared so you might want to defend them from the unforgiving galaxy until they mature. Also be sure to have each system doing something, even if it’s just Industry to Dust conversion, wasted turns don’t come back.Research, is a bit like a big expanding circle, you can plough through in one direction if you wanted to but before long you will have to turn back and follow up the other branches for important and relevant technologies; in game terms, N-Way Fusion Plants & Isolation Shields in the Applied Sciences tree is important early on while Applied Casmir Affect in the Exploration & Expansion tree is very good for early expansion, there are techs in the Diplomacy & Trading tree that is important to happiness and keeping yourself protected is always imperative to your survival so the Galactic Warfare tree will be visited regularly.The somewhat unusual combat system has a somewhat offhanded approach to it. The cinematic battle sequences while pretty and enjoyable to watch lacks some of the interactivity people are used to, where normally you needed to rely on positioning and particular manoeuvres in battle; however instead you rely more on the way you have set up your fleet beforehand which is assisted by a cards which designate actions your fleet can perform, whether or not a heroic Admiral is in the fleet and fleet targeting options during the battle. These battles can be auto-resolved if you wish; you can also invade systems with a number of methods such as a general siege, bombing or sending in the troops – of course you can turn to place to ashes after if you wanted to. The battles are not grand and truly epic but are enjoyable and perform their role rather well. Ships are arranged into fleets, which can be managed from the fleet tab on the galaxy screen, are custom built from hull designs, while the general blueprints are not yours to play with, the toys you attach to it are. Good ship design is essential to defend yourself from hungry Cravers or invade some helpless Sophons on an isolated system; while some understanding of the combat system and understanding how to achieve your design goal is crucial for success, designing the ships in question is quite easy once you know where to find shipyard is. Amplitude while being a small - French – studio, have put a lot of love into its first game, they have also allowed the community to get involved in a number of occasions to help make decisions for the future of the game through the Games2Gether system and forums and are updating the game regularly with content and fixes. Visit the Amplitude forums if you have any questions about Endless Space; discuss the game, query problems or related waffles on your mind. You can also check out their other upcoming* games Endless legend – another strategy game - and Dungeons of The Endless – a rouge-like-dungeon-delving game – if they snatch your interest and run of with it. So, lead your empire to victory in the deep darkness of space, through the vibrant jungles, across desolate barren landscapes, scorching hot sand dunes and towering metropolises. Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate my good friend.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This game is strangely addictive and then I realized... This is Civilization in space why wouldn't it be... I've owned it for less then a week and have sunk a good 30 hours into it already and will probably sink a lot more knowing how many hours I've given to civilization.-Deep game with awesome graphics even works well on slower machines(as long as you don't enter visual parts of battles and do the auto complete battle.)-Tech tree giant haven't fully explored after 5-6 playthroughs.-Great amount of customization with space ships less cookie cutter.Also if you like Sins of the Solar Empire you'll like this game unless you like the fast pace of Sins and not the turn based strategy of Civilization.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Very much a well-done space-based Civilization style game, better than Galatic Civ II in my opinion.  That said, you will most likely need to spend more time understanding and learning the game's mechanics than with either Civ or Galactic Civ.  Expect to get trashed by the AI regularly until you figure things out (or turn the difficulty down).Worth the investment in patience, but I still get beaten by the AI more often with this game than comparable difficulties in Civ or GC.  Do yourself a favor and study the races and start with one that fits your play style... you will get frustrated less often with this approach.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Endless Space is a space 4X game with a notably well-designed expansion mechanic. Unfortunately, the smaller details of this game's mechanics are not well-documented; while the mechanics overall are easy to understand, there are many sneaky factors that can cause a large impact on the game. For example, a star system outside your colored influence circles generate only HALF the science and money - but nowhere is this mentioned, save for a small "distance from empire" factor when you examine your science output in detail.The military system in Endless Space is often criticized. Indeed, space battles quickly devolve into mashing the auto button over and over, as you watch your indestructible ships blow up the AI's endless stream of useless fodder. Because of the common rebalances and redesigns of ship-building, it is extremely difficult to reason about the effectiveness of ship designs. Additionally, capturing star systems is less than glamorous, with bombardment reduced to watching a colored circle fill up and a turns left icon count down.Despite its flaws, Endless Space is in the end still a strong 4X game. Strategy in general remains the same no matter what race or victory type you play, but the game mechanics' nuances and relative importance of timing make mastering this strategy a great challenge.

												The AI is quite rubbish, but then 99.5% of all games suffer that problem.I think what a lot of people get frustrated with is the inability to just half♥♥♥♥♥♥an empire and win, which you can do in a lot of 4x games (Civ 5, for all it's acclaim and excellency, can very much be won just by randomly picking technology with a little conservation.)In Endless Space it's significantly harder. Whether by design or poor AI, the game more or less encourages you to decide on a victory strategy and go for it, and to do that you have to make significant steps backwards to get forwards. Taking the time to build up your navy is necessary for any real chance at a military victory, but doing so early enough to get a foot on the ladder and avoid risk of being flattened by the Cravers and other military empires really does impact your ability to research and build and expand...all three of which are increasingly necessary for building an effective empire.Similarly you can't just hump one research tree or one tactic to victory. If you only build ships, you won't be expanding and your research is crippled, which means your 70 destroyers will be flattened by a single ship before you realize your mistake. If you want a decent navy you need to unlock the better ships (second tree),spread to multiple worlds for the industrial power to build (second tree but not directly related to military at all), and nab the perks that build up your fleet size (third tree) as well as building better weapons (1st tree, and the only one dirctly 'military'), and to do all that in a timely fashion you need to invest in better research methods (4th tree, which also contains a few very vital techs for your fleet.)On top of all that, you need to do it in the right order, or you risk spending too much time on one area to the cost of another....and your empire.Summary: Endless space isn't perfect, but I think it's got the concept of Empire Building down pretty damn good. The reason the AI feels so overpowered and quite often throttles you with ramping up ship strength is because it's a computer, and usually much much better and prioritizing than you.

												While I'm not very good at this game I still enjoy it. It's pretty easy to get into however there are parts that could really do with an actual tutorial rather than a text dump such as the starship builder but it is satisfying to spend the whole game steadly colonizing planets and filling the tech tree and getting all the money in the galazy and still loose. The one massive problem I found was after a really long game I got a weird pop up with a paragraph of code which crashed the game. I have no idea why it turned up but honestly it was so late in the game I couldn't really be bothered to start up the game again.All in all I still like this game, even if I don't fully understand how to play it properly.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Firstly, the surface stuff. the graphics and music are pretty good - the sounds are quiet and atmospheric like you would expect for the universe it's based in. The visuals are nice, and the manual battle sequences are pretty while most of your time is really spent in the battle map, where the UI, once you get used to it, works well enough. I find in a lot of these 4X type games, once you have a large amount of planets/cities/systems/whatever, it gets kind of tedious giving them orders every turn, but for the most part, come end game, you're either pumping out units or pushing for production to research or dust bonuses, so it's not that bad.Now for story.  The factions all have stories and even intro videos that are actually interesting (the first time around). But don't get this game if you expect any kind of campaign because there is none - the story really ends at the beginning of a match. There isn't really much personality in the factions and how they act, it's more to do with some of the diplomatic factors you share with them. What is great though about factions is the multitude of customization traits. Each race has starting research and unique abilities and weakneses, and that you as someone who may want to make your own faction can try to balance yourself as you carve out their identity. Things like modifiers for diplomatic options, population growth, resource management, ship enchancements, etc.Now the negative - taking a bad path in research can lead you down a disasterous path. There are things that are important to get and things that are only time sinks, and it is hard to know which is which when you're first starting out. The random nature of battles makes it kind of annoying at times - the only real strategy when it comes to battle is fleet composition and using certain modifiers at certain times, like boosts to armor or weapons power, but direct control over things is not something that is possible. The AI is a little dumb as well - early on, placing colonies at choke points is a way to box them in and sometimes they don't really do anything about it. Their minds change constantly about you, and alliances fall apart quickly or pop up out of nowhere because of something as miniscule as the fact that your colonies are neighbours.But despite those points, I found the game quite enjoyable. The games take a long time, and there is a good amount of variety in customizing maps, so chances are you will get a fair amount of play time out of it. Basically, the more you play the more you will hone the route through the research tree and balancing all the other factors.I'd recommend this game for sure, but say that the expansion really is something you should only get if you like the game yourself - the amount of content it adds is decent, but you will not make or break your initial impression by missing out on it (or getting it for that matter).

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I'm a big fan of this genre from Masters of Orion.   For an indie game this is pretty amazing.   If you are expecting pure combat, I don't think this game is for you.   It is more about system development and expansion.   I lost the first couple of games on weakest AI because I was focused on military.   I finally won a game on easy using Science.    Micro management of the systems.This is actually very interesting.   I'm 40 hours in and I don't think I've mastered this at all.   My mid game, around 80 turns was very strong.  But my early game is still poor.   What is fun is to put the game in a window.  Then pull up dirty pleasure tv show off to the side and then just clicking through your planets to make them rapidly develop.   You actually have to read the system improvements because one size does NOT fit all.   In other words, on some systems it is a complete waste to build every improvement.  Tech TreeAgain another piece of the game that makes you think.   You don't need everything, especially if your are targeting a specific victory condition like dust, tech, aliance, etc.  Read and decide.  You must look at the planets near your home world before you unlock the colonization for those worlds.   Sure eventually you will get all but you need to race to unlock key strategic systems ExpansionThis is very cool.  It is easier to expand in sytems you own rather than sending out ships.  Makes sense right?   However you still need to send ships out to seed systems.  And you need to seed systems that either block other player's expansion or give you huge development potential.  And you haven't always developed the right technologies to seed the planets on the target system.  This makes for a great game play balance in the game.Ship UpgradesI really like the modification and retrofit system.  Very easy to use and key to keeping your fleet uptodate.CombatThis is a bit dull but not the focus of the game.   You pick attitudes for three rounds of combats, long range, mid range, short range, then your ships do their thing.   I've found repairs to be pretty good.   But again I don't think the focus of the game on combat, especially since you only have about 5 classes of ships to fly with various mods on them.  It is easy to win other ways.DiplomacyI'm still a bit lost.   I don't quite understand why I can't initiate peace treaties.   Maybe that is the way amoeba's are.   Not sure.   Alliances seem good until you get thrown into a battle you don't want to be in.Nay SayersIt always reminds me of players that want to play the way they think rather than the way the game allows them to think.  Sure we all have had our frustrations with that.   Even I had that with the first couple of games.  But once you start looking for other ways to do things, the game opens up.ValueI picked this up on steam sale.  Great value.   Fun little game completely worth the money.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Note:  This review was written for just the Emporer Edition of the game.  I have not yet tried it with the expansion.  If I ever get the expansion, I will update my review.I felt conflicted about whether to recommend this game or not.  In the end, I decided that the pros outweigh the cons.  That being said, it has a lot of missed potential, and I hope they improve on a few things for the sequel.Pros:- The game is a lot of fun, especially beginning and mid game.  A lot of thought has been put into certain details, such as the tech tree, which makes it fun to explore all the different techs.- You can customize your own race, and choose its advantages and disadvantages.  This, to me, is one of its strongest points.  I had a lot of fun creating my own alien races to play as and play against- The game has an AI function that allows you to automate system management.  I didn't discover this feature until my 2nd playthrough, and let me tell you, it sped up the game a ton!  Now, you still need to keep tabs on what it is building and where, as the AI will not always make the choices that best suits your strategy, but for the most part it really speeds up the mid game.Cons:- The game as a steep learning curve.  The tutorial is more or less useless.  It took a lot of playing around with settings and features before I was able to figure out the ins and outs of the game.- Ship combat is a little boring, albeit fun to watch at least.- The End game leaves something to be desired.  Once you get past the mid game stage, the game tends to drag on.  This is especially true if you are trying to achieve different types of victories, such as the science or diplomatic.In conclusion, This game is fun, but requires patience towards the end.  I hope that when they do the sequel, they tap into the potential that this game had.6/10

												This is a great game that I recommend anyone who likes this type of game to buy, I have only one headache that every time I see it just makes me want to scream "WHY DO THIS?!?!?!?" at my monitor and that is the Hero system. Whoever designed them to be both useful on the ground and in space should have been dragged out the back of teh office and beaten with a stick till this was changed, as it cuts the usefulness of most of them in half. Having ones for space and ones for the ground would have made this game a lot more enjoyable than it is for me as I find i have to keep quitting and restarting the game around 5-10 times each time I want to start a new game so that I get at least 1 ground based Hero to begin with, but yeah other than that small headache the game is great :)

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												Very tentative recommendation, 6.5 or 7 out of 10.Frankly, I like the game, but it's shallow. Wide gameplay, but shallow depths. You have planets to manage, systems to conquer, fancy space battles you can watch and organise. Lots of things to do.Until you get into the game. My first match, normal, random AI, default starting stuff I spent a lot of time clicking the "end turn" button. If you don't get the AI to manage your systems for you, you will get waaaaayyyy too many systems to check up on. The research tree is pretty big, and learning what to research is kinda of difficult starting out.Essentially, there's too much of an info-dump of things that may or may not matter with the tutorial bits, and I did what I shouldn't and skipped it. Info-dump + not particularly complex gameplay. There's no mega-fleets (yet), or commanding ships like in E.V.E. of "torpedoes on the port ship! Engage beam weapons!". It's just a cutscene where you choose 3 tasks for your ships to do and that's it for ship vs ship stuff. Have not tried out ship vs planet stuff yet though.Will edit later. Leaning towards the "not recommended", but I don't think I've played the dlcs yet (still in first game, lol). 2-3 hours of my gameplay were spent idling. Game was purchased during steam sale for $14 or so.

												This game takes a while to get in to, and learn, and at first you will most likely fail a lot because the tutorial is trash, but look up guides on steam and you should grasp it quickly. the game is deep and really fun once you get the hang of it. The community is great as well. when i first got it i had problems starting t up, but i just deleted the logo movies that play on start up and it fixed the problem. overall the game is definitely worth a buy, the only real complaint i have about the gameplay is the terrible camera angles in battle, but those don't reall matter as the battles are automated so it only affects cinematic experience.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Many of the game mechnics seem broken or unalanced, such as empire expansion leads to a weak empire prone to war declarations, while a smaller by scientific empire leads to easy wins. Taxation can be bypassed through diplomacy or industry to dust. There is also no system level tax to aid with unhappy systems. Battle seems to be a boring version rock paper scicccors. Ship repair costs are prohibitive. Varrious UX \ UI issues icuding fiddly controls for mananging system\planet populace, no highlightig or greaying out of improvements which make no difference to a system (e.g. you have to read through all the planet types, etc). Queue windows are too small, and dragging and dropping itesm to change priority is a boring chore. Large empires just devolve into micromanagement, but again large empires do not seem the way to go.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												Great game, decent graphics, sleepy music (not boring, just capable of making you wanna sleep), and though there is the rare freeze/crash/both, its still worth getting.+ customizable empires (however you like)+ Cool random events+ Influence colors shows your territory- have to research anything to do with galactic communication- battle numbers are unclear: you could have 26k power vs 12k power, and you could lose- Random event decision making isn't clear on "good" or "bad": You could be "Hostile" and get something great, but if you're "Helpful" you could get something horrible. Just think color coded effects would help (green for good, red for bad)- When making a new empire, click a trait (good/bad), you intend to remove just 1 from the group but game removes entire group. Extra negative is that the traits don't mention what group they are from (whether in title or description)+/- Race/Faction exclusive tech (good if you wanna beat everyone, bad if you're in coop)- Huge maps feel way too small+ Designing ships isn't complicated- Auto-Upgrade can make worst ships in the game, don't use it- Manual Battle is just aesthetic, you can see the battle in action, but thats it- BIG Negative - Can't exit manual battle mode? Can still get Tech Victory even if its turned off- Game admits it will CHEAT in harder difficultiesAnd just note, this is based on the EMPEROR EDITION without the DLC. Overall rating: 7.5/10I mentioned earlier that the game CAN freeze/crash/both, but that is PRETTY RARE. If you want maps that rival MOO3, you won't like.If you want a decent Space TB strategy game, get it.If you want a game that CAN beat you on Beginner mode, get it.If you can handle a game that WILL cheat to beat you, get it.If you can't handle a game that rarely crashes or freezes, GTFO Steam.

												Great game, decent graphics, sleepy music (not boring, just capable of making you wanna sleep), and though there is the rare freeze/crash/both, its still worth getting.+ customizable empires (however you like)+ Cool random events+ Influence colors shows your territory- have to research anything to do with galactic communication- battle numbers are unclear: you could have 26k power vs 12k power, and you could lose- Random event decision making isn't clear on "good" or "bad": You could be "Hostile" and get something great, but if you're "Helpful" you could get something horrible. Just think color coded effects would help (green for good, red for bad)- When making a new empire, click a trait (good/bad), you intend to remove just 1 from the group but game removes entire group. Extra negative is that the traits don't mention what group they are from (whether in title or description)+/- Race/Faction exclusive tech (good if you wanna beat everyone, bad if you're in coop)- Huge maps feel way too small+ Designing ships isn't complicated- Auto-Upgrade can make worst ships in the game, don't use it- Manual Battle is just aesthetic, you can see the battle in action, but thats it- BIG Negative - Can't exit manual battle mode? Can still get Tech Victory even if its turned off- Game admits it will CHEAT in harder difficultiesAnd just note, this is based on the EMPEROR EDITION without the DLC. Overall rating: 7.5/10I mentioned earlier that the game CAN freeze/crash/both, but that is PRETTY RARE. If you want maps that rival MOO3, you won't like.If you want a decent Space TB strategy game, get it.If you want a game that CAN beat you on Beginner mode, get it.If you can handle a game that WILL cheat to beat you, get it.If you can't handle a game that rarely crashes or freezes, GTFO Steam.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I actually got into this AFTER playing Endless Legend, and while I can see what lessons Amplitude took from ES and applied in EL, ES still gives an enjoyable experience for anyone looking for a Space 4X that isn't an RTS.To put it short, the game is very administration and automation heavy. If you're the kind of person who likes the exploitation part of 4X, and if you like automating each of your turns to a science, then this is the game for you. I personally love making research decisions, setting waypoints for fleets, etc. and I can forgive the game's poor combat, but if you're looking for a game to stretch your strategic skills this isn't it.I'm really enjoying this game. After Civilization V's expansion, Brave New World, Civ V became a bit biased towards smaller empires, so having a game that allows and repays rapid expansion and exploitation is welcome.Despite the relatively small size of the playable maps, empires and armies can get pretty huge. The U.I. lacks character, but  it's really clean so administrating your empire is very easy. This is also one of the problems, though, as you start to get into the groove of running your empire every turn starts to feel monotonous, only broken up by random events that, more often than not, end up hurting your empire.Battles are also not very strategic. The combat system is intriguing, but ultimately it just doesn't involve the player enough, and I hope in any future iterations of the game they use EL's battle system. Winning wars ultimately comes down to ship design (which you have to constantly evolve to keep up with your enemies) and outproducing your opponents. It feels really good to have twelve fleets going at once, though, and managing a large navy is also quite fun for me.Great game if you like micromanaging your empire, maximizing production, science, and economic output and planning, then this is the game for you. Unfortunately, anyone looking for a strategic challenge should pass.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Endless Space is a 4X game (expand/explore/exploit/exterminate) in the same vein as Civilization, with a lot of similarities to Civ IV. The game has a lot of interesting unique mechanics in addition to the normal Civ gameplay including a uniquely structured tech tree, purchasable heroes that can lead your troops or your planets, and a unique way to utilize your planets (cities essentially) for resources. In addition, the many traits that the different civilizations have change the dynamic of the game and your priorities. The ability to make custom civilations by mixing and matching these traits also gives a lot of room for creativity and new experiences.However, the main flaw of Endless Space is that it feels somewhat lifeless. It does a lot of things well, but there isn't anything it does particularly amazingly. The game ends up feeling somewhat generic because despite the unique mechanics there isn't anything that stands out as a large improvement over other 4X games. Overall I would recommend Endless Space to fans of 4X games, especially those that enjoyed CivIV more than CivV, and for people who enjoyed Endless Legend and want to try a similar game. However, for people who aren't huge fans of the genre I would recommend sticking to Civ or other common 4X games instead.

												I don't hate this game. The mechanics and features are fantastic (great tech tree, lot's of customisation, etc.). However....The A.I. sucks. They literally go around and try to colonise every single planet. After they have done that, they declare war on you because "they don't have enough room for their population" (even if you are allies). Don't buy this game unless you want to play it with friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												The lore in this game is by far the best ever ! I only say that because there were many years where there was all these diferent lores, such as Star Wars, and Warhammer 40K. Yet none of them really interested me, and for a very long time I never understood fan bases that got made at directors or game developrs for making games or movies that didn't fit into the "criteria" for the lore being depicted. Then one day, Amplitude Studios arrives with a brand new game, Endless Space, and the game is just brilliant. The lore especially, its got a mysterious 'Endless' sort of view point, in the fact that in every game it focuses on the 'now' of the main factions and leaves the mystery part to the 'past' factions that all sort of coincide with each and every game. It was something original, and finally a place where I can could my own and understand the lore, and finally understand what its like to be a geek for someting as fictional and sci-fi as Endless Space. The reason I consider this a recommended review, is because this is the biggest appeal to me when I play Endless Space, I feel like I'm leading the factions to prosperity, and sometimes I would just mindless play the game to roleplay and go on a adventure that only this game could offer. There is no other strategy or 4X game that quite gives you this much sort of engagement in a storyline and lore. I also thought it would be important to note that I picked up this game in 2013, exactly before the day of the release of the Disharmony expansion. The love of the lore of Endless Space still going strong.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												First, let me get this off my chest. Appalling, nonsensical idiocies simply ooze out of this game.Exhibit A. Linear, corridor combat where even ships with no guns can 'blockade' your attacking force and prevent it from moving until you destroy those ships. And you must destroy them one fleet at a time regardless of their relative strength. Fleets of tiny cardboard scouts or huge bullet sponges with no guns can thus blockade overwhelmingly strong armadas and entire star systems for an indefinite number of turns as more worthless ships are churned out and added to the stack, or retreating ships immediately return and rejoin the fray. Combat pointlessly drags on and on where more sensibly you would blast out the entire stack of fleets in one turn or better yet, go around them because they don't have the firepower to prevent you. But not here. Here you are stuck in a 1D corridor and must blast out the barriers one at a time to get through. This is simply an appalling game mechanic for a 3D space game. No. No. No. *No!*Exhibit B. You cannot destroy planets only take them over after a minimum of 8 turns of siege or a highly costly invasion that can quickly deplete your population. This is simply a recipe for dragging out combat. Overwhelming strong sieges (100:1 or more) still take 8 turns whereas they should just blast right through the guy so you can move on. Here there objective seems to be to explicitly inhibit crushing weak enemies by blasting them into dust or by sweeping over them. This slows combat down and turns it into a slog.Exhibit C. Negotiating peace with one member of an alliance immediately forces peace with all the other members without compensation or negotiation. Nor can you negotiate peace with them all at once to get something from everybody. Very beneficial peace settlements with one member must therefore be ignored or the game grinds to a halt while you wait out the peace delay to continue your war with the rest of the alliance. Again, this just artificially drags out the game for no reason and no value.And I could go on, but *despite* these debilitating design decisions, Endless Space is still worth playing.The reason that this is so is because the other aspects of the game compensate for the dumbnesses and the grindy combat. The excellent and deep research tree, the ability to terraform your planets, the special race base characteristics combined with the very broad ability to customize your own race, and the excellent art assets all come together to produce something worth your while. You will need patience to put up with the grindy combat and the ability to turn a blind eye to some of the nonsensical things that go on, but if you can, you will be rewarded with an enjoyable and interesting game with significant replayability.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Endless Space is a great 4X strategy game (Explore, Expand, Exploit and Exterminate). I mostly play action games and shooters and never played a 4X strategy game before. So my experience is extremely limited to say the least. The only reason I got into this game is because of my love for the sci-fi. All those ships fighting in space looked very cool.This game has a learning curve, and you might need to watch some videos on how to actually play it, what researches to complete and in what order, for example, this chick knows her shít:https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLcw-IheRx7UqeOZMTU6fdz-gU8APFeDAhSo after watching her videos I was able to win my first game on normal difficulty (which is definitely not easy).Once you learn, it becomes very easy to understand what to do and when. It's just like in RTS games – you build armies and destroy opponent, only with more ways to win and everyone takes turns. To sum everything up, it’s a very good entrance to a 4X strategy genre. At this stage, this game is fun, perfectly polished, fast paced for a TBS and relatively easy to understand. So I definitely recommend it to all sci-fi fans out there.

												10/10I recommend it.Endless Space is everthing I could hope for in a game.  It gives me the freedom to customize my Faction as I wish, and to customize what kind of map I'll play on.  All of the factions are very unique and detailed, providing a lot of well written background from which to draw a strong narative from.  The hand drawn art mixed in with top notch graphics is an especially nice touch, and some of the faction art was so nice it graced my desktop background for a time.  To top it off, the gameplay, though perhaps not the best I've seen, was really well suited to this type of game.All in all this was one of the few games that I thoroughly enjoyed playing, and my game time reflects this.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												I bought this game because I played Dungeon of the Endless and it was a lot of fun, namely because it was unique.I played this game for many more hours and I liked it. But there are much better 4X games out there.=== The Good: ====Simple and fast gameplay that's relatively easy to learn for a 4X game.Great graphics.Good music.Awesome stories.Good random events.Great simplified combat and interesting cinematic view. -- Wish there was a speed-up option.=== The Bad: ====As this is a thumbs down review, I will need to explain myself.1) The races are very similar and it's usually not that a good idea to specialize too much in tech.2) The UI is simple, but too simple.3) The game plays more like a board-game, this is also a double-edged sword.1) Races and the Tech Tree:- The hero pool is shared. The way they develop and grow is identical.- The races grant relatively small stat bonuses that don't seem to affect the gameplay too much; you can win in almost any way with any race without too much trouble.- Races do not modify the tech tree with the exception of the starting couple of tier-1 (basically free) techs and the locations of a couple various other technologies.- The tech tree balances everyone's research, which basically makes every empire the same even as the game progresses, making specialization sometimes even harmful:a) for bigger military fleets, you must research diplomacy;b) for new combat ship chassis, you must research colonization;c) for more combat tactics, you must research architecture;d) for more armor against one kind of weapon, you must research a different kind of weapon;e) for more heroes, you must research 10 other technologies;f) if you resarch enough of one weapon, you can research high levels of another weapon without researching its preceding levels.I'm sure that there are more examples, but these are the main ones that I thought seemed too illogical. I think that the tech tree should be more linear. Whatever you want more/better of, that's what you research. Also, certain races should have exclusive access to entire branches, not just a slightly earlier tier-4 missile.2) The UI is Bare-Bones Simple:This greatly helps find the important information you need right away. Also, perhaps the game is trying to lower its learning curve, but it makes it hard to get the information you need to get your most out of your empire without going online.- You can't know too much about certain fleet stats until you're in certain situations where they are directly applied, for instance, invasion/bombardment stats.- You can't see clearly what a ship is equipped with or what abilities is has.- You can't see what a class is designed with without going in to modify it.- You can't really see what enemy ships have (even ones you've fought) without fighting them adn watching the cinematic view.- By-turn math for resources seems mostly transparent and listed out quite plainly, but they often don't add up right. That hero's ability isn't reflected in the score correctly, or that +50 dust bonus isn't showing in the system or in the universe as it should, or that operator that you thought should be multiplied was maybe added. I think it's good that they try to show everything, yet it doesn't _quite_ show everything and it makes me uncertain whether it's bugged or if certain things just aren't shown or whether the description doesn't match the actual effect(s).- The specific effects of many facilities are unclear from their descriptions. After building them (see above), they don't seem to add together right according to what the description(s) made me think.- Trade routes are undisplayed (as far as I can tell) in the UI yet there are so many abilities and facilities that deal with them so they are probably quite important. Values that seem to be purely integers have percentage modifiers that can be applied which doesn't really make sense.3) It's a Board Game:- With similar fleet layouts, whoever has the higher battle rating wins mostly unharmed, so a wealthy empire has no way of swarming (and beating) a much smaller yet only slightly higher-tech empire.- Countering card types is more important than actually paying attention to what a card does, so the content of your fleet and the compatibility with the card is not very important; instead you'll find yourself either guessing what the AI will probably do or just start save scumming if it's a close battle.- Some of the random events are too random, too powerful, or scripted poorly. Need 1000 dust to save your homeworld from an attack of 5 large pirate fleets but you only have 34 dust? Not a problem! -- Did you just spend 34 dust and basically wipe out 4 empires? Lucky! -- Did you wait five turns investing (resource) to unveil some Endless secret but never get a message? What a pity!- You can't micromanage ships very much, you can't customize ships very much, you can't rename ships, you can't choose how you renovate ships. It's literally as if they're fixed game pieces on a board. There's a very finite number of ship chassis (6) to work with that offer little in the way of diversifying.- All the planets develop mostly the same way, by building one of each of the same buildings on them. I prefer the facility limit method where you have to pick which ones you want yet you can repeat certain ones to create mega-factories that would starve without outside food. Yet, you can terraform planets to specialize planets. So that almost balances out this situation.- There are literally 3 weapons and 3 armors. You are playing adaptive rock-paper-scissors.- Heroes are all the same between empires, options are limited with how they interact, hero development follows a fixed perk tree, it plays out exactly like a board game. A more RPG, free-growth stat style (optionally, with perks) would be more immersive.If you like fast, very balanced, simple gameplay, being like a board game is a feature. I would rather not need to focus on rules and ideal build orders as much.Final verdict:This is a pretty, story-tastic quick bare-bones 4X that meets the demands of the genre and stops right there. If you're new to this genre, this is a great way to get into them. The combat mechanics are simplified, rule-oriented and even a little card-y. The sides are quite balanced, too. If you like Risk, you will probably like this game.I want to feel like I'm leading an intergalactic empire in a very asymmetric universe. This game is a little oversimplified for me and the limitations of the UI alongside the general lack of options make it feel very unimmersive.Hope #2 is more complicated, it certainly looks that way in the previews.

Posted: October 29, 2016
												I bought this game because I played Dungeon of the Endless and it was a lot of fun, namely because it was unique.I played this game for many more hours and I liked it. But there are much better 4X games out there.=== The Good: ====Simple and fast gameplay that's relatively easy to learn for a 4X game.Great graphics.Good music.Awesome stories.Good random events.Great simplified combat and interesting cinematic view. -- Wish there was a speed-up option.=== The Bad: ====As this is a thumbs down review, I will need to explain myself.1) The races are very similar and it's usually not that a good idea to specialize too much in tech.2) The UI is simple, but too simple.3) The game plays more like a board-game, this is also a double-edged sword.1) Races and the Tech Tree:- The hero pool is shared. The way they develop and grow is identical.- The races grant relatively small stat bonuses that don't seem to affect the gameplay too much; you can win in almost any way with any race without too much trouble.- Races do not modify the tech tree with the exception of the starting couple of tier-1 (basically free) techs and the locations of a couple various other technologies.- The tech tree balances everyone's research, which basically makes every empire the same even as the game progresses, making specialization sometimes even harmful:a) for bigger military fleets, you must research diplomacy;b) for new combat ship chassis, you must research colonization;c) for more combat tactics, you must research architecture;d) for more armor against one kind of weapon, you must research a different kind of weapon;e) for more heroes, you must research 10 other technologies;f) if you resarch enough of one weapon, you can research high levels of another weapon without researching its preceding levels.I'm sure that there are more examples, but these are the main ones that I thought seemed too illogical. I think that the tech tree should be more linear. Whatever you want more/better of, that's what you research. Also, certain races should have exclusive access to entire branches, not just a slightly earlier tier-4 missile.2) The UI is Bare-Bones Simple:This greatly helps find the important information you need right away. Also, perhaps the game is trying to lower its learning curve, but it makes it hard to get the information you need to get your most out of your empire without going online.- You can't know too much about certain fleet stats until you're in certain situations where they are directly applied, for instance, invasion/bombardment stats.- You can't see clearly what a ship is equipped with or what abilities is has.- You can't see what a class is designed with without going in to modify it.- You can't really see what enemy ships have (even ones you've fought) without fighting them adn watching the cinematic view.- By-turn math for resources seems mostly transparent and listed out quite plainly, but they often don't add up right. That hero's ability isn't reflected in the score correctly, or that +50 dust bonus isn't showing in the system or in the universe as it should, or that operator that you thought should be multiplied was maybe added. I think it's good that they try to show everything, yet it doesn't _quite_ show everything and it makes me uncertain whether it's bugged or if certain things just aren't shown or whether the description doesn't match the actual effect(s).- The specific effects of many facilities are unclear from their descriptions. After building them (see above), they don't seem to add together right according to what the description(s) made me think.- Trade routes are undisplayed (as far as I can tell) in the UI yet there are so many abilities and facilities that deal with them so they are probably quite important. Values that seem to be purely integers have percentage modifiers that can be applied which doesn't really make sense.3) It's a Board Game:- With similar fleet layouts, whoever has the higher battle rating wins mostly unharmed, so a wealthy empire has no way of swarming (and beating) a much smaller yet only slightly higher-tech empire.- Countering card types is more important than actually paying attention to what a card does, so the content of your fleet and the compatibility with the card is not very important; instead you'll find yourself either guessing what the AI will probably do or just start save scumming if it's a close battle.- Some of the random events are too random, too powerful, or scripted poorly. Need 1000 dust to save your homeworld from an attack of 5 large pirate fleets but you only have 34 dust? Not a problem! -- Did you just spend 34 dust and basically wipe out 4 empires? Lucky! -- Did you wait five turns investing (resource) to unveil some Endless secret but never get a message? What a pity!- You can't micromanage ships very much, you can't customize ships very much, you can't rename ships, you can't choose how you renovate ships. It's literally as if they're fixed game pieces on a board. There's a very finite number of ship chassis (6) to work with that offer little in the way of diversifying.- All the planets develop mostly the same way, by building one of each of the same buildings on them. I prefer the facility limit method where you have to pick which ones you want yet you can repeat certain ones to create mega-factories that would starve without outside food. Yet, you can terraform planets to specialize planets. So that almost balances out this situation.- There are literally 3 weapons and 3 armors. You are playing adaptive rock-paper-scissors.- Heroes are all the same between empires, options are limited with how they interact, hero development follows a fixed perk tree, it plays out exactly like a board game. A more RPG, free-growth stat style (optionally, with perks) would be more immersive.If you like fast, very balanced, simple gameplay, being like a board game is a feature. I would rather not need to focus on rules and ideal build orders as much.Final verdict:This is a pretty, story-tastic quick bare-bones 4X that meets the demands of the genre and stops right there. If you're new to this genre, this is a great way to get into them. The combat mechanics are simplified, rule-oriented and even a little card-y. The sides are quite balanced, too. If you like Risk, you will probably like this game.I want to feel like I'm leading an intergalactic empire in a very asymmetric universe. This game is a little oversimplified for me and the limitations of the UI alongside the general lack of options make it feel very unimmersive.Hope #2 is more complicated, it certainly looks that way in the previews.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Let's keep my review simple. I will assume you know what a 4X space game is about and just list how Endless Space fares in my opinion.What Endless Space does really well:- Impressive graphics- Keeps micromanagement surprisingly low- Balanced tech-tree- Even with differences in research levels, battles are still not one-sided- The KI opponents are quite capable diplomats. Where I usually NEVER accept an offer from KI-opponents in other games, the "Endless Space" ones managed to "sell" me deals by offering the right incentives.What it does okay (meaning it's nothing special):- Several ways to win- Different species and the option to create your own- The KI opponents are quite good although they do get an unfair ingame advantage. I would prefer to be able to choose their difficulty AND the amount of "advantage" they get seperately.- Diplomatic options have to be researched. While it does make for an interesting game mechanic I would still prefer to have all diplomatic options from the start.What is missing:- No espionage, sabotage, inciting rebellions etc.- There is basically NOTHING besides the respective faction-intro to evoke some atmosphere in the game. Even when you finally win you only get a small picture of your faction and a rather neutral text telling you that you've just achieved economic / military / scientifiy victory.SummaryAll in all I would give it 4 out of 5 stars. It's very good and addictive but putting some atmosphere in there (voice-overs, a few animated messages etc.) would go a long way. Having some espionage and full access to diplomatic functions from the start would also help to make it even better.
