content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I have semi jokingly renamed this game Endless Waste. Let me explain why.Sure you have fleets in space check. You have planets you can build stuff on check. You can research technologies all check. What they don't tell you is there are plenty of 4x strategy games that accomplish these basics. The question is does this game accomplish it better? My answer is meh..... Yes, meh.......Let me ellaborate. Many people complain of the card system for fleet battles in this game. By way of explanation before one of the three rounds starts you and the A.I must choose a card that fits your strategy. You have many options even starting off and more when you research them. How do they work in actual application? The difference is negligible really. Yeah the right card choice can make a tie a victory and the wrong card choice can make a tie a loss. What it can't do is make superior vessels lose. While i respect this choice for balance's sake it has one major drawback. Space conflict does not require much thought. Planning yes, thought no. TBH the disaster that was MOO3 is better in that sense but not graphically of course. The space battles do look nice.Moving on to planets. Like i said yeah you can build on planets. The way they implement planetary research and production meh.... You can not have individual planetary production queues. I'd be fine with that if it were more like Galactic Civ 3 and you have the option of having a spacedock at every planet producing ships slowly or sending industry to one spacedock. This game does not have that option. Don't take me wrong I am not a Galactic Civ fanboy by any means. IMHO they are mediocre as well for one simple fact. The gaming experience does not evolve that much. Yet this game suffers from that sentiment even more.Moving on to research. Yeah they have research. How do i rate it a tiny bit above meh.... to meeehhhh??.... While on paper the research ideas are good. The way the game implements them is very meh.... This is not the reaserch tree's fault though. It is the planet building and space combat's fault. Those systems make seeing tangible results not so immersive. Which is where Galactic Civ 3 shines and Endless Waste does not. Endless Waste is not very immersive. In Galciv 3 for instance it is surprisingly clear what effect the combat research has in combat. You can watch the missile hit and do damage to another ship. You see the ship catch on fire if it does not have enough Point Defense and the missile is strong enough. In Endless Waste you don't have that. Point defense don't launch lasers or countermeasures etc. Missile impacts don't leave clouds of debris and ships smoking and/or flaming. Making it feel like frankly not much is happening. It becomes quickly boring except through statistics... if you are a statistical person. The same with planetary infrastructure even though TBH the same can be said about that with majority of 4X strategy games including Galactic Civ 3. The major difference is with nothing truly immersive in Endless Waste you don't really feel compelled to keep playing. Your choices simply do not matter except through statistics. So in essence since neither planetray infrastructure or space combat is immersive how can research be immersive? The other two affect the one.Leaving to one last consideration money. Is Endless Waste worth the money? To that I say depends. Let me elaborate. If you love statistics, if you love space and the concept of technologies, if you love that when on sale this is drastically cheaper than Galactic Civ 3 this is for you. For everyone else at most just like myself it's meh... at best.In summary Endless Waste except for the select few is just that an Endless Waste of potential. If they only put in a tiny bit more effort this game would be playable for most of us. Right now not so much. It's too bad because i liked the concept.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Revised my last review and giving a more detailed review of this game.  Verdict still doesn't change, as I think you can buy far better games.First, let's start with the Pro's of this game.- The Cinimatics are nice.- The Soundscore is awesome.- The U.I. is very clean.- Ship design is unique and cool looking.Now, for the long list of Con's.- The A.I. is cheaty and only seems to play one way.- There is no real feeling of exploration.- No visuals of any kind for planetary upgrades.- Limited ship builds which are very basic.- Simple bugs such as destroyed enemy ships warping cinematic never fixed.- Gameplay leaves you longing for more.Basically, this game feels like a good Beta build.  Much of everything is there, but lacks a lot of polish which would make this game exceptional.  The A.I. does not seem to hide the cheaty nature of what normally would be impossible play for a normal player.  Little things such as showing devlopment of planets when you upgrade them, were never added.  Even building your ships have a severe hindrance of being very very basic in design.Many little details leave you feeling like this is an unfinished game.  Small bugs which should have been patched out long ago, like seeing a 'warp away' cinematic even if you destroy all the enemy ships, still remain in this game.  Exploration consists of visiting the next planetary system over, but has left out any other type of 'anomaly' exploration.  (ie. no Blackholes, Vagrant ships, Pulsars, etc.)In the end, with a bit more devlopment, and the addition of just a few things, the game would have improved significantly.  It feels like a format for a game was designed, but a vast majority of content was left out, leaving some nice eye-candy, but nothing filling.I would not recommend this game if you are looking for something long-term... I mean, unless you are interested in playing Multiplayer only, because Single player, the A.I. pulls fleets of ships from nowhere.  Management is minimal and a lot of the game focuses solely on moving ships around and your research tree.  Really, there is no depth here.

content:
Posted: January 23
												ES is all in all not a terrible 4X. You have different races, turn based gameplay and a large tech tree as well as quite a few weapon and module variations for your fleet and ships. However, from my limited time with the game I also have too many more or less negative points I'd like to list:- Faction differences sometimes seem a bit minor. Pretty much all the races play similarly. Ok, with one race you get bonuses for continuously and constantly winning battles. From another race you can't flee in combat. These are all details though and don't really change the general gameplay completely imho. One exception might be the "Harmony", the race introduced with the addon, who don't use "Dust", one of the resources in the game, and get actually punished for using it. That's a cool concept. Apart from that all other races use exactly the same sort of weapons, modules and ship types. The differences seem mainly in the numbers. Visually the ships look distinct, but they all fulfill the same roles: Corvettes, Destroyers, Cruisers, Battleships and Dreadnought as well as colony ships and fighters/bombers.- The tech trees are too samey. Ties in with the above point. Even though every race HAS some unique technologies, they don't seem that interesting compared to the huge tech tree. I don't feel diverse enough to be honest. Speaking of the gigantic tech tree. This is divided into 4 sections, I wonder, however, why stronger and better ships require research into a completely different tree than military. Basically you can either invest in better ships or better weapons, but of course you also need research from the other 2 sections to make something even halfway worthwhile. I feel it would have been better to more clearly differentiate the trees into: military (ships, weapons, armor, modules), exploration (engines, wormhole travel, scanning, etc.), colonization (how to make different sorts of planets colonizable, how to improve the living conditions on those planets) and planetary improvements (highways, supermarkets, things adding to production of any resource in general).- The "exploitation" mechanic is finicky, if you have to constantly change it for every planet, but can't even see on the overview which planet is being exploited in what way. Maybe I'm just blind.- The fleet battles are generally a mess. These are divided into 3 main sections: long range, medium range and short range. For every section you can choose a "battle card" (more can be unlocked via research or your heroes), the effect of which is totally random, since it can be countered by the enemy fleet. Since nobody knows what cards the opposite faction is playing, this is pure luck and can either win you the game or ♥♥♥♥ you over completely. Not to mention that the game doesn't do a good job of actually explaining what the different ships do, how to properly equip them, etc. There is just no feedback in the game. Suddenly your Dreadnought got destroyed by a cruiser with half health and 4 scouts...SCOUTS!!!! And you have no idea why or how that is even possible. So, that's annoying.That is a problem the game has in spades. Since there is no in game wiki, you have to basically look up everything online. Compare this game to Civ 5, in which you have a progressive (albeit boring) tech tree. You can pretty much look at that for 1 minute and know what you're going to do, since everything has a purpose and leads to the next thing. You can leave tech out and focus on what you want to do...either military or economic or cultural or just plain old money or space race. It's easy to get into. Endless Space's tech tree is just a big mess and a beginner has no idea what a good research route looks like. And that doesn't even include the rest of the gameplay, where your empire suddenly collapses, because you have expanded too much and your people are annoyed, and the tech to pacify them is light years away.So, to conclude: ES is decent enough I guess, if you have the time and dedication to spend at least 50 hours figuring out all its internal mechanisms. I hope ES 2 is more newbie friendly and perhaps introduces the individual races in a sort of "endless" campaign like they did with Endless Legend. ES 1 just feels to samey for me to invest more time into it and the combat system is too arbitrary for my taste. I want more variation in ships and weapons. Why does a completely organic race use the same weapons as a fleet from Earth or technologically advanced researchers? Why are beam weapons just laser blasts and not actual beams? At least change the colour of some weapons...and give different races different support craft. Maybe organic suicide bombers. Spore launchers. And also boarding torpedoes. The sky is the limit.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
Too Complicated For My Liking, Steep Learning Curve I'm going to start off by saying this is not a review. This Is a suggestion that you try to find a demo or some way to play the game before you buy it. I have not played this game nearly enough to review it, This could be a really good game, There are certainly solid design ideas and game mechanics but... I'm really doubting that I'll be able to get into it. Allow me to explain. In a game like civ 5, my experience has been that while there is strategic depth to be had, its not forced on you. I was able to pick up the concepts of civ 5 fairly quick, and I didn't have the feeling that I needed to understand everything to play the game. This game was precisely the opposite. I was so completely overwhelmed in the tutorial by the sheer number of screens, boxes, information tabs, icons, phases, etc, that I quit the game out of frustration because I felt like I was retaining almost none of the information dumped upon me. Add to that the fact that almost every tab background was the same semi-transparent grey box making them all look fairly similar and the unnessary complication of the  renaming of game concepts like money and resources to things like "dust" and "FIDS", and it's pretty clear to me that there were plenty of things that could have been made so much simpler without any real loss in depth. To fans of the game, Please don't misunderstand me. I'm sure its a terrific game. I wanted to enjoy it as much as anyone else, but I have neither an extraordinary amount of patience nor a fantastic memory, and I feel like one of those things is required to enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
Short version:--If you're expecting Master of Orion 2, skip this title.  Ship designs and combat are lacking, and turns take too long.--If you're expecting Sid Meier's Civilization: In Space, get this title.  There are more likenesses to Civilization than any other game I can think of.Long version:I put over 20 hours into this game, and played three games.  I picked it up after checking the resoundingly positive reviews, hoping it'd be something it wasn't.PROS:-A well made game.  This is not some Flash or iPhone game that got ported.  A lot of work and love was put into its creation.-Diverse techtree and upgrade paths let you pick which way you want to develop.-Multiple win conditions, (even though it eventually veers towards enemy battleships coming to take you down when the game tells on you for being close to victory)CONS:-Steep learning curve, laden with pages upon pages of text in tutorials that overwhelm the new player with information they are unlikely to remember or make use of when it is explained.-Game prone to freezes and crashes.-Game ends before you're ready.  "Oh, you captured MOST of the population.  we'll just take it as read that you won.  Good game!  Have a title screen!"-Nuances of combat can be incredibly frustrating.  "Enemy fleet occupying your system, and you want to make them run?  Attack!  Oh.  They retreated?  That's cool, too.  ... ... but why are they still in my system? >_>"  This can go on for several turns before you figure out what's causing it, or how to stop it.-Combat is too simple, and you don't even get to play it.  You pick three "cards" for three phases of combat, then sit back and watch it play out (Or more realistically, Auto through it).-Balance in combat leaves a bit to be desired.  "Pack 9001 beams onto a ship, and use cards that amplify beam efficacy" tends to trump a diversely equipped spaceship.-Race picks for custom races are oddly specific, and awkwardly costed.  "The Price of Beauty" does not automatically spark in my brain "Oh, that must mean "increased ship costs", right?  And the 30 point pick (nearly half your base pick points), Tolerant, is a pick designed to allow for quick expansion before necessary colonizing techs have been researched, but the morale drawbacks quickly overpower that bonus.  However, the 10 point cost "Optimistic" gives a system wide morale bonus, which directly translates into more resources, both early and late.

												Looks pretty. You think 4x, you think dialogues, dramatic events, strange new places. This doesn't have any of that. The research trees don't tell you what stuff does. There is no real way to change your development. The tech trees for weapons don't appear to change anything. Ship combat is reduced to some strange rock paper scissor mechanic that is never explained. I'm assuming to play this the devs expected you to read a large instruction manual, read every technology, and know what space rock, scissor, and paper looks like by instinct. If you wanted Star Control, this is not even close. It is a race to the biggest rock, paper, or scissors of doom. Darned if I care which is which. I got if for a dollar and I still wouldn't recommend this. You play for 3 hours, then the bots crush all your planets, hopes, and dreams in a few turns.Honestly, there are Facebook games with stronger mechanics and tactics. Endless is my disappointment.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Should be called Endless Cr*p or as a friend calls it Endless Boredom. All you do is wait for research and colonize. Tutorial pretty much sux, you just have to learn it as you play.It seems that the AI has unlimited resources and is only interested in fighting you. You have to actually research diplomancy, like cease fire. Only 1 game did I not get my♥♥♥♥♥kicked on easy level. How you supposed to learn a game when the AI just walks all over you constantly.One senario I had 20 systems (every planet colonized), AI had 4 (with 1 or 2 planets colonized) and yet managed to keep up with me in research and it had way more ships then me. Which meant it only builds ships and nothing else. I had the AI blocked in, attacked a planet with my 25 ship fleet (cruisers and battleships)  and then all of a sudden it was pumping out 25 ships (corvets initially,  then cruisers and battleships) per turn. Just walked all over me, since I couldn't keep up in ship production, since my ships take anywhere from 4-20 turns to build, depending on improvements. I did manage to capture 1 system, and yet it had no improvments at all.I also don't like how you capture systems, evey ship can be used to capture a system. You don't have troops, bombs or anything like that. Just move a ship into a enemy system and it can capture it. Ofcourse the bigger the fleet, that faster it can capture a system. I had ships defending a neutral system, meaning any enemy ship entering that system was supposed to be attack immediately. Yet that didn't happen, AI just shot right past them. Didn't even notice it until it was too late.I should mention that everyone has exactly the same research options. There's no unique research for different races.Even though systems have multiple planets, you only build as a system. Six planets and you can still only build as a system, why even have multiple planets in a system if you can't build individualy on each?THere is  an approval rating, but I can never keep it in the green, no matter how much you try. Frankly I just ignore it, doesn't seem to have any affect on thing. Went 60 turns with a zero approval rating in many of my systems, it didn't slow anything down.Lots of thingss I still don't understand about the game and never will, it just gets boring and it frustrates the sh*t out of you.The most annoying bug in the game is that all of a sudden in every system everything takes 999 turns to build, meaning you will never build anything again. Happens randomly, earilest was on turn 20, latest was on turn 70. I clicked forward a couple of turn to see if it clears up, it didn't and I quit that game. Haven't been able to complete a game yet.I quit playing this months ago, thought I'd try it and it's still a pile of sh*t.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Fun for 10 hours.Buggy and AI loops creating a milking scenarios. Was winning a game on hard until AI started running fleets into one of my systems. They'd attack and immediately retreat, exausting my fleets moves. Was unable to attack them on the retreat. This meant they could sit siege weapons on the system unharmed; unable to attack them, unable to attack any other fleets.Cynamitics were cool at first. Until you figure out it's the same sequence every time.Ship building is fun in the beginning. But you start to realise how limited your options are. There are only 2 kinds of ships in the end; war ships and siege ships. You can't diversify your war ships because you can't choose who's on the front-line in space. Meaning, the only diversity you'l have in your fleet is between your upgraded units and your older units. Medium range and short range weapons are worthless so load up on medium and short range defense and stack long range attack.The game feels a little spread thin. What is there is good but after 10 hours you feel like you've seen it all.In summary: Very fun in the beginning but eventually loses it's charm. Good buy on a steam 80% off deal but don't buy at full price. With that said, Ill probably play another 5 hours of this.

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Making a well-balanced X4 is really hard.Endless Space gets a lot right -- a rich technology tree, interesting ship equipment options, strategic decisions in a lot of places that fit nicely together at a macroscopic level, and some eye-candy to stick it all together. Yet, it failed to convince me. The story felt too shallow, the worlds too unpersonal, and the interactions with the AI too simple. Most surprisingly, research felt linear and boring, as each new technology was found within 1~2 turns, which took away all the excitement and anticipation.Playing with friends would probably alleviate a lot of these critics. But for single-player, it just didn't work me up like Freeciv. Not a bad game, but not enticing enough for me to recommend.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												I was pretty gungho for a new 4x game. I mean who doesn't love homeworld or sins of a solar empire eh?I bought the early access emporer edition and decided to wait till it became a full release. At the time of writting the expansion/dlc has come out so its been a good while since they've patched issues.I booted up the game and got into playing the United Empire. I was expecting some awesome ship battles and wide colony expansion. I went into the game on easy mode. Since this is a 4x game I thought, like most good 4x games that gameplay would be self intuitive. Turns out I was wrong. First time you enter the game you are greeted by walls of text and diagrams for a "tutorial" You spend the first 50 turns figuring out the game and wondering why your score is miserably behind. 100 turns later you lose to an economic vitory by the computer player to which there is nothing you can do about it. ♥♥♥♥ing lovely for an "easy" mode.The ship battles are lame. The fleets line up and take pop shots at each other with 3 different kinds of weapons. The only in battle abilities come from these cards you play that makes the whole battle feel like rock paper scisors. It offers nothing of the joy that you get from games like homeworld or Sins. You have some customization options but again the game poorly explains that too so you also spend the first 50 turns wondering why the destroyer you just researched is no where to be found. in the end instead of mixed fleets you end up with 2 types of fleets. First one consists of mini missle boats whose objective and sole purpose is to take out the second fleet type. The second fleet type consists of your most high tiered ship armed with as many defenses and singular guns as possible. Nothing else is viable.The few guides I managed to find on this game barely give any point in the right direction. Also it seems that according to the community that the game is very unbalaced and also "anti-human", as in no human race faction is competitve against the other races in any sense. The different races barely offer any true difference in gameplay, just different focuses. If that doesn't turn you off then the diplomacy text boxesthat feel like they were written by a twelve year old will...Finally and what REALLY turned me off is the random events that occur in game that only affect the human player. What's this? A deadly plague that offers you 3 options to go screw yourself with? Ok you think to yourself, if this will hamper me then surely the computer is having a hard time too. 20 turns later the computer is double your score with advanced tech and ships and you got NOTHING. Yep thats balanced...If you want a "good" 4x experience then lok else where. You like the whole "civilization" style? Look elsewhere too. Feel like playing a medocre 4x game? Play this alongside sword of the stars 2 and the other crappy 4x titles. Do yourself a favor and put your time toward better things.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Nice game. Complex, but not that hard-to-master 4X turn-based game like I was expecting for quite some time. The AI is quite challenging, even if plagued with some consistent bug (they still keep invading systems without siege power, AFAIK), and there's a really excellent interface that allows you to quickly manage even a vast space empire. Space combat is quite basic, and very different if compared to Master of Orion 2 (if you don't know what I'm talking about, consider it as the current standard for this kind of games): no more ship direct controlo nor tactical combat, simply choose your tactics and watch the video. This is NOT necessarily bad, mind you: it's a game more focused on strategic empire management than ship micromanagement, and it's quite great at it. Still, you can't shrug off the feeling that MoO2 was more complete and immersive, and that's a shame because ES had every card to strip Master of Orion of his crown.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												If you like 4x games then this one is a solid game, although lacking in character. There are a number of alien races, though most are just different human factions. They each have rich details backstories, and the game continues to give you more snippets of a larger story as it plays out. Combat is atypical, being more of a dice-roll and technology competition than any actual strategy. You design your ships (each race has a series of different ship platforms that range in size and function, but they all look basically the same, which was a disappointment), and then choose 3 "cards". The cards give you bonuses, and can cancel out your opponents 3 cards if  you're lucky, and you can get access to new cards through unlocking technologies. The tech tree is massive and interesting, with detaild lore-filled descriptions of each technology. The game is fun overall, but after a while becomes very bland. Most factions feel very similar to eachother, and with the way invasion and system-capture works, wars can become extremely drawn out affairs. The computer AIs are easily exploited via the diplomacy screen by offering trades that require large ammounts of gold per turn from them in exchange for resoruces or luxuries. They will accept the deal (with a few one-time payments of dust, technology, or whatever else you want), and cancel it the next turn when they can't afford the price, giving you any one-time payments they agreed to for free. The other issue the game suffers from is a lack of clarity. I still haven't figured out what food does, and why I should bother getting more than the bare minimum on my planets, but the technology tree is littered with farming improvements. Compared to games like Masters of Orion II, or Space Empires IV, ES is very pretty and interesting, but a little too much like a spreadsheet rather than a game. If you like 4x you'll enjoy it for a while, but don't spend more than 5 bucks on this one.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Endless Space is quite a fun game too play. If you expect the depth of a Civilisation title you'll better don't get it. But is has some of it within. There is a great tech tree, some neat mechanics and a great Ship Modification System. Playtime of a full set of course depends on how many enemies and which difficulty you choose. I really, really like to give some big props to the Developers, because it's beautifully designed and nice and clean to play. These things really make me want to check out the Endless Dungeons Title from them. So in conclusion; In case you search some turnbased strategy in space and you don't want to get all too deep into the Civilisations thing - get it. The first 30min are preserved to get into the game, but I'm sure almost everyone will actually get into it after these minutes of training. Speaking of training, there is only a textbased Tutorial which covers about 85% of the mechanics basics. But, for me, it was enought to figure out the rest of the gameplay. What is sad, is that the multiplayer (at least the public one) is almost dead. About 2 to max. 3 Games are going on, whenever I log in. So you'd better pick your friends and start a nice game. :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												Endless Space is to the 4X space strategy genre what Civilization is to real time strategy games. An extensive tech tree and custom ship designs leave lots of room for variety, and as the game progresses these factors force changes in tactics to keep players on their toes. The expansion and colonisation system is remarkably good, and even with dozens of worlds to manage the beautifully simple UI ensures it is never a chore. Combat may not be to the taste of everyone, however. A very hands off affair, the player chooses cards to establish their tactics in a three-turn battle, and then it plays out itself. For those who love real-time battles this could be a turn off, for those of us who prefer combat to be less of a distraction it''s a godsend. For me personally, Endless Space has rendered all other 4X games obsolete.

												It takes time, it takes patience, and it takes a willingness to lose. But if you put these 3 key ingrediants into this game it'll start to connect. Aside from very silly game bugs (like having a just-captured system take only one turn to reconquer on either side), there isn't much to complain about. Expect to be a little flustered however, because this game has an intricate tech tree and unique game mechanics. These will leave in the dust a little bit, so start your first game on an easier game setting. But aside from that, this game offers an enriching strategical environment in which you can truly show your guff and mettle on an interstellar level.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												The game has so much potential but falls to the floor on the technical aspect :( I picked up this game hoping it was going to get me back to the feeling of playing Orion, but it left me dissappointed. The game itself is build on the same bricks, pick your prefabricated race or design your own. Colonize first the system you find yourself on, and then expand out to the known universe while building you science, economy and not least your army!But while Orion had a smooth learning curve and an intuitive research grid, Endless Space gives you nothing on which direction you want to go. Just random discoveries that tell you nothing. You want to be able to invade your neighbors? well you have to guess on what research you need. You want to bring down maintenance cost? Good luck. You want to research bombers? Go for it, but unfortunately you will then learn that you haven't researched the resources actually needed to build it....The game might have become enjoyable to play after 4 or 5 runs when you have learned what the various things do, and you can be expected to be able to formulate a strategy. Unfortunately the game then throws you another curveball in that saves after about 100 turns tend to be corrupt, and you then have to restart the game before you actually have learned what you need to make sure the next run will be more fun...Don't buy this game unless you feel like having a discussion about why you feel you have wasted your time and money!

Posted: December 3, 2013
												This game is frustratingly difficult. The problem is that the in-game options available to you are limitlessly deep, but there is almost no supporting information about how to implement those choices into a coherent strategy. The result is that you will be happily playing along thinking you are doing fine, and the the computer will appear out of nowhere and maul you. number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												Endless Space is best summed up as 'Civilization in Space'. Multiple victory types, strategic gameplay, massively stupid AI. But Endless Space somehow manages to do combat even worse than Civ. Think about that for a second: Civ's combat was pretty bad. One unit per square, chunky movement, and penalties for even thinking about building a large, war-minded empire.Endless Space's combat is even worse than that.Every fight is rock-paper-scissors. Literally. Didn't guess the correct defense for your opponent's offense? You lose. Parity of offense and defense? Nothing at all happens. Add to this an annoying, time-consuming "card" system that adds ANOTHER layer of roshambo and you have the most annoying combat system ever encountered in gaming. Combat invariably boils down either to turtling or kamikaze attacks.It can be a fun game and has a unique setting, but if you're looking for any kind of smooth, interesting, or even just functional combat system, you should look elsewhere.Edit after achievement hunting: If you're the type that enjoys getting all the achievements in a game, you'll be dismayed - as I was - to find that Endless Space has many hidden achievements. They are nearly all incredibly difficult to get. Not challenging, mind you. They just take hours and hours of grind, luck, and AI decisions randomly working in your favor. Annoying and not worth the time.

content:

												I'm a big fan of the 4X genre, but not all of them can be a Civilization. In fact, this feels way too much like the disastrous Master of Orion III, a game that spent most of the time playing itself. I didn't feel like I understood the consequences of choices in the game at all, especially technology selection. Despite being able to pick up the basics in a tutorial, it took watching a few community videos to start trying to get the hang of it. In contrast, Galactic Civilizations II was immediately familiar and easy to figure out from my many hours of playing MOO II.If you have the patience to really invest in learning the game, you might be rewarded for it. Personally, I think there's 4X space games much more deserving of your dollars.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Don't waste your money! I don't know why but for some reason, a decent amount of people seem to like the Endless Brand.  I bought both Endless games because of the reviews BUT, like Endless Legend, Endless Space is boring, clunky and just plain uniteresting. If you buy this game, do not expect an epic space battle like the ending of Mass Effect 3. In fact do not expect some sort of control over war affairs that you would expect in a 4X game. While it did provide the 4 "x's", it doesn't offer a complex gameplay that players wanted and expected in a 4X game. Playing this game is like playing a facebook game. It felts like a point and click game. There is no such thing as a micromanagement. What they have is not enough. For example, you can't micromanage your Spaceships apart from making a fleet or "pimping them up". You can't even group up fleets to better defend yourself from a strong enemy. The battle scene is quite sad! You are literally watching a 60 second clip where the ship move to one direction while the other is right behind them.  There is not a lot of options you can choose from during a battle except for selecting "Battle Cards" which if you play the game for quite some time, it gets pretty boring and repititive. The ship design is unimaginative piece of crap. Also, upgrading a ship changes the stats but not the appearance which can really break focus on the game. You may think that since you can pimp your ship that the apperance would look different but that is not the case. The battle animation is lack luster. Like I said, you don't even have any control of the movement of the fleet or try a daring strategy. The planets and systems are quite boring. There is no lore to them and you don't even feel any sort of feeling of belonging towards your empire. If you are looking for a decent sim space/4x game, check out Sins of the Solar Empire.

												Absolutely fantastic 4x turn-based space strategy. Looking for a sequel to Master of Orion?   *THIS*.   Beautifully sculpted, wonderfully ambient.  Graphics, sound, and music are AAA worthy.  The UI approaches perfection.   Fleet battles, cleverly handled in real time, are cinematic while allowing tactical stratagems by playing maneuver "cards":  This keeps multiplayer combat very brisk, allows you to influence tactics, yet lets you sit back and enjoy the 60 sec interactive yet cinematic custcene (detractors, imho, are dead wrong).   Sure, a few oddities, but....No one has gotten this close to space strategy since Microprose in ~1998.   This studio nailed it.

Game feels unfinished and lacking, with no campaign mode and no "endgame" or "lategame" design consideration.WIN CONDITIONS~Game is centered around very strange "win conditions".~If you dont tick all the random "win conditions" off, game will randomly end leaving you feel confused.~Game is balanced around having all these "win conditions" ticked on, as a result the endgame is a big mess as the game is not supposed to go that long.~Having the various "win conditions" ticked on promotes isolated race towards your strategy gameplay. Not really fun.AI~AI is pretty stupid.~Trading with AI is easily exploitable.~AI difficulty, like most games, is just a slidebar which basically gives the AI cheat codes or an unfair advantage.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Speaking as a former gaming journalist and gamer who's had MOO2 installed on every PC he's ever owned since it was published, I don't think people have been fair to this game. It's belongs in the 8s, not the 7s, IMO.As many have said. It's pretty.Something not many have said is that the UI is uncharacteristically strong for the genre, which is something I especially appreciate now that I write UI rather than game reviews for a living.Most importantly, it scratches the MOO itch like nothing else has for me to date . I tried but could never really get into Gal Civ. SoTs was heaps of fun while it lasted but not really a similar enough experience to satisfy the same cravings. More than any other 4X sci-fi game I've played to date, Endless comes closest to the MOO2 experience not because it's trying too hard  as a me-too game, but because deep in the roots of Endless's game design, you can see that its designers really understand a lot of the critical aspects of what made that game fun (and even some of the things it could have done better).There's definitely some stuff that I wish was different of course.For instance, the best terraforming tech is way too far up the tech tree. By the time you've come close to perfecting all of your worlds, the AI will be threatening to clobber you with one of many non-eXterminating victories if you haven't all but stomped it into near oblivion at that point. Enjoying the role of magitech one-climate-world planetologist as much as I have in many games over the years, it bummed me out a little but I haven't tried fiddling with the settings that slow the game's pace down yet.To be fair, however, there's plenty of planet-tinkering to be done and the game takes the stances that there really should be no useless planets. Asteroids bring unique system improvement opportunities. A certain hero gives insanely beefy boosts to gas giants which give the strongest resource boosts per colonist but to a high degree of specialty and with a very low max pop. Barren and volcano worlds suck for the reasons they typically do but can actually boost their specialty resource production higher than more ideal equivalents once a given system can afford the unhappy colonist hit.For the most part, upgrades are system-wide (which makes high world count systems extremely desirable since most resource-boosting improvements are per-colonist) but each planet can also have an "exploitation" built for it which essentially gives an added boost in one of the resource types with additional boosts for specific planet types.Resource balancing is pretty unobtrusive. If one of the four resource units isn't in enough supply you'll notice in the form of things not happening as fast as you would like them to rather than disaster. No food means zero pop growth, rather than starvation, for instance. I'm a little dizzy at times so I appreciate this. I also like that the game won't let you end a turn without research selected as there are a ton of topics and research can move pretty fast.Happiness is the thing you have to really think about or risk being punished for it. Colonists dislike excessive expansion. They can actually get grumpy at you for overpopulation and excessive expansion at the same time (uncanny realism for the human-originating factions, IMO). This effectively eliminates colony-spamming as the one-true-colonizing strategy, making it better to focus not just on quality systems at first but on where you're colonizing them due to the game's zone of influence mechanic, which is basically a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on/flag-planting mechanic where colonies sprout faction territory zones after (arbitrary perhaps, but it works) 30 turns. Zones grow and push each other and you can't colonize inside another faction's  zone, which forces a lot of interesting strategic decisions and requires thinking about colonization rather than Zerging it.I actually like the AI for the most part. The only thing I'm still on the fence about is the fact that a faction will sometimes go to war on you because your score is getting too high. I kind of wish I could turn that off because that makes the AI opponents feel more like simulations of not-very-smart human opponents than simulations of other alien factions but that brings me to a point I really love about the AI. I know that the AI declared war on me for that reason because THE GAME TOLD ME. It's possible the AI will go to war on you for stupid reasons, but never for "no reason" as the most helpful review to date reports. The game tells you why the AI did what it did. All you have to do is read the event report and it usually makes sense.The other thing that's fun about the AI is that it isn't stingey and it knows when to quit.  When an AI faction declares war on you and you immediately start gobbling up its colonies like popcorn it will offer you several systems to get you to stop in the hastily offered surrender agreement. It's a nice change from those cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s trying to hock their antimissile rockets for your Xentronium armor for the 20th time in a game or having to conquer 3/4 of their entire empire before they'll even consider peace.It's still terribly stupid when it comes to evaluating circumstances like the fact that every ship in your considerably smaller armada has 4 layers of kinetic shielding and beam weapons and every ship in its fleets has kinetic weapons and zero beam shielding but I wouldn't have it any other way. Punishing that kind of stupid is fun.Combat and ship design were satisfying enough for me, but could use more nuance and there's essentially no tactics. There are three weapon types that each work best at a certain range/phase of battle. Each has a counter defense. Weapons and defenses can be added in quantity at their respective hardpoints. There are a variety of support and special modules but most serve to add fixed modifiers to that essential formula (fighters and bombers being an exception). So design is really around offense vs. the defense and what the AI is likely to be fielding (hint: mostly kinetic in the early game).Fights consist of setting targeting priorities and special power cards to play for three phases/ranges of battles that can cancel other player's cards out if they're of the right category and then hitting "manual" to watch the fight play it or "auto" if you feel safe not watching a different algorithm sort the battle out, potentially killing ships that would otherwise be nigh impregnable in a watched battle.As I said, satisfying enough and I like the cards better in practice than I did on paper. Hero levelling and tech unlock fairly interesting ones and they won't overturn a major disadvantage. But I prefer gadgets and a wide variety of weaponry with quirks and unique behavior within a given type. There's no clever gyro-destabilizer/tractor beam combos to be had here and absolutely no thought to be put into whether you want the next level of kinetic, beam, or missile weapon because it's just bettter and there's really only one upgrade path for each. I definitely hope we get something more tactical and varied if there's an ES2 as this is one of the few spots I felt the game overstreamlined things.One thing that impressed me on the other hand is the way they handled custom factions. ES has MOO's faction detailed individuality cake (granular stuff like research specialties and other races they liked/hated) and eats MOO2's customization too by giving each of the established factions a faction affinity that's a sort of template of specialized abilities, tech tree options and diplomatic dispositions that are decoupled from a fairly detailed point-buy system and whatever appearance you choose.Any criticism aside, this game is a very solid addition to the genre with a lot of good ideas. It may not have the 1000+ hours longevity like MOO2 has had for me but it might have MOO1's and I fully expect to get a lot of play out of it.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I absolutely love this game! Though it holds some similarities with Spore and the Harmony faction reminds me of the crystal species from Stargate SG-1. If you have a lot of time on your hands or enjoy games that take a long time then this is the game for you. A nice turn based strategy game that gives you a 4 branched skill tree, with every species having their own special skills. Maps can be tiny to huge! I love that you can pick  the type of galaxy you play in and being able to make your own faction. Ship building is very complex though you cant actually design a ship but you can add or remove components to change the function of a ship. Space battles are, in my opinion, really awesome! At the beginning of the encounter you pick a counter measure for each of the 3 phases and then either click Automatic or Manual. Automatic does a quick battle showing health bars and what not. Manual on the other hand goes through a cinematic of the attacking fleet coming out of warp near the defending fleet, and then the battle begins. Some counter measures will cancel the other fleets out and some will allow both to be used. Depending on your faction you have to keep your populations happy or they will go on strike. Many factors such as anomolies on planets, overpopulation, and expanding too fast through out the galaxy all play apart in population happiness.  You can terraform planets to your needs and discover ancient technologies made by the mysterious Endless.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												If you like 4x games then this one is a solid game, although lacking in character. There are a number of alien races, though most are just different human factions. They each have rich details backstories, and the game continues to give you more snippets of a larger story as it plays out. Combat is atypical, being more of a dice-roll and technology competition than any actual strategy. You design your ships (each race has a series of different ship platforms that range in size and function, but they all look basically the same, which was a disappointment), and then choose 3 "cards". The cards give you bonuses, and can cancel out your opponents 3 cards if  you're lucky, and you can get access to new cards through unlocking technologies. The tech tree is massive and interesting, with detaild lore-filled descriptions of each technology. The game is fun overall, but after a while becomes very bland. Most factions feel very similar to eachother, and with the way invasion and system-capture works, wars can become extremely drawn out affairs. The computer AIs are easily exploited via the diplomacy screen by offering trades that require large ammounts of gold per turn from them in exchange for resoruces or luxuries. They will accept the deal (with a few one-time payments of dust, technology, or whatever else you want), and cancel it the next turn when they can't afford the price, giving you any one-time payments they agreed to for free. The other issue the game suffers from is a lack of clarity. I still haven't figured out what food does, and why I should bother getting more than the bare minimum on my planets, but the technology tree is littered with farming improvements. Compared to games like Masters of Orion II, or Space Empires IV, ES is very pretty and interesting, but a little too much like a spreadsheet rather than a game. If you like 4x you'll enjoy it for a while, but don't spend more than 5 bucks on this one.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Endless Space is quite a fun game too play. If you expect the depth of a Civilisation title you'll better don't get it. But is has some of it within. There is a great tech tree, some neat mechanics and a great Ship Modification System. Playtime of a full set of course depends on how many enemies and which difficulty you choose. I really, really like to give some big props to the Developers, because it's beautifully designed and nice and clean to play. These things really make me want to check out the Endless Dungeons Title from them. So in conclusion; In case you search some turnbased strategy in space and you don't want to get all too deep into the Civilisations thing - get it. The first 30min are preserved to get into the game, but I'm sure almost everyone will actually get into it after these minutes of training. Speaking of training, there is only a textbased Tutorial which covers about 85% of the mechanics basics. But, for me, it was enought to figure out the rest of the gameplay. What is sad, is that the multiplayer (at least the public one) is almost dead. About 2 to max. 3 Games are going on, whenever I log in. So you'd better pick your friends and start a nice game. :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												Endless Space is to the 4X space strategy genre what Civilization is to real time strategy games. An extensive tech tree and custom ship designs leave lots of room for variety, and as the game progresses these factors force changes in tactics to keep players on their toes. The expansion and colonisation system is remarkably good, and even with dozens of worlds to manage the beautifully simple UI ensures it is never a chore. Combat may not be to the taste of everyone, however. A very hands off affair, the player chooses cards to establish their tactics in a three-turn battle, and then it plays out itself. For those who love real-time battles this could be a turn off, for those of us who prefer combat to be less of a distraction it''s a godsend. For me personally, Endless Space has rendered all other 4X games obsolete.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is a great 4x game with amazing visuals. It has a unique and simple battle system so anybody new to 4x games will know what to do.Every game you start feels different from the last one, even if you keep to the same setup. Also there is no solid learning curve as there are many possibilities and out comes. Even if you do come across a situation that feels familiar the out come and your position with in the game may lead you down a completely different path than the one you were expecting. This makes every game you play highly unpredictable.The game can be quite difficult and frustrating for beginners, even on easy. The level of weapons tech of your enemies very quickly matches yours if you do not invest in your own weapons technologies during a conflict. This makes the game challenging on every level.After long play the game can get repetitive. Dealing with all your planets on each turn can get complicated and frustrating. You can save on any turn.The game graphics are stunning. The level of detail they have put in, on the planets, the galaxy and the battle scenes are amazing. You can tell they have taken there time to get this game looking good.The sound effects are not quite in the same power of the graphic. However they are simple and effective for this type of game. The sound track is very good and sets the tone of the game well.The controls work very well. You can operate most of the game with just a click of a mouse. You do have the option to name planets and ships which obviously requires a keyboard.I do recommend this game for the amount of detail they have put in to the graphics, storyline and descriptions of technologies. However some players may find it difficult and also after long play you may find it repetitive and frustrating.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Nice game. Complex, but not that hard-to-master 4X turn-based game like I was expecting for quite some time. The AI is quite challenging, even if plagued with some consistent bug (they still keep invading systems without siege power, AFAIK), and there's a really excellent interface that allows you to quickly manage even a vast space empire. Space combat is quite basic, and very different if compared to Master of Orion 2 (if you don't know what I'm talking about, consider it as the current standard for this kind of games): no more ship direct controlo nor tactical combat, simply choose your tactics and watch the video. This is NOT necessarily bad, mind you: it's a game more focused on strategic empire management than ship micromanagement, and it's quite great at it. Still, you can't shrug off the feeling that MoO2 was more complete and immersive, and that's a shame because ES had every card to strip Master of Orion of his crown.

												This game is another classic Turn Baased Strategy Game but does involve some knowledge and what you want to shoot for in the MetaView of the game.You colonize star systems, build structures that enhance your output, and can even terraform the planets to suit your needs.The ability to choose what your armada contains means you can have the same ship 20 different ways to suit your needs.Battles work in a Ro Sham Bo format.  You pick a card which is a particular type then it follows a weapon triangle.  If you lose that does not mean you take a beating but your play is less likely to succeed with the possibility of taking more damage.I prefer to play as the Harmony, which do not have dust, this puts us at a disadvantage of not being able to force rush buildings and such, but is beneficial to many of the other aspects.  Planets can only be taken over with ships with siege damage unless you want to wait 999 turns.  This is not really feasible early on in the game.Overall definitely a quality Turn Based Strategy Game.  10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Pretty much what a 4x game should be.There are only 2 problems with this game.--There should be an option for even bigger galaxies. Play this for a while and you will want HUGGGEEE galaxies, but there just isn't an option for it. They pretty much just max out at Med size.--The other problem is fleet size is based on research tree. You can only have x amount of ships per fleet.  Your neighbors beat you because they researched a technology that allow them to have one extra tiny ship in the battle. And their 1 fleet beat your 12 because fleets can only engage 1 at a time.And that is the part most ridiculous. The game has no kinda tipping point for sheer numbers winning. it's like 2 guys with a machine gun kill 10k guys because they aren't advanced enough to overwhelm them. Even with spoons they would get over whelmed eventually.  Which seems ultra unrealistic.You can literally have 1k ships at a system but will loose because the enemy has a slighter tech advantage so it can deploy more ships in a fleet, and dispose of you, because you can only fight one fleet vs one fleet at a time.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2012
												Never ever before have I felt so damn conflicted about a game. NEVER! Not once in my 20+ years of gaming! Endless Space offers INCREDIBLY deep gameplay elements, from micromanaging an empire of planets with trading routes and various planetary exploitation, to customizing your units down to engine tuning and weapon power, and exploring INSANELY huge tech-trees. It even has some mild elements of humour in it, with jokes about low gravity on planets making kids happy (really, that's what the tooltip says!). But yet, I still feel... put off by the game. There's just SOMETHING about it, something I can't put my finger on, that's making me back away slowly with a questioning stare. Honestly, I don't think I'm capable of reviewing this game properly due to my ambiguous feelings towards it. So, I'm afraid I can't give this one a proper grading, boyos. ?/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												First thing you should know: This game is gonna hurt you. It's gonna make you realize that you're not half as good -quarter as good- as you thought you were. This game is HARD in the way that there are a million factors to consider, and one extra food on turn 10 can mean victory or defeat 200 turns later. It's much easier on the lower difficulties, but if you try to play this on even the Normal setting first time through, you will cry.THAT BEING SAID. This game is also deep and interesting. There are almost a dozen different ways to win, and the AI have individual personalities and act accordingly. Resources make sense, and the UI is very easy to use and understand (once you put in a little effort.)One flaw with the game is that it does have a huge, deep, steep, nearly bottomless learning curve. There are, as I said, a ton of things to learn and consider. However, once that curve is mastered, the game has a ton of replay value. Aside from the dozen different and unique factions, you can design your own, meaning that you can make thousands of different races that all play differently.The universe is variable to the last detail, but even if you have the smallest settings, it's almost impossible to get even remotely close universes across different games, so everything plays out differently. Overall, the only grudges I can hold against the game is the learning curve, and the amount of time needed to invest to master it. This is NOT a game to pick up and play for five minutes a day. But if you've got the inclination and time, this is quite possibly the best 4X game in existence.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2012
												I'm not sure if I am using the phrase 'Indie sleeper hit' correctly, but I do not care. This is in my top 5 games of 2012, and is probably one of my favorites of all time. It combines elements of civilization and Galactic civilizations into one neatly packaged, entertaining game. Those who are not fans of comparatively slow paced strategy games may feel the length of turns at times, but the feeling of reward turn after turn is rewarding. The combat is unique for it's kind, if not intuitive. It can add lengths to turns, but that is it's only detriment. The custom faction bit adds a lot of replayability after you get comfortable with the game, and I have barely touched the online scene. All in all, if you like strategy games, space sims, or any combination of the forementioned games, I HIGHLY reccomend this. The only thing that I can gripe about is it's unforgiving difficulty, and complexity of research. I give this 9 out of 10 corborbs.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2013
												Endless Space is best summed up as 'Civilization in Space'. Multiple victory types, strategic gameplay, massively stupid AI. But Endless Space somehow manages to do combat even worse than Civ. Think about that for a second: Civ's combat was pretty bad. One unit per square, chunky movement, and penalties for even thinking about building a large, war-minded empire.Endless Space's combat is even worse than that.Every fight is rock-paper-scissors. Literally. Didn't guess the correct defense for your opponent's offense? You lose. Parity of offense and defense? Nothing at all happens. Add to this an annoying, time-consuming "card" system that adds ANOTHER layer of roshambo and you have the most annoying combat system ever encountered in gaming. Combat invariably boils down either to turtling or kamikaze attacks.It can be a fun game and has a unique setting, but if you're looking for any kind of smooth, interesting, or even just functional combat system, you should look elsewhere.Edit after achievement hunting: If you're the type that enjoys getting all the achievements in a game, you'll be dismayed - as I was - to find that Endless Space has many hidden achievements. They are nearly all incredibly difficult to get. Not challenging, mind you. They just take hours and hours of grind, luck, and AI decisions randomly working in your favor. Annoying and not worth the time.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Considering I love space games and I played Civilization 5 (with 250+ hours) I believed this would be the next favorite. I was very wrong. I have only played the game a few hours (8 hours) and through one play through but so far it has been dry and quite bulky interface wise. The interface is complicated and the galaxy and graphics are bland. It has a Civilization set up feel to it but about half the complexity, a third of the balance, and even smaller fraction of the fun. The Space battles are interesting the way they are set up but your control is very limited to 3 minor choices and the rest is automatic with luck thrown in. The game seems heavily based on building ships and lots of them. Comparing it to Civilization which after 5 games has balanced everything down to a science, Endless Space seems to be heavily out of BALANCE.Perhaps I did not put enough time into the game but some key disappointing features were:*tech tree seemed pointless*reviews for the game were really high*the game seems overly complex in information wise with little meaning behind it*there is just to much to manage for the game to be fun, felt more like homework at one point when I was setting up all my ships from scratch and by the time i build a fleet I need to do it all overi would petition anyone wanting to buy this game to DEMO it first.If i had to give the game a score:2/5

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												I did not like this game. Theoretically it has everything it takes to make a great strategy game. It's stable and not buggy. What it's missing is colour. Flavour. Spice. Endless Space is, like outer space, boring.The science research is generally pretty boring. Either it adds a point to this or that stat, or lets you build a new building that enhances a stat. There's nothing that feels fun, where you anticipate getting a research item because it opens up cool new possibilities in strategic depth. It's more like, "Oh now my fleets can have 6 ships instead of 5... wow..." Compare and contrast with Master of Orion, where you could have black hole weapons and teleporters, cool stuff that change how the game plays.Combat is worse. There is only one (possibly 2) viable strategy and a dumb card mechanic and super boring non-interactive combat scenes. I started reading something else while the combat scenes were going, because they're so long and uninteresting. As a game design mechanic they have you play cards during the battle. I believe they did this to encourage people to watch the combat, but all it does is force you to sit through the combat if you want to play the game optimally. Bad design. Compare with Master of Magic's highly tactical combat, or Civ 5's simple and quick combat, either style of which is much better.I think Endless Space 2, where they've retooled everything and made it fun, would be great. Endless Space the original, however, I don't recommend.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Endless space is a difficult to learn empire oriented turn based. I've played Civ and Endless Legend but none of that prepared for the confusion I was going to be in when I started playing this game. The concept of being unable to move unless you click on a different system/city was very infuriating. Why? Just why? All the games I've played allowed me to move where I damn pleased within reason. As I played further on I got got even more confused by the concept that the system had planets that allowed me to treat the system as a city. It confused me because I felt like every planet to be an individual city inside the massive city known as the system. Apparently not.After closing the game and giving up on it a good friend of mine finally showed me the ropes of the game. It finally bagan to make sense. Like every other Endless game it took me a bit to grasp of what the hell I was supposed to do. After passing the first hurdle it becomes rewarding with victories and ego inflating expansions to♥♥♥♥♥♥off the AI.What confused me the most initially was the tech tree. Everything was everywhere in 4 categories that took me a complete game to allow my feeble brain comprehend on what's what and how it is useful. The fact you have about 4 ships to unlock it got me a bit confused. As I played more I realised that while some had the same space and general stats they had their unique bonus that can change how you mod your ships. Oh, you have to mod your ships as well as creating them. Because you can unlock it and be unable to build it until you create a blueprint so to speak. Which isn't hard; you just have to remember to do it.AI, for certain factions are ruthless, system hogs and full to the brim of testosterone. Automatons, Sowers, Sophons, Cravers, Sheredyn, Hissho, Horatio, Pilgrims, Amoeba, Harmony, Vaulters. Guess which ones are the most powerful compared to the rest.♥♥♥♥ the United Empire. More like United ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s for the amount of expansion they accomplish.Beware the Automatons. Literally capable of building a mass army in one turn. If you do play this game, a rule you should go by is don't like Harmony and the Cravers gain too much power. In fact kill them as soon as you are able to. Harmony will destroy the currency on systems, Cravers consume planets and make it weaker for anyone else who isn't them. If you want all the resources to mass construct and expand, you don't want their  systems if they get their way. It's a hard game to get a hold of at first. But if you are prepared for the challenge and want a nice game. Get this.8.5

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												This game has one of the most akward layouts from tech trees to system management that I have ever played with and I have played with a lot of them. For example one of the most important things to have a chance to survive at all is increase fleet size. The techs for it are scattered all over the place. Once you finally figure out how to eventually scroll in on the tech tree, instead of having the description right there and easy to see and use, you now have to hover over the specific icon within the description. Meanwhile your so zoomed in that it becomes a pain to just glance over nearby techs you might want to be able to see so you end up wandering around in the zoomed in mode. Some might not care but to me its just tedious and annoying. They need to get rid of the useless and crappy story descricptive nonsense for each tech and make the actually techs easier to read. For crying out loud!Then you get to the system management ... you only have 1 building queve for the entire solor system whether you have 1 planet or 6. You can only make one thing per solor system. I mean seriously why bother to even have planets. They are all so mixed up you can't really build anything useful in most of them anyways. For instance, arid planets earn you dust(so valuable ...) then tundra planets are good at research(who knows why) so you en up half the time with half the planets for one thing and half for the other. So even though you have 5 planets its no more useful than one with 2 planets of the same type. It's just a very poor system design.Ship customization...no not really. Yes, you can swap weapons out and some core components but there is zero difference in apearence. Your battleships will all look the same no matter how you outfit them. I mean how pathetic is that for a game made in this day and age.The battle system ... it's just horrible. Your fleet is not commanded by you but instead you use generic command cards for 3 different battle phases. You will soon find most of them are completely useless since there is very little diveristy in weapons. It's just glorified paper, rock, and scissors.Master of Orion 2 made in 1996, that's almost 20 years ago, is head and heals above the quailty of this game. After 20 years of progress this is the best they could put out there? Seriously?!!! They don't even have the right to call themselves  gamemakers with this kind of crap.I strongly, very strongly, recommend that you don't waste your money on this crappy game. The only way people put a positive review fo this game is because they must not have ever played a decent space turn based stradegy game.

content:

												I have played this game again and I changed my thought about it so I will rewrite my review.Endless Space is a strategy game that plays in space. (duhh)Your objective is colonize planets and discover other races and wage war with them.The tutorial is useless and I had to search most things on my phone and that's not what I want, I want to play the damn game!I must say that the graphics are average, sometimes the game looks good, but sometimes it doesn't.Singleplayer:It looks a bit like Civilization 5 but then downgraded...Especially with battles between ships, we all expect Star Wars like battles but instead, you get a cutscene, which is boring.Overall the game is pretty boring and it's just really hard to like the game and believe me, I tried to like it...There is one thing the game does very well and that's the resarch, you have 4 different research types and you kinda need to choose which one you want to concentrate on.Multiplayer:I couldn't find any match, it's totally DEAD!I also want to mention that this game eats RAM for me so if you have 4GB of RAM, you might want to reconsider buying it.Final verdict:The game does some things well, but it's just boring, boring and boring :(I give it a 4/10.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I'm a big fan of the 4X genre, but not all of them can be a Civilization. In fact, this feels way too much like the disastrous Master of Orion III, a game that spent most of the time playing itself. I didn't feel like I understood the consequences of choices in the game at all, especially technology selection. Despite being able to pick up the basics in a tutorial, it took watching a few community videos to start trying to get the hang of it. In contrast, Galactic Civilizations II was immediately familiar and easy to figure out from my many hours of playing MOO II.If you have the patience to really invest in learning the game, you might be rewarded for it. Personally, I think there's 4X space games much more deserving of your dollars.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I've sunk quite a few hours into this game, and I've found it generally entertaining and occassionally genuinely challenging.  Why the negative review then?  The game is really superficial.The AI is a bit dull witted, and the only reason it presents a challenge at higher levels is because it cheats like hell.  You know your devs have phoned it in when the only way to make the game difficult is to penalize the player.  At any difficulty level, there alway seems to be an opponent who will immediately start building up a fleet of warships from Turn 1 so that it can lay the smackdown on you within the first 30 turns, which is incredibly irritating when you're playing a non-martial race.There's not a lot of help available, and the tutorial is totally lacking in substance.  The ability tree overview hasn't been updated since before Disharmony came out, resulting in misinformation that I just find annoying, but would probably frustrate the hell out of your average first time player.  Wording on technologies, abilities, and battle cards is vague and leads to confusion.  I'm still not entirely sure what actual effects some of the battle cards have.  Balancing seems to be an ongoing issue, with 2 races that had to be entirely reengineered because they were bricks from the get-go.And yes, I'm going to kvetch about the Vaulters, because I shouldn't have to purchase another game from a different genre to make the game I already paid for complete.  That's just silly.  Amplitude said the rest of us would get them eventually, when Dungeon of the Endless was released, but that was 9 months ago and the game is still in Beta.  I've already lost my interest in the game, and I doubt it's going to come back because the upgrade cycle appears to have already finished and there's not going to be any further content updates.tldr: Can be fun, but suffers from cheap AI and lack of support.  Generally lacks substance.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I first downloaded endless space because it was on sale for something super low, about a year ago or more. Next thing I know, after creating a booming scientific empire founded on diplomacy and peace (without taking a single military science), I got sick and tired of dying to pirates roaming around my interior and finally just switched direction. We're talking complete right angle here. Worlds which had once been prized for their upholding of human rights were transformed into bleak industryscapes where you work to build warships for your entire life, or are exiled to space. We crushed the pirate dogs. And then we turned to the alliance we worked so hard to build. All races in the galaxy save for one. I declared war on that one, and then left the alliance to fight a war they did not want.  When the loan race proved more cunning than the alliance, I declared war on the alliance and conglomerated an entire civilization all at once. They begged for a cease fire. I said "no". My people cast uneasy looks about one another and wonder internally how they came to be this. I sit back, laugh and revel at how I have 170 hours sank into this game. 10/10 absolutely recommend

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Endless Space is a 4X Strategy game you can choose between a number of races and victory conditions depending on your play style. Like many games of this style you conquer, colonise and generally expand your empire in order to be better than everyone else. I will briefly go through the good and ugly below…Good; Depp strategy elements, with a good amount of micro-management. Nice set of ways to win other than your standard kill everyone else. Nice detailed tech tree. An “ok” diplomacy section with races not always either agreeing with your or out to kill you because you sneezed a nice balance if you like. Like other endless games you have a nice set of heroes with some minor RPG elements. OK’ish graphics and sound/music.Ugly; Tutorial was ok but could have been a little more detailed for those not used to these types of games. A major gripe is the combat which is more akin to a card game or none complicated game of rock/paper/scissors than your typical strategy game. Later on in game micro-management can become very time consuming.Overall I would give it a thumbs up, worth a look on sale maybe not full price considering what you can get nowadays in the same genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												i'm going to be completely honest with this review, when i first got this game and booted it up, i was almost turned off, between the at the time, encumbering ui, and the way it looked, i was about to ask for a refund, but after watching a few youtube videos on it, i figured i would give it another shot, and i am glad i did, as this time, i was not an idiot and i actually read the tutorial, and found out that i love this game! there are a few different races you can choose from, each with a diplomatic alignment, either good or evil, but there is a special race here, one that is going to be an interesting playthrough, this race, is an insect like race, with no goal but to expand and consume all matter of life, ranging from plants to animals/mammals, it reminds me of a race in, i think, mass effect 2 (i think it was 2) but it just goes from colony to colony taking out humans, it reminds me of that race on crack, speaking of crack, this game is like sid meiers civ games on crack, in terms of the combat scenes, its not like the civ games, you can actually move the camera around and get up close and personel with the ships as they fight, all the while choosing actions to do in the 3 ranges, long range, medium range and close range, the actions that you choose are card like, some have a cost while others dont, and the actions differ in types, from offensive to defenseive to engineering, and they have effects on weaponary, shields and armor, among other things. so the combat is not only sexy, but it is also involving more so then the civ games (i'm not knocking the civ games either, i have been a huge fan and still am!) so to sum up this review, this is an amazing 4x game, with quite a deal of depth, but when you first start i highly reconmend reading the tutorial! well worth the money in my honest opinion!
