number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												I have been playing this game on-and-off for quite some time now and conclude that I quite like it. For me, there is a bit too much micromanagement to make it super enjoyable, but is well balanced so that various types of players will still like it.The pros is that the game is beautiful with nice art and spaceships that cool. You can customize your ships extensively to introduce strengths and/or weaknesses to certain weapon types. The tech tree is pretty good with some strategy needed to determine exactly what you are trying to accomplish.The negatives are that the AI is not very good and cheats badly to try to be competitive. You will never have the feeling that you got outmaneuvered militarily and/or diplomatically, just that the 500% resource bonus or whatever will wear you down through attrition. The battle system is also needlessly complex - I understand they probably spent a ton of time building a beautiful real time fighting display, but you have such limited control that it just slows the game down. Even picking "cards" is annoying when the AI spams you with dozens of stacks of ships. I hope things will be improved with Endless Space 2!Also, I did end up buying the DLC that I am torn over. The Harmony are a cool race with much different mechanics, but other than that, I feel that it is not worth the cost. It simply adds even more micro (troops, fighters, etc) to a game that arguably has too much already.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												LOL, this game.  First its a great idea and play routine, but it goes horribly wrong after that point.  The 'retrofit feature seems to only work for the AI, and even when I attempt to use a hero to spy it tells me nothing about what the ships the AI are packing.  What kind of firepower and defenses etc.  However the AI knows this, and in moments retrofits thier entire fleet to thwart your newest fleet creation (EVEN ON NEWBIE MODE).  The AI also apparently does not have to deal with unrest in any form, I say this because they create wave after wave after wave of new ships, thier research speed is incredible (I was fighting ships with 1500+ offensive scores while I was still around 500, IN NEWBIE MODE) and while I was struggling to keep 3 fleets going and dealing with unrest (even PERMA-UNREST on some colonies) the AI just chugs along and steam roles you.  Steam is a great thing these days, lets us gamers have access to a multitude of games ... but STEAM you need to start offering refunds.  I would definetly get a refund on this game as it is right now and a couple others, there's ALOT of junk being sold these days :(

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												My first and favourite 4X. I'd only seen Civ games for years, and didn't really bother playing them. That one got me, and got me really well. My current game (normal galaxy, 5 factions) has lasted 38 intense and pleasing hours so far. It's got a lot of reasons to be so good :Decently challenging AI ? Check.An exhaustive victory conditions set ? Check and doublecheck.Custom factions, maps, rules and units ? Check.A huge and well designed tech tree ? Check.An imaginative and inspiring story universe ? Check. Granted, some of the tech descriptions don't really seem to match their effects, but the writing is excellent (English version). Especially considering Amplitude is French. We aren't exactly aces when it comes to foreign languages.My only complaint would be that the battles and card-set feel kind of bland and repetitive. There is a great need for more variety when it comes to cards. The fighter/bomber mechanic that was introduced in Disharmony really should have been in vanilla ES as an update, if you ask me. Otherwise, go grab it if you haven't already. :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												I own both Endless Legend and Endless Space and they both suffer from the same basic problems ... it's like the developers haven't played 4x games in the past 15 years. They're missing key features that have become key in modern times. No hotkey binding? Come on. Management screens are devoid of crucial information. I still can't seem to find where it shows how much you're paying on maintenance for your fleets. There's a published formula but why can't I see it at a glance?That said, the game is very pretty. The artwork is beautifully done. The gameplay is pretty good, though the AI sucks (which seems to be a consistent theme with this developer ... Endless Legend AI sucks too.) It's playable even on older computers and the storyline is engrossing. The default races are wonderfully done. The technology tree has had a lot of thought put into it and is fascinating just to read through if you're a fan of science fiction. In short, the game is worth playing (especially if you can pick it up on a sale) but it's not as good as even Space Empires IV in terms of a strategic/tactical 4x. I would call it "strategy-lite" in many ways and I don't expect it to have a lot of replayability once I've seen all the events, heroes, and story.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												It's not a bad game but I felt it was very underwhelming... the cheap artsy Civ-5 style (even worse) graphics instead of 3-D representation in many aspects of the game, the abstract and exaggerated but at the same time lifeless foes which make you feel like you're back in some 2000 card game, similarly weird backstory about some old 'endless' civilization that vanished and you find remnants of... or the absence of story with the endless just being an excuse. It's just uninspiring because I have little to empathize with in this lifeless game, and when you actually start thinking about what it actually represents, this is not space at all.. space is not supposed to be a 2-d plane. This is not a legit galaxy exploration game. In a real space exploration game your movement and star positions cannot be constrained to one plane. So it's just a board game with space cosmetics like a civ mod. It's also funny how the huge map has hundreds of stars drawn on the 'galaxy' but only a few select are actually real, and a star cluster according to them can only consist of 5 stars. To understand what I mean, get Mass Effect and look at what a real space atlas is supposed to look like, then look back at your 'huge' Endless Space map and realise how much of a childish game you're playing.p.s. I've played and steamrolled my first game on a huge map with United Empire on normal. I have been reading the enemy is supposed to be a vicious cheater and very difficult even on easier difficulties, but I didn't really find the match very challenging. I just made cheap fleets with nothing but rockets, spat out 5-10 units a turn from one system and just spammed my enemy to death.. won an economic victory because of how long it takes to conquer enemy systems. By the end of the game I was begging for it to end because of this. I'll be trying the higher difficulty now.update: No I can't take this game anymore. It's just bland, boring and eats my time. I'm done with it forever.

												The combat is bad. It's a complicated Rock, Paper, Scissors (lizard, spock?) that is too relient on chance.The AI, militarily, is out of control. If you google search for increasing your fleet size (I just wanted to know what techs to get) a lot of the top articles are people complaining about the drawbacks of the limited fleet sizes and the AI fleets being unreasonably good, even at low levels. My experience with this is enough to make me not want to play again.That said, it has a lot of things going for it. If they had figured out the combat I would spend tons of time with this game.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												A really great space 4X game.  It has a hands-off battle system where the player defines the tactics to be used before the battle begins. Research is split into 4 tech trees, which can be described as economics, industry, expansion, and combat.  Colonization is done at both system-wide and planetary levels, and most of your improvements apply system-wide, with planets constructing specialization structures and terraforming.  The diplomacy system is straight forward and functional, if not exceptionally deep.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I purchased this game under the assumption that it was space Real Time Strategy. It is in a way. If you're looking for more space combat/warfare, I would recommend looking at Homeworld: Remastered. But as it stands, this is more of Civilization in space.My first and only problem is that when you play the game for the first time, the game starts telling you♥♥♥♥♥♥ WAYYYY too much♥♥♥♥♥♥ Every little thing you click on or highlight on the user-interface gives you 2-3 paragraphs to read on what it does. I feel they over-complicated the tutorial as a result, but I'm glad I stuck through it, as what I got was a game that totally surprised me in its addictive nature. The combat may be on rails, but building a space empire sets the story to make the battle unique and epic without actually controlling the battle. The diplomatic side to the AI is lacking and one Race seems to dominate over the others in solo campaigns, but these games are usually intended for online multiplayer experiences, so this shouldn't be an issue if that's what you're looking for.Not happy with the Races to choose from? Make your own. Not happy with the destructive firepower of your destroyers? Change it to your liking. There's hours of content here making it pretty good value for money.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												6/10What a dumb game.  After researching this and another space strategy title I decided to go for this one since it was part of the Steam sale ($7 something so not so much of a loss on this 'investment').  While it has its charm the tech tree and some of the rules related to how to play the game are ridiculous.Say you have 7 ships (destroyers or corvettes, no difference in tonnage so does not matter which - another stupid tech tree option but I digress), and you have an additional group of 7 ships of the same type.  That leaves you with 14 ships right?  NOPE.  You have the enemy show up with 12 ships and they attack the 7 while the other 7 sit in the same star system and watch their comrades in arms get blown to bits without interveneing.  How can this game be rated so high with such an obvious lack of logic in the tech tree is beyond me.  You have to research the ability to put more in your fleet which is completely stupid.  I understand the adminral might not be able to do as well with more ships but then just give a battle penalty or something until he improves or until he researches the required tech, do not just limit ships at 7 or 9 per armada until you research the tech to put more in your fleet, this kills the game.Further where they have stuff in the tech tree is annoying as it forces you to go back and forth between tech areas (the one on the left verses the one on the bottom).The game is not all bad, but compared to the strats of Civilization 4 or 5, Europa Universalis 4, Master of Orion 2, or Space Empires 5, Endless Space is a waste of money.  Space Empires 5 especially was MUCH MUCH BETTER in terms of game mechanics, as of course was Master of Orion 2.  For those really into the space battles and who feel that is why this game is great, check out Sins of a Solar Empire (I think it was Sins, someone feel free to correct me if not and I will figure out which one it was as there is one game where you have space battles VERY similar to Babylon 5 the tv series).  MUCH better firefights...Anyhow I digress.  I still have yet to finish my first game so maybe I will change my mind once I get use to the tech tree (I find it problematic to find anything I want to research as the names for things are not intuiative in my opinion), but honestly I am so disappointed.  Here I was thinking I was finding a diamond in the rough (excuse the cliche) and instead I found a ring missing the diamond, not bad but definitely not as good as it could be, and not as good as many titles that came before it that they could have followed...1st edit: (after 15 hours) - still standing by all my initial statements above...the tech tree setup is horrible, I want to research what I need to bomb my enemies, no civilopedia or anything like you would get in Civilization, and YOUTUBE and guides online do not cover quite a number of my questions at all (some were answered though you have to research a lot).  Went through a period where I was taking 999 turns to research something and though I knew why (random event affecting science), would have been nice to see a countdown on how many more turns I would have to suffer...if you are into games where you want to understand what is going on all the time, this is not it, if you are into games where you need to research a ton online (Europa Universalis) and trial and error and figure out what is going on all the time this is not it either.  You want a game that you are 'flying blind'  in a number of areas for a LONG TIME (15 hours and counting at the moment), than this is it.  I am winning my current game but still I just want to bomb the enemy (yeah yeah I need invasion points more than they do or something like that, where do I even find that, trial and error figuring out how to build something that can bomb or bring invaders, would not be that hard in reality, I got a ship, I got an asteroid belt, they have no ships, I shoot them from the sky with rocks until their cities are in shambles...no option for something like that here, bah...)

												This is solid game exept for one aspect, the random events, they can either make or break a play through and in a strategy game you should either have the randomness at the core, see blood bowl and tabletop warhammmer for good examples of this, or not have it at all, this game has some random event that if it comes up you may as well restart. for example, sometimes you will get a thing come up about pirates and there are no good options no matter what you pick there will be at least one fleet of around 250-300 strength at a valuble or weak point on your empire, dependat on what you pick its either your latest colonised world, you homeworld and one more option that spawns 2 fleets, i cant rember the exact details, the point is you should not have events this devistating be totaly random, earily on this can completely wipe out your empire. if the game added in restrictions as to when certain events come up like the pirate one i mentioned earlier it would be brilliant but things like this are enfuriating, espesialy when your starting out or building a diplomatic empire. basically if you are building a game with randomness then you should place some restrictions on when things can happen, or it can ruin the expirence for some players, from what i've played at conventions the evil within looks to be slipping into the smae trap so i cant blame the developers for this when massive companys like bethesda are making the same mistakes but if you are reading this mr/miss dev, please restrict events that can pop up to only ones you have the means to deal with so unstopable forces beyond your controll dont ♥♥♥♥ the game up, please, this game would be a absoloute gem if you did but things like this are ruining it. anway this turnt a bit rambaly so im going to wrap things up, if you're willing to restart 5, 10, 15 or more times in the hopes that this time you dont get screwed by the randomness then go for it, if you can look past that then you will find a brilliant 4X strategy game, i personaly cant however, it gets in the way of me building a diplomatic and rich empire when i have to pour most of that wealth into my millitary to survive roming bands of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. now i have deffinatly gone on long enough so to close of, restrict randomness please.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												- Too many bugs for a game that has been out for a couple of years. Performance is also an issue on the strategy screen in the late game, on a desktop i7 and a GTX 780.- AI uses a different set of rules than the player. They get to move their units before, after, or during the player's turn. The player can't do the same. This is not challenging, just very VERY annoying because it feels like the game makes up the rules as it goes, and the rules are not intuitive ("I forgot they could do that. Load last save. They can do that too? Ridiculous. Load last save.") For example if you want to assign 3 ships from one fleet to another, you must first remove them from their original fleet, then add them to their new fleet, which are both orbiting the same system. As soon as you remove the 3 ships from the original fleet, the AI will interrupt your turn and attack the original fleet minus the 3 ships. So you need to remember that you need to remove 1 ship first, then assign it to the new fleet, then repeat 2 more times, instead of just moving the 3 ships. The AI rearranges their fleets instantly.- Diplomacy is broken. On hardest difficulty the way to win is to finance your empire and drive your enemies into financial ruin by trading anything against X Gold per Turn. The more money an AI makes the more willing they are to give it to you.The empire building and research tree is mostly well done, altough the finer workings of the expansion penalty are rather unintuitive. This could have been a great game if it had better diplomacy, fewer bugs, and a round robin turn system instead of the abdomination they used instead. If they had also added decent combat it would even have been competition to the 1996 title MoO2, which so far remains unchallenged.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30
												Gather around little ones and I'll tell you a tale of an excentric trillionaire and nasty neighbors. A tale of generousity and betrayal. Allow me to tell you a tale from Endless Space. I started this game with the only race who really seemed appealing. The Horatio. The Horatio are clones, narcissistic clones of the original Horatio who genetically altered himself to create the 'perfect being' and now wants to make the universe more perfect by filling it with himself. Fans of Red Dwarf will suddenly be reminded of the episode in which Rimmer, an equally narcissistic character, did the same thing with Rimmer World. Hilarity ensued.So we start of with a bunch of scout ships being sent in opposite directioins about the ring of the galaxy, eventually encountering the other sentient race who on this occasion were the Vaulters. Now since I've never played this before, I knew nothing of this race and so I promptly left them be. Eventually setting up outposts on wormholes to the east and west of them. Relations were fine at first and trade routes established but trying to appease them proved almost impossible as they appeared to really dislike having neighbors. Eventually I get a request from them asking to open borders. This struck me as odd since they were anything but friendly towards my people. So I declined and carried on learning the finer points of gardening and economics. Then another request to open borders. This time it dawned on me and a big grin formed across my face - I had boxed them into a corner of the galaxy because I had colonized the only two wormholes out. After the 4th declined request to open borders they finally declared war on me and stormed through the wormholes with a moderately impressive fleet. But due to their hampered development they were unable to conquer any planets as their defences were too good. So they blockaded them instead and denied me the profits of those worlds. When I called for a cease fire they didn't return home either, they continued to blockage the systems so a game and cat and mouse ensued as they'd sometimes wander from system to system setting up blockades and I'd move manufacturing around to compensate. After galactic war 3 I finally got sick of them and forced a peace-treaty with a very generous donation of technology and a per round donation of Dust to appease them. Did it work? No. They just couldn't be apeased so the peace turned to a cold war and the cold war turned into outright invasion. Only this time, they'd used my generous donations to create several fleets of impressive power with heroes heading each one of them. Since most of my time had been spent focussing on the sciences and expanding the clone army across the stars my ships were totally unprepared for this. A brutal retreating battle of attrition ensued as fleet after fleet of clones were thrown at this Vaulter Armada created using our own funds. Eventually war ended and I suggested a cease fire - but little did they know I had a plan.With so much invested into the sciences it was easy to suddenly develop ships capable of standing up to this new threat and within next to no time I broke the cease fire and caught all of the Vaulter fleets offguard. When the last one was destroyed I looked to the diplomatic menu, expecting to see the negative consequences of a broken cease fire agreement. What did I see? Bonus points of respect from the Vaulters who were impressed by the might of my new fleet?! Oooo....kayyy.... then.... Suddenly understanding that our neighbors were complete nutcases who loved nothing more than a good fight I promptly dispatched my own fleets to blockade every single one of their planets and suffocated any of their efforts to build anything more impressive than a knife and fork. A scientific victory followed as the Horatio achieved the next plane of digital existance. My only conerns now is that without the need to return to our corporeal worlds the Vaulters are now free again to go rampaging through the galaxy looking for the next good fight.Now then, why was it nessersary to tell you this tale for a review? Well.. because these are the events which took place but it took over 20 hours of gameplay to happen and none of it is as impressive as it sounds. Endless Space literally has you spending most of your time looking at menus. All of the drama described really only happens when you sum up events in your head. It's like reading a book. It's nothing more than a bunch of words and page after page of more and more of them, but with some imagination it becomes alive. Endless Space is like that. It only works with imagination because in reality it looks very, very dull. The learning curve is also incredible as it isn't really clear what you should be doing most of the time and only with some pre-reading of guides are you going to get any enjoyment out of it. Can I recommend it? Not really. I've seen other 4X titles and they really do give you some visual feedback to how your empire is progressing and ES just doesn't really do that. Having more dots on the starmap in your colour just isn't very interesting and doesn't give you that sense of achievement needed to keep you moving forwards. The 'exploration' is limited as you are essentially on-rails due to the cosmic string and wormhole limitations. When you discover new planets there really isn't much variety to what you can find there. Quite often the game falls completely flat as you need to take several turns before you need to do anything else. Numbers are moving behind the scenes but you just don't get the nessersary feedback you need to understand if you have made good choices or bad ones. Maybe ES2 will address these issues and I certainly hope so because there is plenty of potential here for a rewarding experience once some changes are made.(this was a re-review from my previous one done quite some time ago. I gave the game more of a fair chance but still consider it as something I cannot recommend even on discount)

I have tried over and over to complete a game only to get "NullReferenceException:  Object reference not set to an instance of an object" every single time.  That's just sloppy code.  That's not my hardware having issues, thats not my video card driver, it's not DirectX, that's the code.I kept trying to play the game, which I guess is positive.  But the game has serious stability problems and it's all within their code.This wouldnt be so bad if the error wasnt so damn non-specific.  An object not set to an instance of an object?!?  What the ♥♥♥♥ do I do with that?  I've uninstalled, reinstalled, put it on a clean Windows 7 install and the same exact error happens every single time.I can't recommend this game.  I would if I could play it, but its unplayable and you should save your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												- Too many bugs for a game that has been out for a couple of years. Performance is also an issue on the strategy screen in the late game, on a desktop i7 and a GTX 780.- AI uses a different set of rules than the player. They get to move their units before, after, or during the player's turn. The player can't do the same. This is not challenging, just very VERY annoying because it feels like the game makes up the rules as it goes, and the rules are not intuitive ("I forgot they could do that. Load last save. They can do that too? Ridiculous. Load last save.") For example if you want to assign 3 ships from one fleet to another, you must first remove them from their original fleet, then add them to their new fleet, which are both orbiting the same system. As soon as you remove the 3 ships from the original fleet, the AI will interrupt your turn and attack the original fleet minus the 3 ships. So you need to remember that you need to remove 1 ship first, then assign it to the new fleet, then repeat 2 more times, instead of just moving the 3 ships. The AI rearranges their fleets instantly.- Diplomacy is broken. On hardest difficulty the way to win is to finance your empire and drive your enemies into financial ruin by trading anything against X Gold per Turn. The more money an AI makes the more willing they are to give it to you.The empire building and research tree is mostly well done, altough the finer workings of the expansion penalty are rather unintuitive. This could have been a great game if it had better diplomacy, fewer bugs, and a round robin turn system instead of the abdomination they used instead. If they had also added decent combat it would even have been competition to the 1996 title MoO2, which so far remains unchallenged.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30
												Gather around little ones and I'll tell you a tale of an excentric trillionaire and nasty neighbors. A tale of generousity and betrayal. Allow me to tell you a tale from Endless Space. I started this game with the only race who really seemed appealing. The Horatio. The Horatio are clones, narcissistic clones of the original Horatio who genetically altered himself to create the 'perfect being' and now wants to make the universe more perfect by filling it with himself. Fans of Red Dwarf will suddenly be reminded of the episode in which Rimmer, an equally narcissistic character, did the same thing with Rimmer World. Hilarity ensued.So we start of with a bunch of scout ships being sent in opposite directioins about the ring of the galaxy, eventually encountering the other sentient race who on this occasion were the Vaulters. Now since I've never played this before, I knew nothing of this race and so I promptly left them be. Eventually setting up outposts on wormholes to the east and west of them. Relations were fine at first and trade routes established but trying to appease them proved almost impossible as they appeared to really dislike having neighbors. Eventually I get a request from them asking to open borders. This struck me as odd since they were anything but friendly towards my people. So I declined and carried on learning the finer points of gardening and economics. Then another request to open borders. This time it dawned on me and a big grin formed across my face - I had boxed them into a corner of the galaxy because I had colonized the only two wormholes out. After the 4th declined request to open borders they finally declared war on me and stormed through the wormholes with a moderately impressive fleet. But due to their hampered development they were unable to conquer any planets as their defences were too good. So they blockaded them instead and denied me the profits of those worlds. When I called for a cease fire they didn't return home either, they continued to blockage the systems so a game and cat and mouse ensued as they'd sometimes wander from system to system setting up blockades and I'd move manufacturing around to compensate. After galactic war 3 I finally got sick of them and forced a peace-treaty with a very generous donation of technology and a per round donation of Dust to appease them. Did it work? No. They just couldn't be apeased so the peace turned to a cold war and the cold war turned into outright invasion. Only this time, they'd used my generous donations to create several fleets of impressive power with heroes heading each one of them. Since most of my time had been spent focussing on the sciences and expanding the clone army across the stars my ships were totally unprepared for this. A brutal retreating battle of attrition ensued as fleet after fleet of clones were thrown at this Vaulter Armada created using our own funds. Eventually war ended and I suggested a cease fire - but little did they know I had a plan.With so much invested into the sciences it was easy to suddenly develop ships capable of standing up to this new threat and within next to no time I broke the cease fire and caught all of the Vaulter fleets offguard. When the last one was destroyed I looked to the diplomatic menu, expecting to see the negative consequences of a broken cease fire agreement. What did I see? Bonus points of respect from the Vaulters who were impressed by the might of my new fleet?! Oooo....kayyy.... then.... Suddenly understanding that our neighbors were complete nutcases who loved nothing more than a good fight I promptly dispatched my own fleets to blockade every single one of their planets and suffocated any of their efforts to build anything more impressive than a knife and fork. A scientific victory followed as the Horatio achieved the next plane of digital existance. My only conerns now is that without the need to return to our corporeal worlds the Vaulters are now free again to go rampaging through the galaxy looking for the next good fight.Now then, why was it nessersary to tell you this tale for a review? Well.. because these are the events which took place but it took over 20 hours of gameplay to happen and none of it is as impressive as it sounds. Endless Space literally has you spending most of your time looking at menus. All of the drama described really only happens when you sum up events in your head. It's like reading a book. It's nothing more than a bunch of words and page after page of more and more of them, but with some imagination it becomes alive. Endless Space is like that. It only works with imagination because in reality it looks very, very dull. The learning curve is also incredible as it isn't really clear what you should be doing most of the time and only with some pre-reading of guides are you going to get any enjoyment out of it. Can I recommend it? Not really. I've seen other 4X titles and they really do give you some visual feedback to how your empire is progressing and ES just doesn't really do that. Having more dots on the starmap in your colour just isn't very interesting and doesn't give you that sense of achievement needed to keep you moving forwards. The 'exploration' is limited as you are essentially on-rails due to the cosmic string and wormhole limitations. When you discover new planets there really isn't much variety to what you can find there. Quite often the game falls completely flat as you need to take several turns before you need to do anything else. Numbers are moving behind the scenes but you just don't get the nessersary feedback you need to understand if you have made good choices or bad ones. Maybe ES2 will address these issues and I certainly hope so because there is plenty of potential here for a rewarding experience once some changes are made.(this was a re-review from my previous one done quite some time ago. I gave the game more of a fair chance but still consider it as something I cannot recommend even on discount)

												I would say "Civilization... IN SPACE." But it's far more than that. You can create your own custom race with strengths and weaknesses (like building an RPG character), customize your ships part-for-part, explore a HUGE tech tree, and generally not understand most of what's going on until you wiki or google it. A great 4X game to pass the time with that "one more turn..." mentality.Word of warning to anyone coming from Civ 5, though, this is SIGNIFICANTLY harder than that game and even on the lowest difficulty, it is possible to be OBLITERATED by the AI right-quick if you aren't playing in the most optimal way. It can make the game very anti-fun at times...

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												-NEW REVIEW-After lots of research on this game, I won.To start off with, this game is ridiculously hard, even on the easiest difficulty. The AI was still beating me in score. The only reason I won is because the only weakness the AI has on the easiest difficulty is that it has no inhibitions on trading. I won through economic victory by having all of the AI pay me all of their money for nothing in exchange. Not so much of a victory to me.The AI on this game puts no limits on itself when it comes to expansion and production. The "Newbie" difficulty is basically normal difficulty with the exception that the AI loves you after you make peace with them (you start out in a cold war state, in which the AI will invade all of your systems unless you make the AI start on the other side of the map) and that they will just give you free money.I can unfortunately not bring myself to reccomend this game because of the ridiculously hard AI, even though the game is fun to an extent. -OLD REVIEW (I was salty)-So being new to this game I set the difficulty to "Newbie" which states "all you would have to do is just hit the end turn button and you could almost win". I did everything right, built a warship, some improvements, ect, and on this supposedly "newbie" difficulty, I got ƒucking invaded 15 turns in by three warships from another empire and lost. 15 turns in on the easiest ƒucking difficulty. Plus the linear system of movement is annoying, boring, and illogical. So, if you like to play against ridiculously hard and creepishly unpredictable AI and like to take 20 turns to get to a planet 5 star systems away because of the horrid movement system, as well as almost unreadable small text and a terrible UI, this is quite the game for you. I do not recommend this if you are a fan of the Civilization series at all. This was the sole reason I bought the game: to expand my 4x knowledge, and I was completely disappointed at my self at my waste of money that I could've used to buy Beyond Earth. Good day.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												At first this game seemed generic for a 4x, but as I got better the game got more complex. The complexity lies in the design of your empire as a whole. Every development is trading one benefit for another and the degree with which you can fine tune your Empire is pretty insane. The ability to sacrifice one aspect like population growth for researching technology. Getting invaded? In a dozen or so turns you can turn that research oriented empire into a production beast. How about repurposing your battle fleet as an extension of your research? Oh yeah, done in one turn. This game does drop the ball on combat. It's theatrical battles are beautiful and fun to watch, but they don't serve any greater function. The auto-battle button will be worn thin quickly. Also, the AI will instigate war for no reason when you get close to a victory. Then after losing said war, will pretty much all but stop trying. The AI is a very soar loser, I mean that literally. It gets very butt-hurt, very easily.That said, this game does lose a lot of it's appeal playing small maps and/or quick games. For a quick game it loses most of it's appeal. If you're looking for a quick action packed experience, this is about the farthest thing from what you want.If you're looking for a time investing empire manager, then this is worth the money. If you're looking for epic space battles, your enjoyment may be short lived with the exception of a couple of the playable races.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I love Civilization series. Paradox games. Master of Orion. I played them hundreds of hours of 4x strategy games.But I couldn't bring myself to finish a single hour of this one. All the pieces are there, all the usual features, all the buttons you would expect and then some. There sure are a lot of buttons. But it's just bo-ring.It feels like a game recreated by a disgruntled, disinterested team. Piece by piece, they put together this strategy zombie, without having any fun creating it — and believe me, you won't have any fun playing it either. All the pieces are indeed there: there's impossible to pinpoint a singular flaw of this game. Everything works as it's supposed to. But there's no magic. No interesting choices, really. No thrill of exploration, no joy in winning and no sorrow in losing.However, if you're professinal or aspiring game designer, I really advise you to buy and play out the♥♥♥♥♥♥of this game as a case study.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												The main problem with the majority of these 4X space games is that they never feel as if they have any guts to them. By which I mean you select AI opponents which may or may not have some flavour text but they invariably DON'T feel like individual alien races - just a few stats and traits different here and there. Where is the real exploration? The real thrill of encountering a new sentient but strange race? The adventure. It's all very well having varied systems that you slowly dominate with formulaic build patterns but the issue I have with these games is that they always feel just like games. It's like a board game - all tactics and no heart. And this one is no different. Whilst it may well be strategic and tactical it still doesn't feel like you are actually exploring space and for this reason I, personally, can't reccommend it. The whole genre has not really progressed since 1999's Alpha Centauri. After sixteen years one would have expected some kind of tangible progress.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												It is not a bad game, but it isn't a good game either, so I'll give a thumbs down.First of, there is nothing innovative about this game, it basically feels like Civ, but in space, with some weird/counterintuitive mechanics. For example:The combat is basically autoresolve, but with cards you can play. Those cards buff your fleet or debuff the enemy fleet and different card counter each other, on paper it sounds not bad, basically some sort of rock-paper-scissor system. BUT! There are so many cards and some cards even counter itself, that rock-paper-scissor becomes some weird thing where paper can suddenly counter scissors and rocks are a stupid thing to use agains scissors.Another thing is restricted fleet sizes. You can up the fleet size through techs to 22 Points (different ships use different set of points, for example Battleships use 2 Points, Dreadnoughts use initally 4, after a techupgrade 3). This leads to:a) rushing the techs for bigger fleets (Most of the time Bigger Fleet > Smaller Fleet)b) Quality of Ships > Quantity of Ships (Point a is still valid, but you can't zerg a superior ship with 20-30 Ships)Overall I would recommend rather to play Sword of the Stars (The first one, not the second), instead of this game.Good Points of this game are:Somewhat pretty graphicsEasy to get into/Hard to master (mainly because many things are somewhat explained poorly)Nice Lore (All the alien races are somewhat interesting)

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Beneath it's shiny surface lays a game that is ultimately frustrating. The setting, while never adequately explained, revolves around the idea that there are all these races developing in the wake of the ever-mysterious "Endless." A sterile user-interface, unsatisfying combat, lack of customizability, and a limited range of graphics often make this game feel soulless. Rather than feeling free to explore an endless expanse of stars, I more often am updating my building priority queue every time I get a new tech. This is the Excel spreadsheet of space games, I'm sticking with GalCiv 2.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												I've been playing strategy games for a long time now. I started with the famous GalCiv 4x games and decided to get into RTS with Distant Worlds. I've gotten bored with both of them and decided to look for something new. Endless Space EE was one of the games that I picked up during the Autumn Sale, so I didn't spend a lot for it. Although it's 4x, I was willing to delve back into the genre just for something different.I have tried to like this game. I really have. The problem is that I can't get too far into it before I start to encounter a glitch. My ships won't move when I tell them to. I've researched this issue and found out that it's been an on-going thing now since the game first came out.I'm not going to slam the game. But having to quit a game that I JUST LOADED and reload (or even been playing for a bit) is irritating. It's a show-stopper and a deal-breaker for me, especially in light of the fact that the bug has existed for a long time and has never been fixed. Steam overlay is not the problem, since I've only used it ONCE during the several times I've tried to play this game.I'm normally more forgiving when it comes to bugs and glitches. Usually I can find workarounds for them, or just accept them as part of the game play experience. Heck, some bugs can be entertaining. But I can't overlook this one, since it breaks the experience for me.I could go on but I don't want to waste anymore time with this game. If you can tolorate a glitch of this magnitude and the game is on sale, go ahead and give it a try. Otherwise, stay clear of it. Maybe Endless Space 2 will be better...

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												I played Endless Legend before I played Endless Space and I think that more than anything is why I don't care for ES as much. The one aspect that I really enjoy a lot more is the tech, in that it's much bigger and more varied and their is more to change and customize on your ships than the units in EL. That said the tech tree is also a hurdle as you either have to play several starter games to get a feel for it (like almost every other aspect of this game really) or sit and read through dozens of tiny tool tips to figure out what everything does and where you should be focusing your research. I find both games lack in diplomacy a bit. I found Endless Legend's tech tree to be easier to understand and better paced. I felt like I knew where I needed to be at a given point in the game while in Endless Space there is just too much to really know how and where to focus my research, though given enough play throughs I'm sure I'll figure it out.Also, the ability of enemy fleets to just appear in the middle of your empire due to warp jumps is a bit of a strain. It might be an interesting tactical crisis occassionally, but I prefer a game that lets me plan ahead, rather than having to garrison everything.Also just as in EL, the restrictions on army size are annoying, but seem worse here as there doesn't appear to be a way for armies to reenforce one another. So if your enemy has tech giving him a larger fleet size, you either can't fight him, or you have to watch fleet after fleet die just to weaken his fleet enough for one of yours to beat it.Lastly, just as in EL, the tactical battles are a draw back for me. I much prefer the sort of abstracted combat of other 4X style games. I don't need a battle mini-game to drag down an already long and slow genre.Over all, I recommend you go for either Galactic Civ 2, or Endless Legend instead of this. The former because I feel it does space 4x better, and the latter because it's basically a clone of Endless Space that does everything better.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												4/10 at full price. 5/10 on Steam sale.First, consider the source: I am not a huge 4X fan. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind building my empire by exploring, investing in improvements, researching technologies and creating ships. Creating ships to actually fight, but more on this later. Explore, Exploit, Expand and Eliminate are the four elements of this genre, but I believe this game is seriously unbalanced. Explore is okay. You build ships to go out and find planets. You eventually run into wormholes which you need a specific technology to use. You can research to get it, which has a certain interest. The problem is that expanding your empire results in a happiness hit to your people. I found the subjects of my empire becoming progressively more unhappy because of expansion. Okay, I can see that, but it seemed to be impossible to make them happy by investing in their systems by creating improvements, generating more FIDS (food, industry, dust and science-the point system at the heart of the game), or building ships. It made no sense. One of the other reasons they were unhappy was listed as "population overcrowding", but none of the planets were anywhere near their caps. But if one of the pillars of 4X results in a penalty, it kind of wrecks the experience, doesn't it?That said, if one enjoys that sort of thing, i.e. fighting the actual game to figure out how to keep your people happy while researching technologies and actually expanding your realm, then this game is probably going to be for you. The tech tree was kind of neat, but it was very unclear what each technology actually did. Some showed up as system improvements, others were weapon systems and ship types. Others required research in other branches of the tree. Some seemed to have no reason other than spending Science points. I don't mind planning and investing in new tech, but I would like to have a clearer idea of where my return on investment is going to lead.Diplomacy and trade. I never could figure out if the other AI was offering crappy deals or what. I never saw an advantage to trading with the AI. I formed an alliance with the other AI, but to break it when I wanted to expand into its territory, I had to wait 10 turns. Then, I had to wait another 10 turns to declare war. So forget launching a sneak attack or anything like that. Who would want to EVER do that in an empire-building game, right?The so-called combat mode was the worst part of the game. This is a 4x space game, not Pokemon! You set up one of three tactics, Spread Fire, which is every ship firing at every other ship. Nosebreaker, where every ship targets the first ship, and Guillotine where you target the first 1/3 of the other side's ships. You then have an assortment of strategy cards you can play at various points in the "battle." Battle itself is separated into 5 segments The Approach, Long Range, Medium Range, Melee and Results. Nothing happens during Approach and Results. So during 2/5s of the "combat" system, nothing really happens. That is a problem that doesn't really get much better.I have to admit, the individual ships look great, and the animations are slow, but smooth as the camera cuts around the Approach.Then combat starts, and you find that despite the fact that the ships are a mere several ship lengths from one another, the ships can't hit each other! They contain technologies that let them navigate the galaxy. They have thousands of Dust points invested in them, but they make Star Wars Stormtroopers look like Anne Oakley! And it had NOTHING to do with the strategy cards you play as far as I could tell. Even when both ships played Overclock, most of the shots missed at all distances.And the lack of ability to target individual ships is arbitrary and frustrating! My opponent would show up with a behemoth ship that was all Deflectors and Shields escorting other ships that some of which had damage, but there was no way to "target" any other ship. And it was all very repetitive; the ships Approach in the same order each time in orbit around what seems like the same planet. After I got tired of watching the same animations with ships inexplicably missing each other time after time, and ending in draws, I decided to set my formations and strategies ahead of time and let the computer auto resolve the battle. Then, of course, I lost half my fleet!And I kept getting draws. If one craft from either side is left alive, the battle is considered a draw. The ships simply drift, right next to one another during the results phase. Overall, the system is very silly.This system makes the idea of going through the 4x system really repulsive because it takes the "Eliminate" out of the whole system. I want a combat system where movement, formation, offensive and defensive systems, propulsion, ship size and planetary system features allow/require me to formulate my own strategy and fight the battle until one side's ships are destroyed, or they surrender or flee the field.I've played StarDrive 2, Vangard Prophecy and Sid Meyer's Starships. I enjoy the turn based combat from VP where you set the motion movement of the ships based on a balance of Engines, Shields and Weapons and the ship moves into position on the next turn firing as it goes. How you move and the balance of ESW help determine whether you are successful. Unfortunately, there is no Explore, Exploit and Expand to that game.The hex grid board game feel of Starships at the in-system level was also enjoyable requiring you to think how you move, when you fire and what system you use. The battle card system is important, but it doesn't necessarily make or break your tactics. StarDrive simply felt like Gratuitous Space Battles grafted onto Endless Space's 4X system. It needed more tactical movement and targeting options, IMO.The problem is that even after 20 hours in the game; I really have no idea what I should do different the next time. IMO, you should be able to play a game and learn from the outcomes what to do differently to effect the next outcome. For this reason as well as others listed in this review, I really can't recomment this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2013
												Endless space is a 4x (explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate) turn-based strategy game. As any 4x game, you have different victory conditions that you may choose to pursue in order to beat your opponents, be it technological victory,plain domination or whatever your preferred style of play is.The Factions are balanced and nicely done, not only that, you can even create your own faction by selecting positive and negative traits. I like how they all play out differently and each of them has their own story and culture.To make your "civilization" flourish you have to colonize new planets, balance their output of basic resources and collect the luxury resources that help your empire. You can set Taxes, decide what to build in the entire system and specialize the single planets.Every hero has two classes and statistics that help you determine what is his best role, you can place it as a Governor on a system or to command a specific type of fleet. Heroes gain experience and you can choose various skill in a big tree, big enough so I can safely say that even if both players get the same hero (which is impossible in the same game) they might end up with completely different characters.The combat is original. Some hate it, some love it. Me? I personally like it a lot. When two fleets encounter, they engage in a battle consistent of 5 phases (3 of them are combat phases). The Initial phase, where everyone lines up, the Long range phase, the Medium range phase, the Short range phase and the conclusion. In these phases you can give orders and play "cards" that represent tactics (which you can unlock through technology or heroes). Every tactic then has a general group that can counter or be countered by what the enemy plays. I find it a streamlined fun experience, it just gives you the good stuff to do while you watch the battle unfold.The customization of the ships is near perfect imho, you choose the components you want to install, modules, weapons (and at what range), defenses, of course, after first choosing a "frame". After that you name your ship and you can produce it in series. Later, when your technology is better, you might want to Update your old design, you can do that simply and then update any old ship of the same class.The learning curve is so-so, I mean, it's still a 4x game, but it's very easy to learn compared to other ones. I think it has a good balance between accessibility and complexity. You could really say it's easy to learn but hard to master, especially against human foes. The AI is good, but not the best, I would recommend playing it with friends or other people, even if it's just you and another friend with 6 bots.All in all, I recommend this to anyone who likes space sci-fi and 4x games, buy it with the expansion, it's worth it, especially new players coming into the 4x genre. Sword of the Stars players might find this game too casual, then again, I find the SotS series, while great, very demanding, more like a chore than an actual game; that's why I prefer this one.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												The biggest waste of time I ever had.In the short time I played it, I yelled more in frustration then any other game.I disable the tips...I like to play games without tips and just learn as I go,but this game's setup if such ridiculous amounts of garbage, that you pretty much need to have them on so not to completely♥♥♥♥♥yourself at the beginning.First game,started on newbie difficulty since it was my first time playing the game.Sent my starting fleet to the first planet, one ship (the scout) got there before the other,even though they where in the same fleet.There where two pirates, and they destroyed the scout without a problem.I then started over.Second game, also newbie difficulty,I decided to try and make a bigger fleet at the start...There is no way to see how much food or scrap you have...You can see how much research and dust you have, but not food and scrap? Why?But in the fleet page thing where you make you ship setups there wasn't a build button.Which is just ridiculous.To build a ship, you go to a colonized planet, and in the bottom left part of the menu, is where you build your ships.It then takes several turns to make them.Which, I found out each turn is one in game year...It took me 28 turns to build three ships,I then got a event, with the choices,+500 dust,100 xp to weakest hero,50 xp to strongest hero.I didn't have any heroes yet,so I hired all three with the saved dust I had.I then chose the 100 xp for the weakest hero...And not a one of my heroes got a single xp point.They all had 0/10 before and after, so more wasted time.Then after more rage, I assigned one to my fleet, and one to my system,without looking at their stats.I did though and found that I chose the wrong heroes for the job, and tried to switch them out...But I couldn't, I had to wait 6 turns to re-assign my heroes...6 in game years to assign my heroes to new positions...That is utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.This game game me a missive head-ache,so I just un-installed it.If you like overly complicated turn based galactic civilization sims, with garbage interfaces, that you need tips enable to fully understand,then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												For me this game could have been great seeing as it's in space, and is turned based stratergy but soewhere between initial concept and develpment they made some interesting choices. I found the number of races a little disapointing having come out of Civ 5. Admitidally in Civ 5 there is much less to differentiate between each empire except colour and indiidual units but some races seemed a little lazy for example The Terran Empire and A Machine Race share the same ship designs which was annoying for me. I also found the interface anoying and unhelpful. An example of this was when I had amassed several very large fleets of top end ships and decided to declare war. The interface told me my strength was 2nd. Nothing else and no indication of who was the strongest and weakest. Regardless I plowed on and declared war. After some rather poor Rock Paper Scissor combat in some systems (more on that later) I started my invasion, only to find that in my next turn I was being opposed by (in one system) 17 fleets.  This is just an example of how the game refuses to give you important and in depth information like a game such as Civ 5 does. Where you are able to find out your milatary strength against others and are advised on whether you at least stand a chance of winning in a war against an opposing empire. Another problem I have with the interface and general magement is the management of your systems. Again if we use Civ 5 as a comparison, in Civ 5 you are prompted on production in your cities and are once again advised on what to build depending on the direction you are going. Endless Space however desides to do none of this and will gladly let you waste valuable turns not doing anyting in systems making management a chore as I ended up constantly checking my economy screen to see if anthing was bone idle. The game was also rather unhelpful when it came to deciding what to build. Yes a game that holds your hand each step of the way in games like this isn't fun but at least an indication or a sugestion that if your citizen satisfaction is 0% try building these would be nice instead of forcing me to wonder for hours why everyone is striking. Now to the combat, Endless Space bosts a big cinematic battle where from artsy camera shots you can watch your fleets go toe to toe with enemies in epic space battles. Sadly this is not the case, yes you do get to watch as fleets fight each other but your only involvement is through picking 'cards' to use in a rock paper scissors type match. This completely mechanic ruins the combat for me and ruins the game as I watch helplessely while my vastly superior fleet gets destroyed becus their card trumped mine. The other annoying part of the combat is that I was unable to choose which enemy fleet to attack( even when there are 17 of them) which caused more frustration as I find I can't attack the same fleet twice (if I have several fleets and they have several fleets in the same system). This frustration and the combats complete shallowness adds up to make rather boring battles overall. Especially when you compare it to something like Civ 5 which lets you choose who you want to attack AND if your unit is superior to your enemies one you win. Revolutionary! Overall then this game looks good on the surface but on the inside (for me at least) the core is thoroughly rotten. Give this one a miss a miss and if you want a turn based trategy game get Civ 5 its much much better

												This game I've been very up and down about, in terms of opinion. When I first played it I immediately started noticeing problems, such as the terrible tutorial (while thorough is incredibly boring), or all in all the lack of AI communications! As a big total war and civilization fan it was pretty disapointing, but I decided to stick with it and keep trying. As a progressed further and learned things on my own I got to experience a lot more (such as the ability to research more diplomatic negotiations previously unavailable) and also learned of the different ways to manage the economy and exploit certain economic grown (meaning to have your planets be a bit more elite in producing whatever you wish to use it for). I started to have a lot more fun, and although the battles are rather boring (it doesn't allow for interaction during it without the disharmony DLC, which I plan to get) it is still a ton of fun. Don't be like me and try this game for 5 minutes and be aggravated by the lack of content, all it takes is some love and time and plenty is introduced. Especially with the disharmony DLC and the DLC coming out for it, this game is indeed as complicated, and just as fun as Civilization 5 or any of the Total War series and I definately recommend it!

Posted: August 18, 2014
												Could be a great game, if it wasn't for two things:1) The combat system, while it is an interesting approach, in the end tends to boil down to luck, with little real influence on the player side.2) The UI is slow, really really slow. How such an interface can, on a modern quadcore computer, feel like you are stuck knee-deep in a puddle of mud, with an 80 pound backpack on your shoulders, is beyond me. Finishing calculations for a turn takes a good while, even with a very small galaxy and a single opponent. Even moving your fleets, or scrolling the map feels sluggish.If those two things are not a problem for you, give it a spin, as the tech tree is pretty well designed, the races well-balanced and it does have a distinct addictivity to it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I was very much looking forward to a decent modern 4X game. Having very much enjoyed the Master of Orion games and Ascendancy from the DOS days, I was hoping for something new and exciting from the genre. I had tried Galactic Civilizations 2 before and it was clunky, uninspired and unfun, maybe this would be different?This game was completely unfun to play from the beginning. It was very frustrating all around and I couldn't get into the game at all. The star system looks beautiful, I love the way the worlds look and slowly rotate, esp. since you can zoom in on each one... but the UI and game play were not intuitive nor entertaining.The races seemed largely unoriginal, and almost all of them were based on humans, unlike the vastly different races available in Master of Orion and Ascendancy. The tutorials just had popup text over the actual window and only told you what parts of the view port were, not how to use them. Way too much informationation all at once, and not letting you actually poke at any of them while explaining things did not help you figure it out.It took a long time to figure out how to even move ships. I noticed a ship icon next to my home world and couldn't figure out how to tell it to move until I right clicked directly on a system and away a ship went. Right clicking a little bit off just unselected the ship, so I kept thinking I was doing something wrong, and the mouse cursor doesn't change to indicate that the ship would move. Ok... So you right click to move. Except after exploring a nearby system, trying to explore the next star system just doesn't work again (unselecting again), probably because I need some research to be able to travel further from my home world, but I couldn't even figure out what any of the drives did, how to move further, or what was wrong. The game didn't give me a message when I tried to go to nearby stars to tell me why I couldn't go to that one vs this one, it just unselected the movement, like slapping my hand for doing something wrong without saying why. A message saying, "You need Long Distance Space Exploration" or whatever would have gone a long way here. In fact, looking things up in the Wiki and doing searches for this never came up with the information necessary to explore, and I looked all over through the research tree, which was it's own lesson in frustration.The research tree gives minimalistic information in popups, that told you the names of what you could get from the research and some story about that research, but didn't tell you a darned thing about the research itself. And you can't mouse over things in the popups to figure out what the heck they are (though Ascendancy also had this problem). The research tree tells you almost nothing useful, and the names of a lot of things mean nothing.An example: A research you get near the beginning is called "Compact Fusion Reactors". This has the text:"While great leaps forward in fusion technology are on the horizon, the ability to miniaturize and simplify existing fusion technology also provides practical rewards." - Ok... this doesn't tell me much.It says it unlocks "Advanced Magnetics Drive" and "Colonize Arctic". Ok, I get the Colonize one (though who knows why a new Fusion reactor would unlock colonizing arctic worlds), but what the heck does "Advanced Magnetics Drive" do? Does it allow my ships to travel further? Faster? Is it a new module for engines for building new ships? Apparently, it just adds 2 movement speed to all of your ships once you get it. I had to look it up on a Wiki to figure out what it did.The combat system was incredibly confusing from a new player's perspective. I experienced combat on turn 3 with my scout ship up against a couple of pirates... I didn't want to lose my scout ship, so I had all these cards to pick from, so I just picked retreat cause I knew I was going to die otherwise. Then a weird cinematic-ish battle happened where I couldn't tell what was happening at all... and suddenly my ship ran away, back towards my home system. Which is where another pirate was waiting, and this time succeeded in destroying my scout. On turn 4. Great way to learn the game!I never even met up with another race because I couldn't travel very far in the couple of attempts to play, and was so frustrated by the game at this point, I switched back to playing old MS-DOS 4x games again.AddendumThis game is taking many ideas from Master of Orion 2, which I played again after writing this review and could see all the parallels. But MoO2 is intuitive and doesn't require a tutorial, let along a 3rd party guide to play. It came with a book, yes, but even that wasn't necessary because it was easy to just jump into the game having played 4X games before.In MoO2, when you click a ship and then mouse over a star system, it does one of two things. If it is in range of your systems, it draws a green line and gives an ETA for how long it would take to get there. If it is out of range, it draws a red line to it and says how far away it is so you can tell it's too far for your fuel to reach. In ES, there is no indication that the game has a clue there is another system there, no cursor change, no highlight, nothing.In MoO2, when you are presented with the 8 different research trees and which branches you can learn, if you right click on a research, it tells you what it gives you. Right from the beginning, I can right click on "Standard Fuel Cells" and it tells me "Supplies sufficient energy to propel a ship 4 parsecs before refueling." - Ok, I now know exactly what research to work towards if I want to travel further. I don't even know what it says for the correct research in ES, since I could never find it, but I doubt it mentions anything about your ships travelling further from the popup information...I spent almost 2 hours trying to get this game to work for me, and I could not. I'm certain other people pushed themselves through the problems, but to me spending 2 hours and still not even knowing what to do was frustrating.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												To give an idea of the gameplay, it is essentially a civilization clone. It is streamlined and dumbed down to be more accessible to new players.Rather than having a terrain system, each planet comes with it's own perks, making it easier for newcomers to understand the habitation system. The research is presented as a web, which is very easy to understand. The resources are more straightforward. The units are where the game shines, where you are allowed a good amount of customization.What could be so bad about this game, then?- With the simplification of the terrain, the replay value died. Every game you play has a pretty similar feel, whereas you could change the settings of a Civ game and have it go completely differently. After a few games, I feel I've seen all the game has to offer.- With the streamlining of the game, there's not a lot to do. Select options. Expand borders. Sometimes attack. The strategy of the game incorporates no abstract thinking, and you find the key to success is how well you can handle the menus. This is boring.- As I said, customization of units are the best thing about this game. For the first little while, it's fun checking out all the options a ship has. However, especially since a ship has limited stats, the novelty dies off, and you'll wish for pre-sets.- Each battle comes with the option to view a cutscene. You'll want to see this cutscene twice, at most. It's long and boring.This game doesn't do anything that Civ hasn't done better. If you want a similar experience for free, "CivFree" is a pretty similar game. Definitely do not pay $30 for this game that I would bet you would not spend 10 hours on.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												A nice space game with great long-time motivation, as you can see by my playtime of 300+. But it depends on your player-personality. So for me:Pro: A great Tech-tree with great influence. Many and editable factions with influence on the strategy. Good editable random space-systems. I like the battles, you choose tactics for three battle-rounds, the rest is up to your ships, this is different in Endless Legends. Great soundtrack, I would compare it even with the Mass-Effect-Soundtrack. Contra: Well, the AI is very hard, but you can choose your level of difficulty. The diplomacy works, but rather simple.So, welcome on board, Captain.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Rating: 4/10 -- ★★★★☆☆☆☆☆☆Valve: Please change recommendation/review system to use a 10 point star system. Much more accurate than "yes/no".This is even more disappointing than StarDrive.  The reason?  Because this actually had a lot more potential and looked a lot better and the videos were great.The videos draw you in, show a lot of exciting combat.  You know what happens when you play?Tedius research planning.  End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  Build one thing. End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  End turn.  Build one more thing. End turn. (x10).Yep.  You basically just end turn, a lot.  The tutorial is terrible.  It's a picture with text (Ok, an advanced picture with text).  I lost my fleet because the tutorial came up and stopped me from clicking anything, I lost before I could finish reading the large volume of text information, and it canceled it's self so I couldn't finish learning battles.  I tried a manual battle, it sucked.  Auto is the way to go.  Which kinda sucks too.  There are only 3 ship classes you can use, this is after I researched 60% of the military research and 40% of everything else.  It's a really long boring RTS with great graphics with misleading videos to get you to buy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20
												Gave this game around ten hours or so of play and in the end the best thing I can say is I'm glad I bought it on sale for one dollar. The basic theme and systems of the game make sense but there is absolutely zero polish to the game. There are problems here which a decent Q&A testing or even an open Beta testing series would have found and fixed. The game just feels unfinished. Diplomacy is a joke; the diplomacy system in Civ games is better (and that's saying something). The tech tree takes forever to move through in the early game and the different ship classes can all be skipped. Only the final ship class is even worth your time. Space combat is a joke; pick three "cards" to determine your fleets' strategy and then sit back. You can't control or change a thing. Horrible idea, horrible. I won't be continuing to play this game.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												To give an idea of the gameplay, it is essentially a civilization clone. It is streamlined and dumbed down to be more accessible to new players.Rather than having a terrain system, each planet comes with it's own perks, making it easier for newcomers to understand the habitation system. The research is presented as a web, which is very easy to understand. The resources are more straightforward. The units are where the game shines, where you are allowed a good amount of customization.What could be so bad about this game, then?- With the simplification of the terrain, the replay value died. Every game you play has a pretty similar feel, whereas you could change the settings of a Civ game and have it go completely differently. After a few games, I feel I've seen all the game has to offer.- With the streamlining of the game, there's not a lot to do. Select options. Expand borders. Sometimes attack. The strategy of the game incorporates no abstract thinking, and you find the key to success is how well you can handle the menus. This is boring.- As I said, customization of units are the best thing about this game. For the first little while, it's fun checking out all the options a ship has. However, especially since a ship has limited stats, the novelty dies off, and you'll wish for pre-sets.- Each battle comes with the option to view a cutscene. You'll want to see this cutscene twice, at most. It's long and boring.This game doesn't do anything that Civ hasn't done better. If you want a similar experience for free, "CivFree" is a pretty similar game. Definitely do not pay $30 for this game that I would bet you would not spend 10 hours on.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												This is a good 4X game and deceptively addictive. You will lose hours playing it and then want to come back for more, not really knowing why.Pros:-Easy to use menus. Looks slick. -Extreemly customizable. You can set up each game however you want with a crazy amount of options. It's one of the things that greatly helps the replay. -Smart. You have to think and plan ahead. Seriously. Cons:-While the famous tech tree is cool, it is also BS. They basically stripped basic tech from a space faring civ so you have to research simple things. And sometimes a simple piece of tech will require another item to be researched to be fully used. -You will read about how hard it is. It is hard. Very hard. Don't play your first few games on anything other than very easy.

content:
Posted: April 17
												This is a good if shallow space 4x. The UI is probably the best in class. Minimalistic, simple, and intuitive. Each species also ends up playing differently. I also like the random events that happens. It can be frustrating sometimes but freshens up the game.It does come with some big cons though. Ai is nonexistent and the way they compensate is to have them cheat like a mofo. You can have triple your enemy's output and they will still be able to out-supply and out-produce you in a war. The technology tree is also very shallow which basically boils down to bigger values and better upgradesI would recommend 4x and space fans to try it out on a sale or free weekend. It's gone on sale for dirt cheap a couple of times, the latest one being $1

												I really do like this game.  It's like Civ but in space.  The factions give you enough different ways of playing the game to keep it interesting and you can even customize them.  I have a very big problem with it, though.  I have tried playing multiple times with friends and one of us always runs into a game breaking bug before we can finish a game.  We've tried playing through a dozen or so games and we have yet to be able to complete one.  This is unacceptable.  I wouldn't consider buying anything by AMPLITUDE in the future unless I knew it wasn't this poorly made.  They were so close to having a great game.  Try at your own risk.

												A wonderfull game. Full of massive space battles, amazing diplomacy options, and a dazzaling array of other sci-fi acessories. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is a great 4X game.  The UI is very nice, but the art beneth the UI is fairly simplistic.  Deciding where to go in the tech tree is a bit tough when other empires are at war with you.  And it took a bit for me to figure out how to raid planets, basically you must have troops, and the other seige units are just to take out the defenses.  I wish you had more autonomy / control in the detailed battles, like being able to fire the shots yourself.  Instead the detailed battles are just cinematics, with the ability to change the next tactic.  Since you don't know what they will choose anyway, changing the next tactic doesn't really gain you anything unless the battle is evenly matched.  I really like 4X games the first time so I spent quite a few hours on this.  But once I got through the tech tree and beat the game a number of ways, I was ready to move on to a non-4X game.If you like 4X games, you'll probably like this one.  The new things it brings to the table is futuristic technology.  But the gameplay is pretty much the same as any other 4X.
