number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												this game is basically like if your parents bought you every single birthday present ever, and gave them to you all at once, there're just soooo much content. everything, from the shape of the galaxy to the individual perks of your custom race can be changed. and the gameplay is no different. while not as epic or spectacular as games like Civiliation, you'll launch this game, and after a while you'll switch windows to check the time when you realise you've spent the whole day just playing this one game. it engrosses you in a weird way, rather than shoving action and epicness at you, it smothers you with endless amounts of content, and the best part is that very little of the game is hard to understand. One would assume that with so much detail to go into, the menus would be cluttered and getting from one emu to another would be a chore. Nope. the way this game handles it's content is amazing as well. With a few exceptions, I knew what every option and every symbol in the game meant simply by hovering over the icon. The organisation and streamline is amazing as well. everything is exactly where you'd want it to be, because it makes so much sense. I cannot recommend this game enough to you. please, get it if you love 4X games and want to do justice to yourself, I am not disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2012
												Endless Space is a decent 4X game. The races are very diverse and uunique. The skill tree is large yet easy to navigate. The randomness of the galaxy and solar systems allow enough variance that you much constantly adapt strategy. There is no one route to victory. The negatives are combat is about as bland as it can get and very confusing the first few skirmishes. Just acept the fact you will loose almost all encounters in your first play through.  Which isn't that bad, but the deal breaker for me is the fact this game doesn't tell you when a unit still has moves. Say you're at war with another race and you send a fleet around to flank. The move order takes 3 turns to complete, which is outside of your empire and you forget about them. Well they'll just sit there and never make a sound until they are attacked or you happen to move the map to there sector and remember them. I just couldn't play the game like that. I'd get caught up managing systems and tech and realize I hadn't moved a unit for 10 turns.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2012
												4X turn-based strategy with a focus on economy & tactics. The music is very immersive and changes based on where you are in the game (planetary view, shipyard, etc.). Combined with the crisp, clean visuals the devs have found a way to make the sterile menu navigation somehow not boring. Sadly this charm can only last so long since most of the game is spent digging through menus trying to balance your empire on a see-saw. The biggest graphical disappointment is how "flat" the galaxy feels; there are eye-catching planetary views when zoomed into a star but from above it feels like playing a board game. Although there is combat, there is an "Auto" mode that lets you pre-load commands so many battles end up playing themselves. Even with the wealth of tooltips, many basic game features are hard to grasp, such as the seven victory conditions. The devs have been working hard to improve the game but the current tutorial is really barebones and is basically popup screenshots that explain things that the tooltips already show.Endless Space is a highly customizable sandbox in space that offers you many unique ways to conquer the galaxy (or not at all; you can disable all victory conditions). A work in progress worth picking up if you can handle the difficulty and steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Endless Space is one of the better 4X Space games out there. On the surface it’s a lot like the rest of the Master of Orion “clones.” You’ll take control a galactic empire, research new ways to oppress your subjects and exterminate your neighbors, design ships to suit your whims, build great public works projects, and generally act like cartoon Space Nazis. What makes Endless Space a little different is the amount of customization. For instance, there are tons of ways to upgrade the planets in your star systems. Want to turn an Edenic Paradise into frozen tundra planet populated by only a few scientists? Endless Space will let you do that.  I especially like the heroes who can lead your fleets or act as Governors on your planets. They gain xp for their service and can be upgraded in numerous different ways. Maybe you could train one hero to be a magnificent propagandist who just needs a microphone to stave off riots. Or perhaps your hero could focus on raising food production, increasing research output, or being better at blowing up enemy ships.There are some downsides. For instance, I don’t like the combat which sort of plays out like rock, paper, scissors. It really sucks. Also, the tutorial is inadequate.TLDR; It’s interesting if you want to manage a big galactic empire, but combat is disappointing. If you prefer blowing up ships and conquering empires to building them then you should look into something else.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Arguably my favourite 4X game ever. Ever. No but seriously - it's challenging but doesn't cheat - it's complex but not confusing (well, once you understand the resource system) - it's hilarious, smart, and full of some of the more interesting sci-fi races and backstory out there. If you play one 4X game in your life, this should be it :) My one complaint is that it could use a stronger (voiced?) tutorial - but if you give it 30m of initial confusion - you will begin to see why it's awesome :)

												This is a magnificent take on the 4X genre. It's a turn-based empire builder. With a real-time battle system, that has your fleet attacks separated by three different distances. Long range, Medium range, and Short range/Melee. You choose which attacks/strategies you want to use at each distance. I recommend you watch TotalBuiscuits video: WTF is Endless Space for more info. If your a fan of the genre it's a must buy especially if its on sale. ~ Black6Blue

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Very interesting game for fans of strategy gaming. You conquer new planets on a galaxy that you create before tha game start. You will run in to other civilizations. You can be friends or enemies. There is a tech tree that you discover as you progress. You can dedicate your progress to science, money, food or production. You can create technological upgrades for your army in order to build best fighting ships in the galaxy.Dont have anything negative to say about this game. You can watch the full animation of your ships fighting with other ships similar to star wars or star trek. Im a fan of neither, but the ship wars are awesome.Give it a try if you like strategies and space related games.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												The game Beyond Earth/Starships should have been, at least in terms of depth, lore, combat, character styles and replayability. You can dive in at a low difficulty and just play a combat game, or go higher and micromanage planets and moons. Expected to play it for a couple of hours and then get bored, and, well... after playing most races and dozens of galaxies, there's still tons of fun to be had. Faction-specific technologies are whole new playing styles, for a start, instead of a specific improvement/unit. An essential example of how games ought to be, with a tiny footprint, great graphics, and a heavy focus on story.

												A fun little TBS, not very complex, but with just enough depth to become immersed. Plays like a mash of MoO3 and Civ4, with a dash of GalCiv2. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I got this game with the DLC while they were on sale for $7. I thought it looked like a fairly entertaining, outer space turn-based strategy, and honestly wasn't expecting much after looking through the negative reviews. Then, I spent an hour just reading the applied science and military branches of the tech tree in game. And I don't normally care about such detail in a game.Don't listen to the bad reviews. If you like space stuff, strategy and/or turn-based games, or Civilization-style games, you will enjoy Endless Space tremendously. It is a beautiful, surprisingly humorous, addictive, and intense masterpiece. The graphics are very playable even on the lowest settings, but look phenomenal if you can run them at their highest. The universe is interesting and pulls you in. The game is deep, and manages to be very balanced while also keeping every race unique as far as their strengths and weaknesses. The attacking side in battle always starts with a better firing position, forcing the defenderer to take sustained fire for a little while before being able to shoot back at maximum efficacy. That was one thing I didn't like. In fact, the combat system seems bad at first. I wish that players had more direct control over their ships. The combat is nevertheless quite fun once you get used to it, because it has the oppossing sides choose cards to play at each phase, and there is basically a time limit. It has that inexplicable joy that card games like Pokemon have. Due to the factions being well-blanced, the slightest difference can decide the outcome of a battle. As in real life, it is only "safe" to attack when you have a clear advantage.Overall, an amazing game for its genre and worth the price even if you don't get it on sale, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2012
												4X turn-based strategy with a focus on economy & tactics. The music is very immersive and changes based on where you are in the game (planetary view, shipyard, etc.). Combined with the crisp, clean visuals the devs have found a way to make the sterile menu navigation somehow not boring. Sadly this charm can only last so long since most of the game is spent digging through menus trying to balance your empire on a see-saw. The biggest graphical disappointment is how "flat" the galaxy feels; there are eye-catching planetary views when zoomed into a star but from above it feels like playing a board game. Although there is combat, there is an "Auto" mode that lets you pre-load commands so many battles end up playing themselves. Even with the wealth of tooltips, many basic game features are hard to grasp, such as the seven victory conditions. The devs have been working hard to improve the game but the current tutorial is really barebones and is basically popup screenshots that explain things that the tooltips already show.Endless Space is a highly customizable sandbox in space that offers you many unique ways to conquer the galaxy (or not at all; you can disable all victory conditions). A work in progress worth picking up if you can handle the difficulty and steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												OK, but not great.  I came back to play this one again, and found I didn't care for it as much as I had on first impression.The mechanics are ham-fisted and arbitrary.  Metrics like "approval" are illogical in the game context, and simply there to slow down the player's rational march toward victory.  Example: citizens on planet 1 are rioting because you colonized planet 7 in another system.  Why?  There is no rational reason within the fiction of the game.  It is not like overpopulation on a single planet.  And there are actually good logical reasons for people to be proud, like any other civilization in history.  Yet the designers want to slow you down, since you will obviously want to Xpand, which is why you came to play this game.  So you either take the hit to an empire-wide reduction in output, which is self-defeating, or you pause to build expensive infrastructure on every single star system in order to magically make people happier.  Oh, and don't forget that you have to first lengthily research the arbitrary technologies to build the  happy places.There are some interesting features here, but they are overwhelmed by the chores put in place to slow your rational progress down the 4X path.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I love this game.Btw, never mind the low hours on record - I played before outside of Steam, so I know it quite well.Some people compare Endless Space (ES) to the classics of 4X, say, Master or Orion II. I disagree with that comparison, and would say ES occupies a slightly different niche: a complex, but not /quite/ as complex 4X game, very pretty to look at, very good music, and plenty of fun.Compared to MOOII, there's less to optimize, battles are played out faster, per turn you spend less time on giving orders, so I'd say it's overall slightly less complex, and a bit more "casual" -- but not by much.So MOOII (and perhaps: Civ), and Endless Space on the other hand, fulfill two different kind of 4X needs, in my opinion: maximum complexity, but sometimes being a bit dragged out for the former, very enjoyable, easy to jump in and out, but a bit more casual, the latter.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Endless Space is a fine 4X strategy games from a very enthusiastic developer, however it lacks on certain parts and fails to deliver a fully fun experience.Let’s just start by saying that the DLC (disharmony) is a  MUST  for this game since it improves on numerous aspects and gameplay. So either buy it in the bundle (gold edition) on doesn’t at all.The game is not a hardcore space simulation rather than a more casual but fun take on the 4x genera.  It’ fairly simplistic and you don’t have much “tools” in your hand to manage your empire. You will colonize planets to planets with your colony ship, discover and exploit resources, build improvements, creating, customizing and assembling ships until your meet the enemy. Leveling your heroes and deal with Random Events are also a thing, but that’s about it.Combat is similar to Galactic Civilization where you don’t have much “live” impact on the battle. You need to choose a card (representing a battle tactic) and match with the enemy’s card and that’s pretty much it (also you can set formations and attack pattern). The battle will automatically goes on without the player getting involved, and it all comes down on how did you customized the ships and what card you choose.And that’s where the game lacks a bit. Although combat is fun, there is not much variety to go for meaning that there are no special attacks, weapons or tactics (you will discover cards later on, but none of them are OP) that will surely break the enemy. You can only choose kinetic, beam and missile weapons (or combination of the 3), assemble the ship and hope the enemy did not develop defenses against the chosen weapon. I find this a little bit lacking.Another problem is the late game/endgame. Victory conditions are ridiculous for Science and the Invulnerable Empire building victory (Wonder) requires 40-50 turns (so around 170 tops) with massive science and labor points already. The game is TOO LONG for these victory types. The only thing you can go for is Domination and/or Score. But the AI is like a brick spamming ships and improvements like hell and even an easy AI will kick your♥♥♥♥♥ When there is just 1 or 2 AI left you will find yourself in a trench war where everyone is ultra-powered and since there are no special weapons or tactics you cannot break each other. And if you go to war it will be a constant battle for one system since the AI will just spam ships faster than you can defeat his fleet. After some turns combat will be so frequent (you will have 4-5 battle every turn) that you just stop caring and pressing the quick combat button.  This is when you will turn to multiplayer instead. However there is a major flaw/bug in the game which is called the De-synch bug. It turns out when you play with a friend to beat the AI the game will freeze up on random turns and you cannot go forward or back. You need to reload a previous save, hovewer the game will stuck at the same turn. THE END! It’s a pretty much  GAMEBREAKING BUG . I have opened threads and contacted support numerous times but these issues have not been resolved for a long time now and there seems to be no fix for it. Many people suffer from this issue, not just me. (see below the forum thread)http://forums.amplitude-studios.com/showthread.php?47367-End-Turn-Game-Freeze-Stuck-Multiplayer-BUG&p=225289#post225289This bug essentially makes it impossible to play Multiplayer, and sometimes even when you 1v1 will freeze up.-------------------------------------Endless Space is a good 4x game from a pretty much new developer.  I would say even though its flaws I like the game, and did not regret buying and supporting it. The Devs are nice guys, although direct customer service are not their strengths (as mentioned above) Now that Endless Space 2 is announced I hope they listen to the critics and make it a truly awesome game.If you are looking for a decent 4X game with great graphics and you can overlook its limits than you can safely purchase Endless Space. 7/10 Good

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Endless Space is a fairly traditional 4X game.  Colonize, expand, build a fleet, conquer stuff, and so on.  It does have a small twist of a simultanious turn system(aka everyone is taking their turns at once, so someone could lock down one of your fleets by engaging them before you move them and so on).  Some like this, some don't.  I'm fairly neutral about it myself.  While I'm pretty slow about making my decisions, sometimes it's actually helped that I tend to go later in the turn order as I get to see what everyone else is doing and then make my moves accordingly.  Sometimes of course it hurts as an enemy moves somewhere preventing me from doing what I was originally planning.  Graphically it's nothing amazing by today's standards but the graphics are functional.  The game as far as I can tell is mostly bug free.  There was one game breaking bug I came across and I don't know if it's gone(there have been multiple updates since that happened and I've never been in the situation that caused it the first time) where lots of ship stacks from different empires all going into the same spot would cause the space battle warning but wouldn't allow me to actually go into the fight and wouldn't let me end the turn since there was a battle that needed resolution.  It happened in my second game I haven't seen it since and other than that I haven't seen any bugs at all.  I do wish the empires had a bit more variety than they do(other than ship designs they feel a bit too similar to me with one exception) perhaps via having more unique techs than they do but honestly I've had a lot of fun nonetheless.  Outside of empires feeling a bit samey, my only real complaint is the diplomacy system and to be entirely honest I'm at a loss for a game with a good diplomacy system.  Civilization, Galactic Empires, this, none of them seem able to get diplomacy out in such a way that it doesn't feel tacked on.  The AI especially gets really weird about diplomacy at times wanting you to be at a very specific strength or it'll hate you for being too strong or too weak and if someone attacks you it gets pissy about you building a large fleet to fight off the attacker.  I had excellent relations with two AI empires, then the Cravers went genocidal on me forcing me to build a massive fleet to push them back, by the end of our war the other two empires(both Pilgrims) had gone from excellent relations to neutral ones.  On the other hand kudos for them not doing the whole attack, surrender, attack immediately after they surrender stupidity that some other games(Warlock, I'm looking at you) have done.  The Pilgrims never attacked me once the entire game even after ending our alliances and peace treaties.Overall I'd say this is a competent by the numbers 4X game that won't wow you but also won't dissapoint.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Endless Space is a fine 4X strategy games from a very enthusiastic developer, however it lacks on certain parts and fails to deliver a fully fun experience.Let’s just start by saying that the DLC (disharmony) is a  MUST  for this game since it improves on numerous aspects and gameplay. So either buy it in the bundle (gold edition) on doesn’t at all.The game is not a hardcore space simulation rather than a more casual but fun take on the 4x genera.  It’ fairly simplistic and you don’t have much “tools” in your hand to manage your empire. You will colonize planets to planets with your colony ship, discover and exploit resources, build improvements, creating, customizing and assembling ships until your meet the enemy. Leveling your heroes and deal with Random Events are also a thing, but that’s about it.Combat is similar to Galactic Civilization where you don’t have much “live” impact on the battle. You need to choose a card (representing a battle tactic) and match with the enemy’s card and that’s pretty much it (also you can set formations and attack pattern). The battle will automatically goes on without the player getting involved, and it all comes down on how did you customized the ships and what card you choose.And that’s where the game lacks a bit. Although combat is fun, there is not much variety to go for meaning that there are no special attacks, weapons or tactics (you will discover cards later on, but none of them are OP) that will surely break the enemy. You can only choose kinetic, beam and missile weapons (or combination of the 3), assemble the ship and hope the enemy did not develop defenses against the chosen weapon. I find this a little bit lacking.Another problem is the late game/endgame. Victory conditions are ridiculous for Science and the Invulnerable Empire building victory (Wonder) requires 40-50 turns (so around 170 tops) with massive science and labor points already. The game is TOO LONG for these victory types. The only thing you can go for is Domination and/or Score. But the AI is like a brick spamming ships and improvements like hell and even an easy AI will kick your♥♥♥♥♥ When there is just 1 or 2 AI left you will find yourself in a trench war where everyone is ultra-powered and since there are no special weapons or tactics you cannot break each other. And if you go to war it will be a constant battle for one system since the AI will just spam ships faster than you can defeat his fleet. After some turns combat will be so frequent (you will have 4-5 battle every turn) that you just stop caring and pressing the quick combat button.  This is when you will turn to multiplayer instead. However there is a major flaw/bug in the game which is called the De-synch bug. It turns out when you play with a friend to beat the AI the game will freeze up on random turns and you cannot go forward or back. You need to reload a previous save, hovewer the game will stuck at the same turn. THE END! It’s a pretty much  GAMEBREAKING BUG . I have opened threads and contacted support numerous times but these issues have not been resolved for a long time now and there seems to be no fix for it. Many people suffer from this issue, not just me. (see below the forum thread)http://forums.amplitude-studios.com/showthread.php?47367-End-Turn-Game-Freeze-Stuck-Multiplayer-BUG&p=225289#post225289This bug essentially makes it impossible to play Multiplayer, and sometimes even when you 1v1 will freeze up.-------------------------------------Endless Space is a good 4x game from a pretty much new developer.  I would say even though its flaws I like the game, and did not regret buying and supporting it. The Devs are nice guys, although direct customer service are not their strengths (as mentioned above) Now that Endless Space 2 is announced I hope they listen to the critics and make it a truly awesome game.If you are looking for a decent 4X game with great graphics and you can overlook its limits than you can safely purchase Endless Space. 7/10 Good

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Endless Space is a fairly traditional 4X game.  Colonize, expand, build a fleet, conquer stuff, and so on.  It does have a small twist of a simultanious turn system(aka everyone is taking their turns at once, so someone could lock down one of your fleets by engaging them before you move them and so on).  Some like this, some don't.  I'm fairly neutral about it myself.  While I'm pretty slow about making my decisions, sometimes it's actually helped that I tend to go later in the turn order as I get to see what everyone else is doing and then make my moves accordingly.  Sometimes of course it hurts as an enemy moves somewhere preventing me from doing what I was originally planning.  Graphically it's nothing amazing by today's standards but the graphics are functional.  The game as far as I can tell is mostly bug free.  There was one game breaking bug I came across and I don't know if it's gone(there have been multiple updates since that happened and I've never been in the situation that caused it the first time) where lots of ship stacks from different empires all going into the same spot would cause the space battle warning but wouldn't allow me to actually go into the fight and wouldn't let me end the turn since there was a battle that needed resolution.  It happened in my second game I haven't seen it since and other than that I haven't seen any bugs at all.  I do wish the empires had a bit more variety than they do(other than ship designs they feel a bit too similar to me with one exception) perhaps via having more unique techs than they do but honestly I've had a lot of fun nonetheless.  Outside of empires feeling a bit samey, my only real complaint is the diplomacy system and to be entirely honest I'm at a loss for a game with a good diplomacy system.  Civilization, Galactic Empires, this, none of them seem able to get diplomacy out in such a way that it doesn't feel tacked on.  The AI especially gets really weird about diplomacy at times wanting you to be at a very specific strength or it'll hate you for being too strong or too weak and if someone attacks you it gets pissy about you building a large fleet to fight off the attacker.  I had excellent relations with two AI empires, then the Cravers went genocidal on me forcing me to build a massive fleet to push them back, by the end of our war the other two empires(both Pilgrims) had gone from excellent relations to neutral ones.  On the other hand kudos for them not doing the whole attack, surrender, attack immediately after they surrender stupidity that some other games(Warlock, I'm looking at you) have done.  The Pilgrims never attacked me once the entire game even after ending our alliances and peace treaties.Overall I'd say this is a competent by the numbers 4X game that won't wow you but also won't dissapoint.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Note: review only applies to the game with Disharmony DLC; don't bother with the vanilla classic mode.Endless Space is a fine turn-based space 4x, but it's not on the same level as the timeless classics such as MoO2 or GalCiv2. Compared to contemporaries, Endless Space is nowhere as great and deep as Distant Worlds (but boasts vastly superior graphics), way better than Sins of a Solar Empire in terms of vanilla customization and replayability (but not in replayability due to mods and overall depth/lore/flavor), and vastly superior to Sid Meier's turned-based space 4x games.PROS:+ Customizable faction/race (stats/traits-wise, not appearance)+ Customizable ship modules (stats/traits-wise, not appearance)+ Can rename star systems+ Relaxing automated combat; almost no tactical control aside from choosing tactics+ Decent graphics+ Good BGM+ Sleek UI+ Pleasant gameflow IF you know what you're doing+ Large skill trees+ Acceptable amount of planetary/installation customization+ Stats/traits, etc. are mod-friendly+ Decent replayability, though definitely not "endless"+ He is the Horatio. They are the Horatio. Horatio gazes upon the stars and wishes to fill up the galaxies with the most beautiful thing in the universe: Himself. Horatio.CONS:- Pre-chosen number of factions; no emergent factions, such as pre-spacefaring species for enslavement, experiment, worship, etc.- No end-game return of old race/death horde, despite the lore existence of one that features prominently throughout the game- Vanilla faction/race roster lacks distinctiveness, mostly humans and robotics- Automated combat gets old fast, the tactic cards system sounded nice on paper but more often than not is no better than "educated" rock-paper-scissors- Near non-existent tutorial that leads to unnecessarily steeper learning curve; good luck figuring everything out without wiki/faq/forum guidance- Frustratingly opaque game mechanics, despite the sleek-looking UI; confusing/misleading stat descriptions- Suffers the same zero-sum AI mentality that plagues many 4x and grand strategy games: diplomacy is highly unreliable because even the most trusted and friendly ally will backstab and hate the player forever because of Win Conditions- Graphics not moddable, so can't introduce new races or ship skins. Because of this, replayability can drop drastically after a few playthroughs if you don't enjoy the vanilla factions--your mileage may vary- Severe desync issues in multiplayer campaigns that effectively ruined multiplayerOverall, Endless Space is a pretty good space 4x that looks nice and plays well IF you take the time to study the mechanics OUTSIDE of the game... or learn through mistakes and repetition. And no, that's not good game design and polish. Despite all of its flaws, Endless Space is still one of the better contemporary space 4x games out there, just a bit below SoaSE and DW.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Disappointing. Lacking a proper interactive tutorial. Lacking in polish. I don't know what it is about 4x strategy developers these days are thinking when they design their tactical situations, but they are clearly not trying to appeal to me. I don't particularly want minimal involvement with the situation, deciding on an overall strategy and then letting the AI fight it out. I like to be hands-on with my space battles, thank you. Master of Orion always got this - and it's the strategy series that (with the exception of the awful MOO3) everyone tries to live up to. The tutorial is pretty much worthless. It explains all the functions of every screen, but it's intrusive, and provides no hands-on demonstration of what each screen does (apparently you're expected to thoroughly read an understand each instruction it gives before moving on to the next). The game needs a truly interactive tutorial mode. In all, I am quite disappointed in this game. I played it for about 2 hours, and don't plan on playing it one second more.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16
												Got this for 1 buck while it was on Sale.First of all, I started right into Multiplayer and Tried most of the Factions aviable. The "Singleplayer" is basicly a you vs x ai. Nothing else, but thats normal for those kind of Games. Thats why a couple of Friends and me played it. Much more fun that way but the Multiplayer occasianly Crashes for various reasons. No big Deal since the game autosaves everey Round start but still annoying that its somewhat constant. Rougly every 2 to 3 hours the game has a Crash. After every Crash all players had to revalidate the Game data on steam. Didnt mind it the first 10 times, but after playing for a long weekend like an addict it became annoying as well.First of, the game has in My opinion a very shallow combat. You got 3 main weapon types: Kinetic(machine guns), Beams (obviously Lasers PewPew) and Missiles. All those 3 weapons are tooltipped to be for a Special Fighting Range. But guess what, we quickly learned its simply the Best to use Cheap Hulls and load them with as much Kinetic set to long Range. Most battles didnt even came to a Medium Range or Melee combat. So much for that.Also, the ship building is very "uninterresting" for me. You got several hull types, obviously the bigger ones need research, and you just click how many Modules of what kind you want. Fun for the first 5 times but annoying that you need to create your "one use" designs" every game. It felt very repetetive, like the most of this game.Same with the whole economic and exploration stuff, nothing new here. If you ever have played a 4x strategy game, you wont see anything new here. You go and build your Empire with the planets randomly generated in your vicinity, make the best out of them and then go Annihilate your Enemys. There is one major let down here, if you Manage to form an Alliance and destroy everyone else, beside you and your Allies, you still dont Win. Either you Kill your Ally or you go for Scientific Victory, that takes ages to achieve, or... well. You could also win by having the majority of the systems what is somewhat unlikely if you have allies.This game is basicly just a machine that turns your Time into Frustration after you played it a while. Fun at first but becomes Boring, repetetive and uninterresting as you play it. I can only recommend it to Hardcore 4x Fans.

content:
Posted: February 26
												You will spend hours learning this game and once you get into it you'll discover that there isn't much to it. Very much a shadow of traditional 4x games, but also very much a poster child for the problems with modern strategy games having been dumbed down so far in order to appeal to casual gamers that they don't really serve a point. I speculate this is why the documentation is so poor - to keep you from figuring out that you should just return the thing before your two hours run out.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I have attempted several times to replay this game hoping for the best as it was originally hailed as  parallel to the fabled, "Masters of Orion" series but after pre ordering and recieving a half finished program replete with bug after bug into the realm of inplayability, I gave up. Subsequent attempts at replay after following the updates have yielded an unbalanced concoction of simplistic drawing schemes and a half attempt at a technology tree that the computer always outpaces you at. the combat system is completely unteresting using "playing cards" which you unlock more options through research. Prior to the start of a "battle" you can chose 3 cards, 1 for long, middle, and melee range hoping that your card cancels out theirs or at least brings that phase of the battle to a draw. The battles waste several minutes watching terrible camera angles fire pew pew style at a distance in the hopes that you might see an explosion. You can chose to auto battle but it seems these are destined to lose more often than not forcing you to waste your time in the "theater mode battle." Bare in mind you have zero control once the battle has started and the only contribution you gave was the selection of cards at the beginning of the battle in hopes that the odds may be ever in your favor.1/10 and a waste of hard earned money on a half finished concept with little player involvement.

												Another clone of Galactiv Civilizations 1/2/3. I will not return to this game - after almost 18 hours of play. 1) strange diplomacy, lack od spying and dyplomacy options, computer oponents and their AI F**** with war options. You can give everything to oponent ... war will come ! and this is diplomacy ? ONE BIG LOL !! Aliances ... just forget. This game have no diplomacy. Im bored of games in oponent's atack my fraction after lack of space system to colonize. So you may have aliance wiht francion after for example 9 turns ... You are in war with this fraction. Totaly stupid resolution for diplomacy.2) battles on paper ! maybe lot of stuff for ships ... but who cares ? if 90% all stuff is unusable. Even Imperium Galactica 1 have better battle options !!! Ships ... i don't like this desing. Space battles, i don't know - after 15 battles all looks the same. There is no place for tactics, so you may have better ships but you may lose. Like in Civilization I - veteran tank destroyed by milita. Simplified compat for game in such scale is not an resolution. 3) WHO RULES EMPIRE ? !!! ... management system in Master of Orion III was better (and it was Excel like system). Endless space have any management system ? One view option on main page ? This game don't have management system. 4) Research - i like it, it was good, guite nice balanced; forget about funds for science. 5) Building on planets ! ... it is a joke ... you build on system not on planets ! ... ;/ who think about this ? System management and planets management simplified to maximum. You can't even build trade ships and spy ships. 6) Area of game, maps, stars, galaxies ! well it is main positive of this game ! well prepared i really liked it.7) MUSIC ... just turn it of. THIS GAME have the worst MUSIC IN ALL 4X space games !! After 2 hours of contiual play i have to turn it off. 8) Graphics ? Videos ? ... 4/5 after technological victory screen. Overal: 3/8

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Endless Space has a lot of potential, and even lives up to some of it. For instance, if you're looking for some beautiful space battles, you've got 'em. Please don't use them in multiplayer, though. And you've got - count 'em - four tech trees. Of course their interdependencies and documentation leave something to be desired. Ah, and you want a nice game you can play LAN-only. Well, um, no. Simultaneous turn-based play? Yep! Oh, but save often because you will undoubtedly crash. Oh, and save often because you will also likely have saved game corruption. It's a fun game for single-player, and if you keep the pace fast enough you might even finish a small multiplayer round.But this one is less "a diamond in the rough" than it is a chunk of coal that just didn't get enough heat and pressure.

												I played the game for about two hours on doing skirmishes and trying out various things to come to the conclusion that while the game is enjoyable for the most part but fell down in my opinion with the card-based fleet battle and general lack of controll of how your ships moved and preformed in combat. Occasionally, the extra RNG of the cards just made an otherwise winning plan ultimately fail. On the other hand, the planatary management and research were quite streamlined and easy to follow, if slightly simplistic. I would recommend this as a starting point for those just entering the genre, but hard core fans may wish to look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												2-sentence review for solo play : it's not really a bad game in itself, but it lacks any strong points, and thus falls way behind the major titles of the strategy world. About as fun as an excel sheet on start, it got a bit better with time till I noticed the total lack of epic feeling, and the awful repetitiveness of the management.Pros:- <2-min thinking> ... sorry, I'm dry... >_<   Maybe a bit of "1-more-turn" magic, but all turn-based games have it, so can't really be a noticeable proCons:- hard to learn, easy to master (this guy explains it better than me => http://steamcommunity.com/id/jewthanasia/recommended/208140/ )- no real tutorial (there's only on-screen explanation about what the buttons do)- extremely painful tech-tree where you have to read tons of stuff to decide amongst the dozen of choices proposed to you- no exploration feelings, nor any real empowered feeling ; for a 4X, that's a big fail- idiotic battle system based on luck, extremely repetitive without any strategy involvement- visually extremely austere (it feels like you're spending your time looking at spreadsheets with a galaxy screensaver as background)

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I applaud the developer for the creativity they pour in to each and every Endless game that they make.  I just don't feel that the design choices for Endless Space yielded an enjoyable game.  There are so many things about this game that are either completely counterintuitive or are never explained.  My criticism here is the same as for Endless Legend:  if you are going to do something radically different, you really ought to do a better job explaining it to avoid turning away new players.  The tutorial and manual may as well not exist because they are both useless.  They explain all of the things you are immediately able to figure out for yourself and absolutely none of the nonobvious stuff.But even after I figured out how to play properly, I wasn't having fun doing it.  Endless Space just isn't fun for me.  I install it again from time to time hoping my opinion will change (because it is such a neat concept) but it never does.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												This game is not great, in fact in my opinion it isn't even good. I wouldn't say I'm a die-hard 4X player but throughout my life I've put anywhere from 600-700 hours of 4X gaming into my life. Endless Space only accounted 6 hours of that, which is rather small. The reasons behind this are simple, too. 1- The User Interface is horrifying in my personal opinion. The tutorial goes over the majority of it all, however it's just- ugly. Descriptions of tools and buttons are paragraphs long, the colors are dull, and the panels to access key game elements don't stand out, as if they're hiding from you.2- The Music. I didn't have any problems with it at first. The music was unique and entertaining to listen to, for the first 10 minutes or so. Afterwards it's extremely aching to the head. Constant and useless noise echoing through my ears is what I remember of it.3- The Battles. Endless Space is like no other 4X game that I've played. The battles are won by cards and luck, and they're cinematics rather than the player controlling the battle himself, on top of that they get very tedious after the first four or five times. 4- The overall lack of immersion really kills it for me. I'm big on immersion. Whether it be Arma, Stellaris, or even Mario Kart on the Wii, I always want to feel as immersed as I can be. Video games are meant to shift your mind into a new world, with new experiences and activities. Endless Space does not do this, in fact it does the opposite. For me, playing Endless Space wasn't immersive at all. When I played it felt like a chore, me pushing to WANT to enjoy the game. I hate doing that, and it ruins the overall vibes.5- The lacking of any strategy was surprising and a big reason why I haven't clicked the "Play" button on this game since July 2016. I get it, I explore systems with no diversion other than the color of the planets surface and size, colonize any available worlds, and expand. This is natural in any 4X game, yet when I do it in Endless Space I grow, well bored. There is no real reason to choose certain worlds other than their size for maximum population, and when interacting with other nations I feel as if I'm playing Civilization 1. It's the typical bland diplomacy system with a few various options. In the end, you'll almost always go to war with all of the nations anyway, so you might as well forget diplomacy entirely. AS I've said before, the combat system is also extremely dull.6- The map of the game and even the game itself feels dull. I'm not certain how to describe something of this nature other than the fact that it's missing something most other 4X games have. I don't know, maybe replayablility perhaps? Overall, the game works well, and the developers put there time and money into this game, so I'll be nice and recommend it. But in the end, most people won't put more than 50 hours into this game. In fact, haven't even gone over 10 yet.

content:

												Freaking wonderful turn based space 4x.  The development of this game was a lot of fun as the dev's let loose their crazed fans into a forum like atmosphere and let them vote on features the team would work on.  It was a wonderful idea because some things I voted for and wanted are in the game!! it also sucks because some things I wanted and voted for didn't make it.  but it was a good thing because it helped this game become great (and for me it gave me a greater sense of attatchment to the final product I think).  The best UI of all time award from me goes to this game, easy and intuitive I often find my self cussing other games UI's more often after I have played this game. The create your own race feature is nearly flawless.  I only wish more depth in look customization and that there were some way to design our own main abilitiy or choose from a longer list, even if items on said list didn't come from one of the premade races.  Other than that you have a lot of options to make a race just how you like (because of Pax Imperia's greatness I will always love and be extra critical on this feature).  Also a lot of the more recent updates to this game have added very awesome content. All in all "Buy This Game".

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												This is easily one of the best space-themed 4x games out there, and it has a ton of really neat ideas. Sadly, the game falls pretty short in execution (with AI opponents at least). Several in-game systems just don't work in practice. The diplomacy aspect of the game is probably the most aggregious offender of broken mechanics. Computers will violate or end treaties willy-nilly even when it benefits you and hurts them. The computers appear to suffer from mass technology trading (to your detriment) like older Civ games did. Additionally, the game will often kill treaties for nonsensical reasons. On multiple occasions I've had alliances and cooperation aggrements auto-cancelled by the game because I lost a resource, even though the resource was never involved in the trade. Amusingly, this even sometimes happen in error when the game somehow thought I had lost a resource. The combat system initially feels neat; however, it gets tiring quickly. For some bizarre reason the designers thought it would be a good idea to incorporate an arbitrary time limit before you can resolve any combat. It's possible this is some weird technical reason because of simultaneous online/AI play. Regardless, it's dumb; it gets old extremely fast. Additionally, the computer seems to play their combat cards randomly. You can reload and replay the same encounters 10 times and you'll get 10 different sets of cards played by the computer. Often the cards the computer plays makes absolutely no sense. Also, the combat system will often say you have an (often large) advantage with combat, you can counter multiple computer cards, and yet somehow still lose your fleet without killing a single ship. This isn't a rare occurrence; it's frequent. To make matters worse, I've found that the fleet design system seems to work really well if you just let the computer design ships for you based on your best components. When prompted, the computer will always pick one weapon and one defense piece and use only those pieces. Finally, there doesn't appear to be a way to examine the makeup of an enemy fleet until you click the combat button. Once you've clicked that button there's no way to cancel it, which is asinine. The game lacks a true tutorial and instead uses in-line help. Unfortunately, the inline help is shown the very first time you go to any screen, which means you spend the first 30 minutes being bombarded by walls of text only to forget it all an hour or two down the line when you're trying to remember how some advanced mechanics worked (which you didn't have access to when the inline help was going).The game also appears to several necessities that we've come to expect from 4X games (like Civilization). It lacks victory tracking (for you or the enemy) other than some extremely basic percentages that aren't explained and are hidden, an in-game encyclopedia (civlopedia style), advisors to help you when you're just starting out, an online community (there's very basic ones starting up, but they are small), or a mod community. The largest issue I found was that the diplomacy system was extremely shallow and boring. You don't unlock any interesting diplomatic options until several techs into the tree. Once you get them, you'll find that anything sufficiently interesting is missing. There's no way to convince others to go to war, peace doesn't protect your colonies (which makes little to no sense; at least provide a separate option for this), and the game forces you to break your alliance for often trivial, nonsensical reasons.  To top off some failed mechanics, the game has some really obvious and extremely frustrating bugs. My favorites include game screens that are sometimes inaccessible for no discernible reason (spam clicking will sometimes bring them up), buggy math where global % modifiers are applied incorrectly to colonies with negative output (this works both ways amusingly, a negative % modifier and a negative output can cause a positive total output), and some amusing visual bugs where ships and systems will twitch in place. Likely the biggest bugs in the game are those revolving around diplomacy. More than a few times I've had ships get effectively stuck in systems because of an odd confluence of borders, treaties, and ships in orbit defending airspace.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												First off, I'll say that while this isn't a terrible game by any means, there are much better 4X space games out there.The one thing I like about this game that most other space 4X games don't do is heroes. You can recruit and assign heroes to fleets and star systems and the hero will gain experience and level up and provide various bonuses. The graphics are pretty nice as well and the descriptions and the lore are interesting to read.Unfortunately for the rest of the game, other games have pulled off the same mechanics in better ways, but even though this is a newer game it did not learn from the games that came before it.First off, the UI could use some work. Some things are hard to find (and the tutorials don't tell you where everything is so you have to dig around) and some things don't make sense. For example, when a random event happens that generates random anomalies on random planets, it doesn't tell you what planets, you have to manually check all of yours to see.The tech tree is kind of annoying and illogical at times. You start in the middle and can research technologies in 4 independent trees. The thing is, 3 of them have various forms of shield tech but you have to get halfway up in each tree separately to get to that point even though it seems like a basic shield precursor should lead to all those techs. All of the same factions also share the same tech tree which Combat is also a boring automatic numbers game. You can customize your ships, but in reality this customization is pretty limited and all that really matters is the final combat rating. There's a poorly named manual mode which isn't actually manual, it just shows a little cinematic of your ships blowing each other up but otherwise works exactly the same way as automatic resolution. Whoever has the most ships and the highest combat rating wins, there's really no tactics involved.The AI is annoying on any difficulty level. They spam combat ships and will overwhelm beginner players regardless of difficulty, but they're one trick ponies (doesn't matter what civilization) and don't learn from your actions so once you learn how to beat them all the difficulty levels become trivial.All upgrades are built on the system level and their cost doesn't change regardless of how many planets are actually affected by them, so building an upgrade costs the same in a system with 5 planets vs one planet, yet the system with 5 planets gets a much bigger bonus. This illogical behavior is a cornerstone of the game and makes it difficult for me to enjoy. Each system is also limited to a single production queue regardless of the number of planets.Overall, I was disappointed with this game and have a hard time recommending it over the other available 4X space games, especially at the asking price.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												The game is playable and enjoyable up to a certain point and then the limited parameters of the  clumsy tactical combat system lock you into an "Endless" war. Retreating ships cannot be fired upon???? Who came up with that brilliant idea???  The tech tree is almost undecipherable until you play the game a few times and is laced with pedantic and misleading verbiage.  There is very little room for diplomacy and you can't really engage in cloak and dagger shenanigans or black ops  such as assassinations or clandestine raids on outpost systems. There are no orbital battle stations or defensive systems (satellites or mines) which would discourage  multiple incursions into your space and free up your fleets to engage and repel the enemy. While on that subject you should be able to disengage a fleet from a system being besieged in order to protect or relieve another beleaguered fleet or planet. Planetary sieges are extremely boring  since there is no quick way to completely neutralize a planet or system by means of neutron weapons or biological warfare. Planetary defenses are visually nonexistent and dependent on simple variables.  Please note: I've only played this in single player mode so some of my criticisms may or may not apply to the multiplayer version .There's supposed to be a sequel to this game and I hope they improve on the combat, diplomacy, orbital defenses and tech systems in order to make the sequel more immersive and rewarding.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												After playing this for a couple hundred hours, I can now conclusively state that while this was certainly promising as an update to that old classic "Spaceward-ho!", it is actually stupidly broken. The main problem has to do with siege dynamics. You can place as many defenses as you want on a planet, but if the attacker has siege points on their ships wherin marines can land, well, the siege lasts about 2 turns. This rapid mechanic makes the strategy aspect of positioning fleets irrelevant.  I have also tried their other "endless" universe games, and they are also just bad. I don't understand the praise for these games.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												After seeing how many positive reviews Endless Space got and it being on sale, I thought I'd give it a go.  Having played anything from MMO's, turn-based and real-time space games I was quite excited with the whole colonizing aspect of ES and combat looked so cool!  What a disappointment!  Combat is interesting to watch the first handful of times and after that I let the AI take over just to get it over with.  You cannot control your ships, just throw cards at it and see what happens.  The story line starts of being quite interesting, after that it just becomes a bunch of text since it doesn't really have much influence on your gameplay.This is by far one of the most boring games I've ever played.  If you're looking for exciting space combat then this is not the game for you.  Give it a go if you like reading a bunch of meaningless text and throwing stuff in queues and wait how many turns for it to complete so that you can do 1 simple little thing.Utterly disappointed!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Well, I take back everything positive I had said.  Ignore the "peaceful" nature of your enemies.  Ignore the peace treaties, trade treaties and big gap between your borders.  Forget trying to have a big fleet to deter attack, or no fleet so you don't threaten anyone into war.  The AI can populate 20 planets to your 10 (literally), get to a point where it has 30 command points of warships to your 5, can develop troop landing and build invasion ships while you are only half way there and WILL attack you even when you have been at peace since you met.  To cap it all you scamble a fleet together and send it to the system they are attacking.  Does it A)  Take on the invasion fleet that has 6 command points to your 12, or B) attack a sodding scout ship and therefore you loose your homeworld?  Have a guess.  This game can be great, but sometimes it's less fun that putting your hand in a blender, and just as pointless.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I bought it and it's DLC for 66% off during a sale, and then an additional 50% off because I was a Founder for Endless Legend. At first, the game will be overwelming and you'll have no clue what to do. The tutorial available is quite in depth, and took me 20 or so minutes to go through and read all the information available. If you've played Endless Legend, this is just like that but in Space. You colonise and terraform different planets, build and manage fleets, establish trade routes and form diplomatic agreements aswell as going to war, which you have the option of bombing the planet, or sending ground troops. The game has utterly beautiful graphics, and it looks a little like a David Attenborough documentary when you're looking at the planet overview with the graphics set to Fantastic. There's a diverse number of species, ships aswell as different planet types. I love the types that are rich jungles or entirely oceanic as they're great eye candy. Much like Endless Legend, there's wonders that effect your planet/systems outputs (FIDS) for the better or worse. I'd STRONGLY recommend buying this game if you love stuff like Civilization. Games good points:- BEAUTIFUL graphics.- Rich lore (Just like EVERY other Amplitude title). - Vast upgrade tree.- Multitudes of options.- Ability to change a planets geographical layout to your needs.- Several different playable races.- Hundreds, if not thousands of hours of gametime. - Cheap if brought on sale. Games bad points:- Costly if not on sale.- Hard to learn at first, which may be offputting.- Slightly buggy save system, will not allow me to rename my saves. All in all, a strong 9/10.

content:
Posted: February 14
												I liked this game, but the latest version appears to overly cheating, i am invading an empire with 2 planets left both of them undersiege by my fleets, AI keeps spoofing out of nowhere spaceships every turn, even with an excellent hero i can not keep up with the amount of ships a single planet with no special ressources produces, not only the game cheats by pooling ships out of nowhere but my hero constantly keeps failing in using any abilities, the AI also has  a good array of at least 3 heros, there is no way 2 medium planets with no special ressources can maintain 3 heros of level 5-10 and their fleets, AI heros are healed next turn. Myself with my hero 15 and 2 fleets of 7 have to change production to coin making, i got annoyed of this as every game has the same result, there is no mathematical way of winning against an AI with infinite spaceship numbers and no expenses, the only chance is the AI is not as smart as a normal player so in the long run it is possible to kick the AI, but the fact this game AI cheats extremely hardcore just killed my fun and preference for this game.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Got the game free from a friend, started playing it ...seemed ok. but as my game went on, i realized how gay the combat is in this game. It doesnt ever get better either. I love 4x games, but i cant stand this one. Combat is like 5 levels of rock paper scissors. and most levels you cant input during combat. Your enemy has missles? well you need to research flak, then build all your ships on flak, then use the flak defensive manuever (card) during combat and hope your new anti missle ships are there during combat. Oh, well the enemy just used anti flak card, and it countered your anti missle card so you're dead. Now the enemy ships have lasers and bullets? better research shields and armor. I love Civ and Endless legend but this game was super gay the entire time. Very unrewarding in all aspects.What the game tries to do it does right.But it seems like they wanted a 4x with no combat.6/10 at best.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Gave this game an honest chance after playing a disapointing demo when it first came out. The very poor AI is given advantages across the board to compensate, which makes for an ultimately un-enjoyable game. If you win, it will be because the AI is so stupid as to throw its fleets at you a single file. If you lose, it will be because the resource and science advantages the AI get (even on easy difficulties) means that in late game the AI will have an insurmountable advantage.Also the diplomacy options are very limited - even poorer than Civ. Not a disastrous game, but I came to expect better AI and more depth.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												I hated this game.A friend recommended it and kept pushing me to play it with him. We ended up getting a multiplayer game and argh... Boring. I'm not too sure what to say about this game really, if you like turn based titles then this might be worth looking into. I had never played a turn based title before and I found this aspect awful.The races are interesting but you don't really get much of an immersion effect going. The battles are boring, the research tree is uninteresting. The visuals of the map were beautiful, but it's quickly ruined by the fact that your armada must take turns. It felt too board game like, and if I wanted to play a board game I would... on a board. This 90's tradition of plane paper gaming has expired in my opinion, and is only kept up by fanatical nerds who suck at playing more in-time titles. Sorry, truth hurts.Not for me, I would recommend Sins of the Solar Empire with the Star Trek 3 Armada Mod. Much better experience than this game.0/5, garbage.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												This game has everything you would want in a 4x space strategy game.  Except for one key thing that imho is most vital in a 4x strategy game ... the space combat is absolutely, without a doubt, the worst I have ever seen in a 4x strategy game with the possible exception of MOO 3.  Its just a matter of seleting a few 'cards' at the start of the battle and click a button.  Thats it.  No strategy and no real planning.  Just hope you pick the one card that trumps whatever random card the AI happens to pick (If the fleets are evenly matched).  There is no way of possibly guessing or knowing what the enemy will pick based on thier weapon platforms (that I could tell) and ship design.  Might as well close your eyes and pick, its just as effective as anything else you might pick (tested!).  Than click a button and watch the ships slug it out (no fleet control) and cross your fingers! This is most unfortunate because the rest of the game has everything you would want! Customizable races, heroes and fleets that level up, deep/rich/interesting tech tree, lotsa resources to Xploit, customizable ships... ect ect.  It seems the dev spent all this time in creating an awesome game then spent about 10 minutes implementing a combat system before release.  If you arent into the combat aspect of 4x games you would really like this title but if interesting/tactical/fun combat is something you are looking for in a space strategy game stay away from this one!

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												You want to spend 5+ hours clicking a button? Then this game is for you. It has an amazing amount of micromanagement resulting in you constantly clicking "End turn" until something happens. As usual with games like these, it's almost impossible to balance weapons and expansion. If you spend on expansion one of your AI allies will turn on you and begin eradicating you. If you focus on weapons you miss out on colonization and research. In the end I wasted 10 hours trying this game twice and both times it was infuriating how long it took for something to actually happen. I wish I could get my money back.

Posted: April 20
												I started playing this game alot.  No tutorial.  Just learning as I go.  It seemed like something I'd really like until I got to the combat.  Literally the dumbest thing I've seen.  You'll have a war going on.  You'll mass your forces into a fleet and barricade a system.  The computer will split its army in fragments.  What this means is you can only attack 1 time per turn.  So you'll have your massive pile of army and the enemy will have it's massive pile of army as well as ten thousand fragmented individual units.  Of course when you click the attack button you can't select the big army.  Oh no you get to kill the computer's army 1 unit at a time forever because you have no control over what you attack.  That's just one system.  It will be like that at every system and I have 24.  Just pure garbage.  If I'm at my system where I barricade it before the enemy got there I should have an unlimited amount of clicks espcially if you are going to have the computer fragment its army which is ignorant in the first place.  I'm killing the enemy literally in my system.  I'd fragment my army too to compensate but you have no control over what unit attacks what unit so when you click attack with your 1 unit the computer puts that up against the huge army and not one of the fragments.  This is so stupid it made a 10/10 game a 0/10 game.  Unplayable!

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Endless SpaceThe Basics: Turn Based 4x Space Strategy GamePrevious Time Spent: 15 minutesExpectation of learning Curve: mediumWhy I bought this: Super-cheap steam sale, reviews, art styleFirst Impressions: Endless Space has lovely art and interestingly thought out factions full of intelligent beings of different mindsets and abilities. I found myself lingering over the various sliders that come with starting a game, including galaxy size, relative connectivity of star-systems, and the age of the galaxy. I was also taken aback by the differences in the groups, and found myself settling on "The Cravers," a group of cyborg-insects, which bore a strong similarity to the Borg, and seemed like an interesting start. Everything looked cool, and the first few turns seemed to provide interesting choices and goals.  My 3 hours: I spent my first hour with Endless Space trying to learn, following through in-game tutorials to make sure that I understood the systems involved in the game. I played as the Cravers for my first hour, and spent some time tooling about the galaxy and focusing on trying to colonize other worlds. I had set up the galaxy so that spreading out was fairly challenging, and my ambitions of spreading like cyber-locusts and darkening the skies of the entire Galaxy were ended when a heroic space pirate set up a blockade around my home system, effectively preventing construction and further growth. With that, I scrapped my first game, and first hour within the game. Overall, I found myself liking the feel of the game, and finding the basic systems well-described, but frustrated by a lack of external benchmarks for my performance. In hour 2, I excitedly restarted the game, this time taking on the role of some kind of birdlike warrior race (think Goose-Klingons or something), and I ended up in a less doomed starting position, but ultimately not getting very far. This came down to the barren galaxy I had chosen  to set up, and what seemed to be a relatively non-transparent system for colonizing. There are a variety of technologies needed for colonizing non-earthlike planets, and I focused too much energy on learning how to colonize fairly exotic planets, instead of covering the basics. This led to the area around me getting taken over by more pragmatic aliens, and a lot of lessons learned.In hour 3, I restarted once again, this time as a species of friendly space Amoebas. My goal here was a focus on mostly peaceful expansion throughout the cosmos. I knew the systems far better, and was this time able to concentrate on gaining the ability to colonize actually useful nearby worlds, creating a small foothold in my galactic neighborhood. I also experienced some mild conflict with my neighbors here, without ever escalating into a declared war. This allowed me to see the way the game handled combat, which I quite liked. When a battle is about to commence, you as the player don't get to control your fleets directly. Instead, you have something like a deck of tactical cards, built up by your technology and other special abilities, and play one card per combat phase, which generally dictates what your assembled fleet will do. There's a bit of a rock paper scissors match to this, with some cards effectively countering eachother at various phases. I'd like to see this in more detail in the later stages of this game, with higher technology and fleet sizes, but for the scale I saw it in, it was satifying. My Highlight:  Testing out if an opponent would be willing to declare war after I chose to destroy one of their scout vessels that had been trespassing far into my territory and threatening an area I was eyeing for colonization. I got to feel some legitimate fear as I entered combat, crushing their ships, and waiting for a diplomatic response. Realizing that my foes were too smart to be baited into war by one hostile act was exciting to see. My Verdict:  Endless Space is a game with a lot of character, and some great writing. But, ultimately, I don't see myself returning to it in the near future, as once I had the basic systems down, I more or less felt like I was clicking through turns, waiting for things to happen. I think if I had more time on my hands, my verdict might be very different, but for now, it's not for me.

												My son and I played this game for the first time today for about 3 hours when suddenly error boxes pop up twice and the game screen goes all blury. The game error windows were the only things not legible. The error windows were not from windows OS but from the game itself. We closed the game, loaded up a save, and discovered that all improvements on our planets were gone, all of our planet exploitations were gone, and the AI player went from having half our individual points to double.  This game has been out 4.5 years and they still don't have the bugs worked out. Why support a publisher that does not support it's product? I had hoped that this program would run like Master of Orions 1 or 2. We used to run an 8 player hotseat game every other weekend and MOO never crashed on an old Pentium 1 with windows 95 back in 1997. Where is the pride in craftmanship? GONE. They couldn't even come up with much original content. SOPHONS = PSILONS they even look the same.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												"2001: A Space Odyssey" AKA "Endless Space"  is a 1968 British-American science fiction film produced and directed by Stanley Kubrick. The screenplay was written by Kubrick and Arthur C. Clarke, and was partially inspired by Clarke's short story "The Sentinel". Clarke concurrently wrote the novel 2001: A Space Odyssey which was published soon after the film was released. The story deals with a series of encounters between humans and mysterious black monoliths that are apparently affecting human evolution, and a voyage to Jupiter tracing a signal emitted by one such monolith found on the Moon. The film is frequently described as an epic, both for its length and scope, and for its affinity with classical epics.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I find this game... boring.There's nothing really especially bad about it per se, it's just boring.To begin with the engine was really poor optimised, it runs really crappily on my machine and my machine is a machine that can handle Skyrim at 35 fps on medium/high settings. A 4x strategy game should not run this slowly. It was actually worse than Vanilla Civ V for how slow it was to turn.The UI is, impenetrable, to say it a single word. I don't need to say much more than that.Getting to the meat of the game. The Civilizations are boring and bland, the universe is unoriginal and uninspired. All the sci fi tropes are present. Vagrant nomad civilization? Check. Amoral secretive aliens bend on destroying the universe as we know it? Check. A currency system lifted straight out of Dune? Check.The only good thing about this game that I can say is that at least the developers -tried- to be original in one respect. The combat. It's fought with cards... for reasons... And I will be honest, I don't like it. I'd much rather direct the combat personally with the option to auto it with the cards instead of having to just use these stupid cards all the time (and let's face it card game battling in a 4x game is jarring and weird to say the least).A friend of mine recommended I buy this game over Stardrive (because apparently Stardrive is terrible) and I wish he hadn't. It was a complete waste of money for me as I felt like it was a game that was all flash/bling and no trousers/substance.I don't generally review games I don't like, because I am not a negative person but honestly this one has got to be a no from me. Don't buy.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												So, I recently got into Moo2 the other day, and upon doing reserach into the franchise, discovered remakes and clones. This one was on sale for ~$9 and I thought why not, it looked fun an interesting. Well, I was wrong. It's woefully balanced in favor if the AI. Always. I have attempted a few tries, and everytime, I am at war with a faction that is so overwpowering that I have no hope of standing a chance. And it happens way too early in the game for it to be natural gameplaying evolution. I lowered the difficulty from normal to very easy, and I get beat even worse.And if you're on a mac, there are actually fucntions of the game that just don't work (like rush production, a standard in these types of games). You are literally at the mercy of just waiting for every production, every time. You can't use your income to help at all. Sadly, I got this because it was on sale, as opposed to Master of Orion Conquer the Stars, because I really just wanted to play a game but wasn't ready to commit to $50. But I feel like the level of testing and development put into it made the $8 not worth it. And actual functionality of the game not working is a serious problem.If you have a Mac, I would recommend sataying away.

content:
Posted: April 15
												I bought this and the expansion for $1, played for about 3 hours, and I'm not sure I will pick it up again. I love the theme and universe of the game but the UI and gameplay are needlessly obtuse and repetitive.  There is too much clicking involved to get into and out of menus (click on a star system, click on a planet, select a thing for the planet to do, click out of the planet, click out of the star system, repeat with next star system/planet). A system like Attila TW for selecting provinces and then choosing upgrades from a panel at the bottom would be much better.   Combat is another weak area. I thought it would be really cool to make your own ships and choose 'cards' (tactics)  etc and it is...but it also is not:There are so many meaningless combat skirmishes that take up loads of time. Half the time the AI retreats if it is outmatched which devolves into your fleet chasing a single ship (or worse, 3 ships that split up into 3 separate fleets) all around your interior. So you ignore those and move to take enemy planets, but then these small ships just camp there and blockade your planets and strangle your economy.  Overall I have found the game to be a big frustration.   Surprisingly there are a few annoying similarities between this and the total war series (like clicking 'end turn' over and over again) but I enjoy TW much more because the gameplay feels decisive and there is a sense of accomplishment, even though Im craving for a good space game.  I would recommend that prospective buyers buy Endless Legend instead,  or something like Sins of a Solar Empire.  Ultimately for $1 it was worth a shot but if I had paid full price I would be pretty regretful now, wishing I'd bought something like Stellaris instead.

												Just another 4X space game.In this game, you manage a space empire. Expand to new planets, research technology, build ships, fight aliens, and so on. This is a turn-based strategy game. This game is nearly identical to : Master of Orion (original), Master of Orion 2, Master of Orion (modern), Space Empires V, Galactic Civilizations, Galactic Civilizations 2, Galactic Civilizations 3, Sword of the Stars, and probably a bunch of others I am forgetting. It has no notable distinguishing features, and the UI and polish are overall inferior to the likes of the Galactiv Civilizations and Master of Orion series. There is absolutely no reason to play this game if you have played some of the others.If you haven't played some of the others, there is still no reason to play this game. Pick up the latest Master of Orion or Galactic Civilizations instead.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												At 25hr play time this game is left wanting. Why is the AI so strong when I have 10X the systems resources and research? I'm built up to 10x the systems and can only research by the limited amount. How does the AI get so strong when you own 30 systems to the AI's 4 systems? How do the AI ships get 10x as strong as you with so little investment? This is entertaining for the first few hours. But then you realize it's convoluted nonsense. I can not see a path getting even close to the strength of the AI.When you compare the end game stats it makes no sense that the AI has so much more than you when they have so little. How did they get so strong while investing so little? While you are trying to figure this out. Why are you robbed at every turn? You learn nothing and can not do anything about it. Or why you are being robbed. Your stuff just vanishes. Turn after turn you go broke with no way to stop it or why it's happening. It's all convoluted nonsense that looks like a complicated game. If there is a reason it is hidden so it takes you longer to find out it's gibberish.
