content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												I don't know what it is with me and space 4X games. I love Civ V, and the same kinda thing should work in a sci fi setting. I tried Galactic Civilizations III and Sins of A Solar Empire; they both sucked. I played 17 hrs of Endless Legend until I got bored, though, so I figured I'd try Endless Space. It's not a bad game, really, just empty and lifeless. They show you a short "video" for your faction at the beginning of a game and that's about all you ever hear from them. Every faction plays the same. They all have the same technology tree and the same random events. A disease rampages through the galaxy, and it's affecting my machine empire, huh? Curious how that works. The planets don't have any personality, they're just for resources and minor customizations. I'd love to have a space 4X where you feel like the planets in your empire are real entities. This game won't even let you customize their names. If the star systems name is, say, Mars, all the planets are called Mars I through VI. I guess giving them individual names would make it harder to manage them; like if a message says "This and that happened on planet Bill Clinton", you might be like "Where's that again?", but that's only because all the planets are the same, anyway. GC3 was better at that, I guess, but it still felt bland. Starships are all the same, too, except for their looks.All in all, I can't recommend this game, except if you can get it cheap and just need something for 5 hrs, which is as far as I made it.

content:
Posted: April 14
 Endless Space	 Kosmiczna strategia grana w trybie turowym paryskiego zespołu "Amplitude"	 O grze:  Akcja gry jest w odległej przyszłości w galaktyce zamieszkiwanej przez 8 cywilizacji.Gracz wybiera postać i obejmuje kontrolę nad jedną z cywilizacj. Jego zadaniem jest zdominowanie pozostałych cywilizacji. Wszystkie strony wykonują swoje ruchy jednocześnie, co znacznie przyśpiesza zabawę w trybie multiplayer.W świecie gry znajdziemy setki planetarnych systemów i każdy z nich posiada randomowe : planety , surowce oraz sekrety. Autorzy przygotowali też rozbudowany system modyfikowania statków, który pozwala samodzielnie wybrać uzbrojenie, napęd, opancerzenie oraz systemy pokładowe każdej jednostki.Nie zabrakło również elementów dyplomacji. Rasy mogą zawierać sojusze, zawieszenia broni, prowadzić wymianę surowców, technologii a nawet całych układów planetarnych.  Moja opinia  Ta gra jest bardzo rozbudowana oraz miła do gry. Zarównież trzeba użyć sprytnośći oraz inteligencji. Reseachować inne rzeczy. Przejmować planety na których tworzy się kojene statki do walki , defensywy oraz do przejmowania innych planet. Oraz ustawiać na planetach co mają tam robić twoi. Atakować inne cywlizcje. Bronić się przed nimi.Według mnie ta gra jest opłacalna do zakupu jej.  Oceny  GRYonline.pl (8.8/10)  gram.pl (9.0/10)  Moja ocena (9,5/10)  Ogólna ocena użytkowników steam (8.5/10)  Ocena ostatniego miesiąca użytkowników steam (5,0/10)  PLUSY I MINUSY [h1 PLUSY [/h1] -Rozwinięta gra-Mało bugów-Zoptymalizowana-Miła rozgrywka-Dużo trybów trudności-Multiplayer-Gra turowa-Reseache-Duże rozwinięcie (typu: Układy planet itd...)-Ładna grafika ... MINUSY  -Długa gra-Trudne sterowanie dla tych co kupili tę grę dopiero.-Trudne początki-Brak rozwinięcia języków (Polski)  Reszty minusów nie mam do tej gry  Wymagania sprzętowe  Rekomendowane: Core i5 2.6 GHz, 2 GB RAM, karta grafiki 512 MB (GeForce 8800 lub lepsza), 2 GB HDD, Windows XP (SP3)/Vista/7, łącze internetowe [h1 Czy grę opłaca się kupić [/h1] Według mnie to : "Nie". Gra wymaga sporo pieniędzy na kupno jej. "34,99€" Dla tych którzy nie mają dużo doładowań do "Steam" i często ich nie stać na takiej ceny gry to nie zbyt fajna sprawa. Ale jeżeli ktoś ma dużo pieniędzy na steam lub chce tą grę kupić to "Tak". Gra jest tak według mnie ( Pół na pół ) warta kupna.  POLECAM

number of helpful: 7 of 22 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16
												Please ignore the limited time spent in game, as I discovered the reason for my review in the extra research I did after purchasing the game on sale.In short, in a game that is very like SotS, Civilizations, and SoaSE (which have teams,) there are no teams (only temporary alliances) and only one player can win. You cannot win with a friend, and will eventually have to either crush them or just quit the game. In all fairness to the developer and players who think this is a piddly reason for a negative review, consider this. Many players purchase games like this specifically to play with their friends, and it should be a relatively easy thing to add, so how could both they and we benefit from such a move??? Why is this a review and not on their forums???	Quite simply this is because the game has been out for 5 years and Disharmony out for 3, so this change is most likely never going to happen, nor will it happen 1 year after its launch like it should've.To those who say this would've broken the game: 1. It would also be easy to lock this feature to Singleplayer and Private Multiplayer to keep it out of public servers.2. It will not break YOUR game, it will only break the games of those who CHOOSE to use team systems.To those who say  it wasn't worth it, there were two bonuses there:1. Adding Co-op to the tags opens up the game to a wider market, not only to players with co-op friends but also to less strategic minded players who wouldn't be able to win singleplayer without a bot on their team.2. The change would detract froms reviews like this.To those that think co-op is dumb for this game:1. Sins of a Solar Empire2. Civ 53. Sword of the Stars4. Galactic Civilizations II5. Supreme Commander (V and FA)Name one, RTS or 4X, that doesn't benefit experience-wise from playing with your friends.

content:
Posted: April 14
												I enjoy real-time strategies - I can't say I always enjoy turn-based, but I've disregarded that for my review. When I saw this for a buck, I figured I'd grab it. Somehow, I feel robbed. I feel like a lot of work went into it, and it's worth that whole dollar to someone, but not me. In no way could I ever see it being worth $30. That's ludicrous. At most, I see this being originally released at $10 and something I might find on a Wal-Mart shelf along with some hidden object games.The UI is terrible, the font makes me feel like I'm working, the game has so much minutia that it clouds gameplay and the gameplay itself was just, well, boring. If I was younger, and had an endless summer with no end in-sight... no, even then I don't think I'd recommend it; there are much better games out there.So, I don't think this is worth even a dollar, albeit, I have known people that enjoy tedium that's a result of poor design, not interesting gameplay, have their lives to waste away, don't mind the lack of any inspiring content, can happily click their life away to no real benefit and don't mind staring down the Arial font for hours on-end. If you find yourself in that camp, you might enjoy it. I still, though, even to those poor souls, would not recommend it. Go, find yourself a friend. Maybe pick up a hobby that meets in groups.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												The only interesting thing about this game is the exploration. Everything else is pretty dull really. Designing your own ships seems interesting but I found it all a bit complicated and in the end just ended up pressing the Auto upgrade button. Every 10 turns or something. Which is exactly what the AI does and this comes apparent when you are attacked by a bunch of ships 'xxx Destroyer 78'. Which leads on to combat, which is dull. You have 2 options, Manual and Auto. Manual supposedly lets you choose 'cards' to play but is basically a cut scene. Auto just skips the cutscene. Unless your fleet is massively larger than the other fleet, it will be a draw.Invading other systems seems to be if your invade score is bigger than their defend score. Then how long it takes is dependant on the difference. So, if your attacking score is 3600 and their defend score is 2500, then it will only take about 60 turns to invade. Snore.  I know at their core all games are just about numbers but most games hide this fact. Endless Space doesn't. It is a very thinly veiled numbers game.I tried to like it, I really did. MOO2 is one of my favourite games but I guess I'm still looking for a decent replacement because this ain't it.

number of helpful: 0 of 10 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Nope. Just Nope. You guys know.I am seriously a Fan of Games in this Genre. And Generally Endless Space is not an Bad Idea. Its just that the actual Result they got Sucks. Many Events and other Stuff just have no Real Explanation. Hell you get Events of stuff and have no Idea what even happened cause its not even telling you were something happened on your Planets. Needless to say that you first have to look into each nook and cranny to find out what stuff is even doing at all. And even then sometimes there is just some Modifier and you got no idea that it was there or why its there....The Interface in General is very annoying. Alot of stuff requires you to Check every system manually over and over. And you cant just Build everything on one Place to build out one System you have to Search for the Stuff on each Planet itself. But you know.The Interface and Events and all that Stuff can be Acceptable.It makes the Game really hard to get into as an Beginner. But once you know everything. You can Play it fairly Good with that. The 2 Things really Breaking this Game for me. Are 1. That the Game is entirely Unstable in Multiplayer.After Round 100 you can Expect it to Crash or Freeze once per 20 Turns. Which is entirely Unacceptable. 2.The Game is creating an very very stupid mix. Its setting you up in very small Places right next to other Empires thus pretty much forcing you into an very fast paced Combat situation. While at the same Time Combat is entirely Automatic only allowing for minimal Influence from your Side. The Strong Point of this Game which is Management and Strategy is Completely Dropped because you never get a Chance to really make use of it. As even on the absolute biggest Map Settings you will meet the First Enemy in Turn 30 and thats given your really Lucky. But the Combat Aspect of the Game is seriously not worth mentioning. It lacks replayability. So even if Winning a War your just not feeling Good on it. Because well your basicly just cliking through the Combat after a While because there is no real sense in doing anything else. So in the End.It could have been a Great Game if they would have Fixed the Stability Issues. And would have Enlarged the Maps so you can actually make some use of the good Parts of the Game and dont end up thrown into a War right away anyways.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												This game is not friendly for people who have no experience with this sort of thing. There are so many missed opportunities in the tutorials for learning such a complex system. In selecting a standard single-player game, all there is are walls of text and still portraits that "explain" things to you.Walls upon walls upon walls of text. Trump style walls. There are no animations, voices, or interactions. Factions are explained in text. Help is explained in text. The tutorial is nothing but text. The only thing I saw in trying this game that has video and voices are the short videos after you select a faction.Make no mistake, there is TONS of potential here, but they really dropped the ball on the immersion for outsiders. To its credit, it seems like a game that would get better and give back 100x the more time you put in to it; however, like a good novel, you must be drawn in at the beginning too.Not recommended unless you know what you're getting in to and have a lot of time, energy, and patience to put in to it.

												well i can see why people are marking this game down to negitive. it was confusing at first but then i guess i started to understand it. sometimes a stray ship will come to my planet and offer services or peace but as im reading that text it disappears and end's my turn...im i missing something? or is that a bug? i dont remember pressing end turn. this happened many different times. also its sort of lame to keep ending your turn just to research technology. theres soooo much technology to research and as you try to un-lock the higher technologies it gets longer and longer and longer to accomplish. 10 turns. then its 20 turns.. then its 50+ turns. i dont have time for that. why not just have a timer count down instead of ending a turn? arnt my researchers researching even when im NOT ending a turn? do my researchers only work when i end my turn telling them to end a day's work? thats rediculous. real researchers have a time table to complete their work.  either you end a real day or not. real people researchers dont have to end a day to accomplish a lengthy research task. its almost like your telling me that by ending my turn im giving my tiny invisiable researchers the power to gain knowledge. why not just have a timer? like a 5 minute timer? or a 10 minute timer that counts down? we dont have time to keep pressing end turn, end turn...its rediculouswell i guess i cant complain. i paid $1 for this enture game. i think alot of people did

												It's a good game -- see other reviews for pros/cons, but at the end of the day it nails just-one-more-turn -- but I don't recommend it unless on sale, for the soundtrack. The reason is simple: planet text in the system screen (which you spend a lot of time in) is horribly blurry! I've spent a fair bit of time playing with game and computer graphics settings but to no avail. Internet research shows that this is not unique to my computer. It's a shame though, because other screens such as the galaxy overview, skill tree, and combat UI are all crystal clear. Oh, well...Just save your money for Endless Space 2 if you're concerned.

Posted: April 13
												Dripping with neckbeard humanist self-indulgent fantasy, I feel like I paid too much at $1.00.  The tutorial about as fun as reading a textbook for a class in which you accidentally enrolled.  The interface is clunky and unintuitive.  I love simulation games, but this one just missed the mark for me.  I don't understand all the gushing praise.  It's just a Civ game re-skinned in space with all the polish of an open-source Linux tool made in someone's basement.  Just go play Civ again or perhaps Farm Simulator.  You'll be much better off.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Endless Space is a 4X game in every way, shape, and form, all presented in a beautiful science fiction setting. As per usual, you'll gather resrouces, expand your empire, and try to rule the galaxy in a variety of ways. What I love most about Endless Space: 1. One of the most impressive UIs I've ever used in a game of this kind. Seamless controls, intuitive, easy to learn. The design of the UI is just flat-out brilliant. 2. The variety of ships and combat strategies separate this game from most 4X games. Instead of just a results screen, you can watch combat unfold in epic real-time, even controlling the camera in any way you want. So combat, while still essentially all based on mathematical values, is visually stunning and fun. Where I think Endless Space lacks: 1. As with most 4X games, diplomacy is weird and factions can do some very random things. For instance, a faction offered me a Cooperative Alliance which I accepted. I hit "end turn" and they declared war on me. Strange, but common to me in my experience playing these types of games. 2. More of personal hope, more compatibility between Mac and PC, so that my brother and I don't have to try several times to get a multiplayer match going. :) All in all, if you are a fan of 4X games and want a scifi themed one, look no further. Endless Space is beautiful to look at, a breeze to control while playing, and a very in-depth game experience.

(missles are best at long range while kinetic weps are best for close). You can customize each of your ships to be whatever kind of comatants you wish. Very well detailed turn based space deplomacy/economic/scientific/conquest stratogy game. 9/10

Posted: June 26, 2014
												Amazing turn-based strategy, one of the best I've played in years. The gameplay is well planned, the balance between the factions and their racial abilities is kept, it's not overly boring or frustrating thanks to the quick pace, so even if nothing special happens for a few turns you won't feel it that much. The storyline, although a bit in the background, is also well thought out. This position is a great choice for any strategy lovers out there. It will keep you warm during long, cold, winter nights, and cool during the summer :P.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												A quite good 4X game which seems to take its inspiration from the legendary classic Master of Orion 2.True to its forefathers there are custom races which compete for the mastery of the galaxy with multiple possible victory options. This means planet management, technology trees, ship design and to an extent diplomacy with heroes added to the mix. The space combat is nicely animated (if you want to have a look at how it goes) and is resolved neatly in phases with rock-scissors-paper style tactics which can make or break the battle. Even though at it seems to have all the elements and these are decently implemented, there is still something missing, which eventually drops the game to only quite good. The problem is that it is streamlined and polished to an extent that nothing really sticks out. The technologies go forward and help you in your campaign, but there are no death rays or anything else to look forward for. The events in the galaxy are only text boxes to click through and diplomatic relations feel the same regardless of the races involved. So in a long run it just dries up to turns executed in a routine fashion and statistics. Still, while this game does not really compare to the legends, it is still an entertaining exercise to play though and can be recommended to fans of the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Truely amazing game. A packed tech tree, split up into different catagories to control your empire. Unlike other games like this, you can create your own ships by adding different components to the standard ship. Graphics are excellent quality and instead of a user directing the ships in combat, the combat options are chosen from a selection that gets bigger as you discover more technology, then the combat happens automatically or you have the option to watch it. The diplomacy GUI is well done with all options available at the time easy to spot and you can see the diplomatic relations between the other factions. The galaxy maps have seemless zoom in and out but could do with an expantion and made much bigger, as it can get a little cluttered. Bigger maps are always a good idea.Finally just remember there's always that one faction hell bent on taking over the galaxy, the trick is to make sure that its you.

												That old 4X feeling!Not since the days of Master of Orion 2 have I enjoyed a Space 4X as much as Endless Space. It had a clean interface, great combat visuals, and a solid blend of ease-of-use and customization. While certain management aspects feel too easy on the standard difficultly level, it does provide a good learning curve, allowing you to juggle all of the elements of your empire with ease.The combat is the real stand out element, as the tactics choices for each phase (Long, Medium, and Melee) really add a strong element of player control, without slowing down the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Overall, the idea behind this game is a good one, and the setting is a lot of fun. ES takes a lot of the things I love about other titles, like Master of Orion 2 and Sins of a Solar Empire, and combines them into a pretty decent 4x game. However, the game can be buggy at times, the races and techs are unbalanced, and the AI is horrible.Computer players seems fun and interesting, at first, with a variety of reactions to your proposals and to the way you build your empire, but in the end, it's almost always the same: The other races start declaring war on you, one after the other, often seemingly out of nowhere; this is simply because (among the many factors that can influence AI attitudes)...you're doing well. Winning makes everyone hate you, apparently. Expand too much? War. Expand too quickly? War. Get too far ahead in science? War. Monopoly on valuable resources? War. Build too many ships? War. Make friends with too many other races? War. Score gets too high? War. That means, in the end, because war is pretty much inevitable, the only rewarding or realistic way to win is by determined conquest. There's a diplomacy, scientific, expansion, "supremacy," and even an economic victory option, but they're all a pain to attempt when you're constantly at war and having to account for that.Endless Space is pretty; it's creative in a lot of ways; and it manages to hold my interest when I'm playing with humans, who are less predictable and a lot more entertaining. Overall, I recommend the game, but as a multiplayer experience: Skip the single player and don't bother with AI opponents if you want the most for your money, unless you like playing the same wargame over and over and over. Until the developer improves the AI and does some rebalancing, I can't in good consicence  really say anything positive about the single-player experience.

content:

												FIRST IMPRESSIONS: it has one of the best interfaces I've seen in a 4X game in a long (long!) time. Streamlined, polished, modern... whatever action/item you want access to is usually no farther than 2 clicks away. This is not a minor feat, since interface is what you are constantly interacting with in these kind of games. Combat system, with its "card game" mechanics, is a mixed bag -I liked so far, but I can undersand people reacting negatively to it. I think I will have a more educated opinion with a couple of dozen hours of gamplay under my belt, but as I said, so far combat is working for me. Tech tree is comprehensive and intrincate, nothing to envy of Galactic Civilizations or Sid Meier's Civilization itself. Exploring is compelling and empire management hits the right balance between being detailed but not overwhelming.As I said, these are just FIRST IMPRESSIONS, with only around 5 hours of gameplay. Most important feature yet to evaluate is AI; too litlle interaction yet. So far, I recommend this game as a true succesor of GalCivII. I will update further down the road.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2013
												A really complex, yet simple looking and nice programed, game with a spacial theme. The new Civ 5 spaceship brother comes to us with this amazing independent game. I'm still wondering the effort it took for making this game, it looks amazing, and doesn't need a super computer to work; mechanics are pretty well designed, you can even use the AI to aid you, programming it for constructing, for example; battles are, a bit strange coming from this type of games, it reminds me some kind of rock-paper-scissors kid game, but much more complex than it seems, you really have to plan every bit of the battle to trully have a considerable advantage, and believe me I've seen from small fleets destroying great armies with a good usage of the strategy, to massive fleets obliterating everything without need of any tactic at all; economics is a great part of the game too, taxation is a very important part, and is directly related with aproval (this is, how much your people likes you, bread and circus and you have an empire), and everything is related to this, food (which is related to population), industry (production,have it high and you will build armies in a couple of turns), and science (believe me, science is very, very important in this game).There are also events, relics, heroes...and everything that makes a good game of this style just lovely and addictive.We have enough for saying this is a great game, and I'm willing to have more from this Endless adventure :)I give it a 9 / 10, I really like the freedom it gives, makes you feel you are playing with your faction, and that's amazing. AI is a huge bonus to the game too. On the other hand, graphics and design are great too, but music isn't amazing, just "enough", it works, makes the job done, but I know games that music is omg...indescriptible.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												While Endless Space certainly has some problems the good far outweigh the bad. Most likely people will hear about the combat, how it's essentially a guessing game and you have no direct control over the ships. The combat is mainly based around manuvers and abilities cosen before a certain "Round" if you will, starts. All of these are unlocked through the tech tree, which can seem dauting at first glance but once one reads the descriptors it becomes more apparent. The map design is well done, and actually resembles a strange alien galaxy. The story is a bit confusing but story is rarely important to a 4x game of any sort, most of the time the player makes up their own story. The ability to make a custom race added alot to the immersion, allowing the choice of ship aesthetics and bonuses to the game. Some act as though this game is a spiritual successor to Master of Orion 2 (or 1 they were both awesome), it really isnt. While it is similar in a few ideals it is it's own game. Endless Space is a good 4x space game, with its wonderful graphics and smooth gameplay its a wonder this didn't get to be more widespread. It's challenging but not without being fun. A good choice for any fan of the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Endless Space is a complex, gorgeous and heavily emphasized on overall strategy game that changes the pace from the conventional 4X games such as Civilization. Amplitude studios have came up with a most flamboyant game that will ignite your screen with a palette of vibrant colours and one can easily spent countless hours contemplating the elegance of the endless space. The dept of each technology trees, decisions about diplomatic relationships, positioning of fleets and planetary expansion makes the game feel alive to your every decisions, as you try to negotiate a truce to secure your stern while positioning your fleets to invade a hostile nation.However the game is not without its shortcomings: although there are multiple ways to secure a victory the AI seems to always put an emphasis on domination victory (war), even pacifist nations such as the Sophons will eventually agress you. Furthermore, the game is axed on the overview of galatic conquest and players who are expecting an up-close and more tactical real-time strategy mechanics will be disappointed. The game does offer cinematics for space engagement only, but players will be unable to control their fleets directly, instead they will be asked to issue general commands to be used during the skirmishes and much like a rock-paper-scissor pattern some commands are superior to others and each have their own weakness. Overall, this is a game I would only recommend to space science fiction fans who values high quality graphics and do not mind the lack of real time strategy aspect. For all its pros and cons, Endless Space is a (7.5/10 - above average) in my personal opinion.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Endless Space has you playing a turn based game very reminiscent to the final space age mode of the Maxis game ‘Spore’ along with the mapping structure of said title and others like Galactic Civilizations I and II.Both games display forms of colonization, terra forming and research to upgrade your planets. Endless Space takes on a less direct approach than Spore however, eliminating the space to planet surfacing system that Spore displays for direct town upgrades such as turrets.Instead Endless space gives you a huge verity of research upgrades that can benefit anything from your tech, military prowess, planet upgrades (including money, defenses, offences weapons and fleet sizes) and diplomacy. There are 8-10 races to choose from or you can make your own race using one of the avatars provided in game, whilst picking your own pros and cons to balance said race.The galaxy can feel empty without getting to put a face or faces to your empire, which was addressed within Endless Space. Giving you multiple heroes at your disposal, three are given to you each time you start the game, completely at random. You do need to hire them though and your max hero quota is 3 to begin with, but can be upgraded through tech. Heroes also have classes. Multi classes can be found on each hero, but they always start with a preselected 2 that are constant for that hero in every game. Ranging from warrior types such as Spy, commander and Pilot, plus other types that benefit planets and systems more so.I only have one thing bad to say about the game that really isn’t bad. The tutorial system in the game is vast and helps out, but only to a certain degree as it is only text based. Throughout my first 3-5 playthroughs I found myself still confused about little things that stumped me as I went along. Such as keeping my population happy, how to keep up with my fellow civilizations that were developing within the same system as myself.All in all it is a great game; all it really needs is an upgraded tutorial system in my opinion, perhaps voiced instead of text based, or both at the same time.Pros: Immersive game playextreme detailing for an indie gameHuge upgrade tree systemWide verity of races and heroesBang for your buck.Cons: You blink and the time goes by.Despite a vast text tutorial you’re left confused and moments that will be vital in the long run.8.5/10

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												A more polished and flashy but slightly less fun version of Galactic Civilizations 2.  That is not to say Endless Space is bad, no not at all, just sort of uninteresting at times with turns that literally have to be just clicked through.  A lot of the random events arent as fun or involve decisions, and the cinematic strategy card battle system is different and gives you some mild form of input, but is still kinda meh.  The overall graphics, user interface, and presentation are all very good in my opinion.  Other strong points are that the 8 or 9 different races all have an interesting little backstory compared to some other 4x games, and they actually do play a little differently.  The tech tree provides some unique options for each race and provides enough info about the techs that it feels more like actually discovering something instead of just "lasers 1, lasers 2, lasers 3" type progression like most 4x games.  Overall its not quite the deepest or most involved strategy game but its certainly worth a spin if you are a fan of this genre or are looking to try out a turn based strategy game that is a bit easier to pick up than say something like Europa Univeralis or Crusader Kings.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Overall, the idea behind this game is a good one, and the setting is a lot of fun. ES takes a lot of the things I love about other titles, like Master of Orion 2 and Sins of a Solar Empire, and combines them into a pretty decent 4x game. However, the game can be buggy at times, the races and techs are unbalanced, and the AI is horrible.Computer players seems fun and interesting, at first, with a variety of reactions to your proposals and to the way you build your empire, but in the end, it's almost always the same: The other races start declaring war on you, one after the other, often seemingly out of nowhere; this is simply because (among the many factors that can influence AI attitudes)...you're doing well. Winning makes everyone hate you, apparently. Expand too much? War. Expand too quickly? War. Get too far ahead in science? War. Monopoly on valuable resources? War. Build too many ships? War. Make friends with too many other races? War. Score gets too high? War. That means, in the end, because war is pretty much inevitable, the only rewarding or realistic way to win is by determined conquest. There's a diplomacy, scientific, expansion, "supremacy," and even an economic victory option, but they're all a pain to attempt when you're constantly at war and having to account for that.Endless Space is pretty; it's creative in a lot of ways; and it manages to hold my interest when I'm playing with humans, who are less predictable and a lot more entertaining. Overall, I recommend the game, but as a multiplayer experience: Skip the single player and don't bother with AI opponents if you want the most for your money, unless you like playing the same wargame over and over and over. Until the developer improves the AI and does some rebalancing, I can't in good consicence  really say anything positive about the single-player experience.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												To get it straight. This game is not Master of Orion and it is not meant to be. It obviously takes a few of the old school elements like the turn based approach but that's about it.The game by itself is neatly done. The AI can be tricky for starters but its not unbeatable.People complaining about missing videos and storyline seem to miss the idea about this 4x style game and the fact that it was an Indie-production. It is supposed to do some things differently!The game does what it is supposed to. Entertain the strategy fans of us. There is no rule for how deep certain aspects have to go in order to be well done. This is just a matter of personal preference. Obviously the balancing of technologies or the rock-paper-scissor-system can be critizied but this will happen even if we all the sudden had a new shiny version of MoO2.People just love to b*tch about how things have been better before.So, to come to a conclusion. This game would be a solid 8´-8,5 out of 10 if people could abstain from downvoting just for not liking the idea. Sure it can be rated lower if you do not like it. but giving a 0-2 for a fully functional and neatly done title is a joke. Makes the complete user review idea abundant.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I had really been looking for something in space to replace Civilization 4 and with several hundred hours played in Civ 4 I feel I can speak pretty well. This game has depth, customization, the ability to automate(effectively I will add, I have not seen the automation do anything I wouldn't have except for when I am focusing on a certain starting strategy so far) the mundane brainless activities so you can really get down to the nitty gritty fun parts of the game like HEY dude I just made it through the first half of the game without having to do too much point-click upgrade this brainlessness. The game really focuses on the fun parts of the turn-based strategy genre: what to research and when for the most streamlined development, what race fits your playstyle most, and most importantly making your way through the game while still being completely enveloped in its atmosphere. Lets face it, turn-based games aren't fun because of how long each turn takes, but because your strategy works best. TLDR: I don't know where the talent that gave us Diablo 1 & 2, Fable, and others went but these guys got it right. This is what quality games should be and put anything else out there these days to shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Sort review, worth a fiver (quid)Longer review I got this game cheap, and for the price i paid (a few quid at the time) it was a good purchase, it can be fun managaing your empire to win either a military, financial or diplomatic victory but while its fun the game does have some let downs, although these let downs could easily be fixed with updates and continued support These are the let downs that nagged me the most.Crashing, end of string error or something like that will become your worst nightmare on this game, although its quite good at auto saving so when it does give you that error and crash, you haven't lost too much, but still annoying as heck.'clunky' controls, it seems to me like sometimes i have to double click or re-try a set of commands in order to get my ships to follow it, not much of a problem but it really is annoying.Want a full scale, insanely massive war? Too bad, max ships you can build in 1 fleet is about 23, and those are the rubbish ships, i want the limit raised so i can have massive numbers of heavy war ships flying around the galaxy tearing through any fleet i come across, plus, a space battle just isn't the same with four or five heavy ships compared to 40-50 of the buggers. Yes you can have alot of fleets, but I would like to see bigger numbers of ships in these fleets for even better space battlesOptomisation problems, i run a cross fire (2x7950's overclocked) and this game doesn't understand what that is so runs my 2nd GPU at max and the first GPU barely warms up (to solve this i had to disable crossfire), when this game could easily be ran on probably Intel HD4400 graphics.  Although it does have some frame rate issues mid battle, which for the graphics and cards im running is a little dissapointing.It seems there is only one music track (or multiple similar sounding tracks), which for a game where you can spend hours playing, you really like a change every now and again. So I often get some music going on YT and reduce sound of game. The initial game instructions left me scratching my head confused as hell as to how to play the game, I had to actually go off the game and watch youtube videos to work out how to actually play. Actually a second thought, SP mission modes would be good for this game to ease you more into whats going on.Battle system is meh at best, you have cards and tactics that you can chose for your ships to use, but nothing more, it would be nice to place ships and be able to give each ship you control an order, e.g you target this ship, defend this ship to the death, you ram this one or something like that would give the battle part of this game an awesome edge over some comp.So as you can see this game has got some things that could be improved but dont let that put you off, it really is a good fun game, but beware, if you buy, give it patcience to learn how to play and time for a game, it can be a very long enduring game.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Civilization meets Sword of the Stars, meets Galatic Civilizations 2.  Meet other races, befriend them or kill them, Research technology, develop your infastructure, colonize new planets and solar systems, expand your resource base. Conquer the Galaxy.The interface is easy to figure out and movement around the galaxy is MUCH better than SOTS.Another nice aspect of this game is you can design, build and upgrade your starships as you see fit. You can create Dreadnoughs full of Missiles or Curisers loaded with Beam Weapoons...etc. The computer players will change their ship designs based on your designs, so what worked in the previous battle may not work the next. This forces you to adapt your strategy.If you are going to buy it, look for the Gold Edition with the expasnion pack for even more fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Lots of fun to conquer the galaxy, build neat ships, out-tech opponents and exploit planets. One thing worth noting is that the screenshots with all of the space battles are all cinematics, you aren't actually controlling anything when that is on the screen. Battles have three phases where you pick an action to perform and the you can watch a cinematic to see how it plays out. Overall I played about 20 hours before I got bored/frustrated with the mechanics. I found that the macro game got quite tedious and there were a few things which I would have liked to see automated-streaming battleships from a star system to the battlezone (basically infinite construction of a specific ship type and have them move to a specific point after being created)-automate battles: when I had a lot of fleets 10-20 and each turn had roughly that many battles it was tedious to select battle cards for all phases (leaving them blank puts you at a big disadvantage). It would have been great to see an AI for fleets similar to what happened for systemsI would recommend this for people that like Risk, or the Galactic Conquest campaign in Star Wars Battlefront (although it lacks the high-intensity action of the actual battles).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Endless Space is a 4X game in every way, shape, and form, all presented in a beautiful science fiction setting. As per usual, you'll gather resrouces, expand your empire, and try to rule the galaxy in a variety of ways. What I love most about Endless Space: 1. One of the most impressive UIs I've ever used in a game of this kind. Seamless controls, intuitive, easy to learn. The design of the UI is just flat-out brilliant. 2. The variety of ships and combat strategies separate this game from most 4X games. Instead of just a results screen, you can watch combat unfold in epic real-time, even controlling the camera in any way you want. So combat, while still essentially all based on mathematical values, is visually stunning and fun. Where I think Endless Space lacks: 1. As with most 4X games, diplomacy is weird and factions can do some very random things. For instance, a faction offered me a Cooperative Alliance which I accepted. I hit "end turn" and they declared war on me. Strange, but common to me in my experience playing these types of games. 2. More of personal hope, more compatibility between Mac and PC, so that my brother and I don't have to try several times to get a multiplayer match going. :) All in all, if you are a fan of 4X games and want a scifi themed one, look no further. Endless Space is beautiful to look at, a breeze to control while playing, and a very in-depth game experience.

												This game is amazing. Even though this is my first 4x genre game, I still have a blast every time I play this. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I can really only recommend this game if you enjoy playing 4x strategy games. Overall this game is very visually appealing with interesting character designs and stunning ship designs. Initially I thought that the introductory lore behind each of the races was compelling but the story doesn't develop any further than that and there isn't any real interaction between races outside of diplomatic actions. After trying out the game with all of the different races there is not a whole lot of really distinguishable differences in gameplay between the different races and even the tech trees for all of the races are exactly the same, so it becomes less of a tech tree and more of an arms race. The space battles are fun to watch, especially once the largest ship types are available. However the battle strategy is determined before the battle starts which may turn some people off. Endless Space is a worthy entry in 4x strategy games, however I'm hoping if a sequel is developed that Amplitude Studios improves on what is good with this game and adds more story, more interaction between races, and maybe just maybe include some gameplay that goes more indepth into invading a system and laying siege on individual planets. Maybe even include some mechanic where each colonized planet in a system has to be conquered before a player can take control of a system? Come for the art design, stay for the space battles.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Many people compare this game with the classic space 4x game, Master of Orion 2. As one who sunk many hours into that game, I can see where thay are comming from; this game containes (and in some cases improves) many of the features that I loved, but still keeps a few that I hated.Heres the things I like about it:Heroes are much more Dynamic in their leveling, with their own skill trees and abilities.The races are more diverse while still containing the same point buy system from its predessors.The planetary anomolies, giving bonusses and penalties to planets throughout the galaxy.Some things I hate about it:While the card system is an interesting idea, it still dosen't change the fact that combat is either an automatic uninteresting button click, or a painfully long cinimatic experience. Though to be fair it is an improvement to MoO2.Late game fleet managment is a nightmare of navigating through menus and figuring out who is where and who still has a turn.The AI (both Player and Improvement) is terrable. The Improvement AI will constantly Build military building that aren't nessasary and eat up your dust (money).final thoughts: If you like MoO2 or Alpha Centauri and want another game like that than you have to look no further. If you were expecting something else, then it's best to keep moving.
